Quote: They will be made to stumble
Note: The writer speaks of God’s causing the evildoers’ plans to fail as if God were making them stumble in their paths. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God will make them stumble” or “God will cause their plans to fail” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: since their own tongues are against them
Note: Here “tongues” represents the words that they say. Alternate translation: “since the words that they say are against them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Alternate translation: “what God has done”
Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. Alternate translation: “go to him for protection” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: all the upright in heart will take pride in him
Note: Here “upright in heart” is an idiom that means godly or righteous. Alternate translation: “all the people who are godly will praise him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

# Psalm 065 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 65 is a psalm of praise to God.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### God’s power
God answered prayers and gave the people justice and hope. God created nature and controls it, sending rain so the grain and pastures grow well.
# General Information:\n\nThis psalm is a song of praise. Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “This is for the director of music to use in worship”

Quote: For you, God in Zion, our praise waits
Note: This speaks of praise as if it were a person who could act on its own. Alternate translation: “To you alone, God in Zion, we will offer our praise” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: our vows will be carried out to you
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “we will do what we have promised you that we would do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

David speaks about iniquity as if it were a person that is able to defeat or oppress. Alternate translation: “It is as if our own sins were defeating us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
The word “them” refers to our “iniquities.”
The words “you” and “your” in this verse refer to Yahweh.
This exaggeration expresses that the man is in the temple very frequently to worship Yahweh. Alternate translation: “worship often in your courts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])

Quote: We will be satisfied with the goodness of your house, your holy temple
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The goodness of your house, your holy temple, will satisfy us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Here the word “we” refers to David and the people of Israel, but not to God, to whom he is speaking. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])
Alternate translation: “your house, which is your holy temple”
Alternate translation: “Because you are righteous”
Alternate translation: “you are”

Quote: of all the ends of the earth & across the sea
Note: These two phrases have similar meanings. Alternate translation: “of all the people who live throughout the earth and across the sea” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

Quote: of all the ends of the earth
Note: This refers to the people who live all over the earth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: you who are belted with strength
Note: The writer speaks of God as if he wore his strength like a belt. Alternate translation: “showing that you are very powerful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the roaring of the seas, the roaring of their waves
Note: These two phrases have the same meaning and are used together to create a vivid impression on the hearer or reader. Alternate translation: “the continuous roaring of the seas” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
a loud noise caused by the wind and waves
This is also something that God makes quiet.
loud noise
proof or something that shows that another thing is true

Quote: you make the east and the west rejoice
Note: The phrase “the east and the west” refers to the people who live all over the earth. Alternate translation: “you cause people everywhere to shout joyfully” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
This refers to the soil of the earth.
Alternate translation: “you make the soil very good so that good things will grow in it”

Quote: the river of God is full of water
Note: This refers to the supply of water in the sky that God sends to water the earth and fill the streams. Alternate translation: “you fill the streams with water” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
The writer is speaking to Yahweh, so these words are all singular. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
Alternate translation: “the earth’s furrows”
A furrow is a long narrow trench made in the ground for planting seeds or for watering the field where grains have been planted.
edges
The words “You” and “your” refer to Yahweh and so are singular. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])

Quote: You crown the year with your goodness
Note: Here the “year” is given the human quality of wearing a crown. Alternate translation: “You have honored the year with a good harvest” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: your wagon tracks overflow with abundance
Note: Yahweh making the soil so good and fertile that it produces an abundant harvest is spoken of as if Yahweh were traveling through an empty land in a cart, leaving abundant food behind wherever he goes. Alternate translation: “everywhere you have been, you have left abundant food” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
There is so much dew in the pastures that they are said to drip with it. Alternate translation: “The pastures … are full of dew” or “Much dew drips in the pastures of the wilderness”

Quote: the hills are clothed with joy
Note: The writer speaks of the beauty of the hills as if they were joyful people, and of joy as if it were clothing. Alternate translation: “the hills are like people wearing joy” or “the hills are like joyful people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: The pastures are clothed with flocks
Note: The writer speaks of the pastures as being so covered with flocks that it is like the pastures are wearing a garment.
a large field where animals feed on the grass
group of animals, such as sheep and goats

Quote: they shout for joy, and they sing
Note: The pastures, hills and valleys are so bountiful, that they seem to shout and sing for joy. Alternate translation: “they are like joyful singing people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
The word “they” refers to the pastures and valleys.

# Psalm 066 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 66 is a psalm of praise.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh saves
Just as God brought Israel through the wilderness, he took the author through hard times but saved him. The author will worship God by sacrificing animals to him. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/save]])
# General Information:\n\nThis psalm is a song of praise. Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “This is for the director of music to use in worship”

Quote: Make a joyful noise to God, all the earth
Note: A “joyful noise to God” represents singing and shouting praises to God. Alternate translation: “Let all the earth sing and shout joyfully to God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
This refers to all the people who live on the earth. Alternate translation: “everyone on earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Sing out the glory of his name; make his praise glorious
Note: These phrases have similar meanings and are used together to emphasize how wonderful God is. Alternate translation: “Sing about how wonderful God’s name is; sing wonderful praise about how great God is” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
God’s name here represents God himself. Alternate translation: “his glory” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
The works of God cause us to be in awe and terrified because we know he is powerful and holy.

Quote: By the greatness of your power
Note: Alternate translation: “Because you have great power”

Quote: All the earth will worship you
Note: This refers to all of the people who live on the earth. Alternate translation: “All the people on earth will worship you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: they will sing to your name
Note: Here “your name” refers to God himself. Alternate translation: “they will praise and honor you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
These words refer to God.

Quote: he is fearsome in his deeds toward the sons of mankind
Note: Alternate translation: “he causes people to feel fear and wonder when they see his deeds”
Alternate translation: “humanity”
These words refer to God.

Quote: He turned the sea into dry land; they went through the river on foot
Note: This refers to the crossing of the Red Sea. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
The word “they” refers to God’s people, the Israelites.
The word “we” refers to the Israelites, their ancestors, David, and the people he is speaking to. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])
These words refer to God.
These phrase “his eyes” refers to God himself. Alternate translation: “he sees” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: let not the rebellious exalt themselves
Note: Alternate translation: “let not the rebellious people exalt themselves” or “let not the rebellious people be proud”

Quote: Give blessing to God & let the sound of his praise be heard
Note: These two clauses have similar meanings. The idea is repeated to emphasize the importance of praising God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
These words refer to David and the people he is speaking to. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])

Quote: he does not permit our feet to slip
Note: The writer speaks of God’s protection as preventing his people from slipping as they walk or falling off a cliff. Alternate translation: “he has not allowed us to fall into disaster” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: You brought us into a net
Note: The writer speaks of God’s punishment as if God had captured his people in a net. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
a trap for a bird or an animal

Quote: you laid a heavy burden on our backs
Note: The writer speaks of what the people have endured as having to carry heavy loads on their backs. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: You made people ride over our heads
Note: This is a picture of being horribly defeated in battle. Alternate translation: “It is as if our enemies defeated us in battle and then drove their chariots over our fallen bodies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

God tested them with natural disasters like fires and floods. Alternate translation: “we suffered like people who suffer from fires and floods” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

The writer speaks of the blessings that the people of Israel now have as if they had been brought into a wide open space where they are safe. Alternate translation: “open place where we are safe” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: which my lips promised and my mouth spoke
Note: Here “lips” and “mouth” refer to the words of promise that were spoken. Alternate translation: “which I promised” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
Alternate translation: “smell of the smoke of sacrificed rams”

Quote: I will declare what he has done for my soul
Note: The word “soul” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “I will tell you what he has done for me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: I cried to him with my mouth
Note: The word “mouth” represents the whole person who cries out to God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: he was praised with my tongue
Note: Here “tongue” represents words or speech. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I praised him with my tongue” or “I praised him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Alternate translation: “loved sin” or “held iniquity”

Quote: would not have listened to me
Note: Here “would not have listened” implies that God would not have answered his prayer. This can be made clear in the translation. Alternate translation: “would not have heard me call out to him” or “he would not have answered my prayer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: But God has truly heard; he has paid attention
Note: These two clauses have similar meanings and are used together to emphasize that God has heard his prayer. Alternate translation: “But God has truly heard my prayer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Here the author’s prayer is given the personal quality of having a voice. Alternate translation: “my prayer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: who has not turned away my prayer
Note: Here “turned away’ represents ignoring his prayer. Alternate translation: “who has not ignored my prayer”

Quote: or his covenant faithfulness from me
Note: The phrase “has not turned away” is understood from the previous phrase and can be repeated here. The idea of “his covenant faithfulness” can be translated with the phrase “being faithful to his covenant.” Alternate translation: “and has not turned away his covenant faithfulness from me” or “and has not stopped being faithful to his covenant with me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

# Psalm 067 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 67 is a worship psalm.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Praise
People all over the world should be praising God.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “This is for the director of music to use in worship”
Alternate translation: “people should play stringed instruments with this song”

Quote: cause his face to shine on us
Note: The writer speaks of Yahweh acting favorably towards them as if Yahweh’s face shone a light on them. Alternate translation: “act favorably towards us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: your ways may be known on earth
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “people may know your ways on earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

The writer desires for everyone to know that God has the power to save them. This can be made clear in the translation. Alternate translation: “and the people of all nations may know that you have the power to save them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: let the nations & govern the nations
Note: Here “nations” represents the people who live in all the nations on the earth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Alternate translation: “fairly” or “justly”

Quote: Let the peoples praise you & let all the peoples praise you
Note: The second clause intensifies the meaning of the first to emphasize how important it is to praise God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: The earth has yielded its harvest
Note: Here the writer speaks of “the earth” as if it has chosen to provide a harvest to the people. Alternate translation: “We have reaped a bountiful harvest from our crops” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: all the ends of the earth honor him
Note: This means that people everywhere should honor God because of his blessings. Alternate translation: “I desire that all people everywhere on the earth may have an awesome respect for him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

# Psalm 068 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 68 is a worship psalm.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s greatness
God is exceedingly great. He takes care of the weak and helpless. He is glorious in his temple. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/glory]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/temple]])

### No Common Theme
Scholars have found this psalm the most difficult to interpret. There does not appear to be any unity to this psalm.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “This is for the director of music to use in worship”
This could mean: (1) David wrote the psalm or (2) the psalm is about David or (3) the psalm is in the style of David’s psalms.
God beginning to act is spoke of as if he stands up. Alternate translation: “Let God begin to act” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “let God chase away his enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: As smoke is driven away, so drive them away
Note: God’s enemies are spoken of as if they are smoke that is easily blown away by the wind. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Drive them away as the wind blows away smoke” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: as wax melts before the fire
Note: God’s enemies are spoken of as if they are wax that is easily melted by a fire. Alternate translation: “cause them to disappear as wax melts before a fire” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This refers to the wicked people in general. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
This refers to the righteous people in general. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
These means the same thing and emphasizes the amount of joy they feel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
This refers to God. Alternate translation: “to him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: the one who rides through the plains
Note: God’s presence among people is spoken of as if he rides on the earth in a horse or chariot. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

God is spoken of as a compassionate God who acts like a father to orphans. Alternate translation: “One who acts like a father to children who have no parents” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
God is spoken of as a merciful God who protects widows. Alternate translation: “a protector of widows” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: God puts the lonely into families
Note: God is spoken of as if he places lonely people into families. “God provides families for those who have no one to live with” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: he brings out the prisoners with singing
Note: God is spoken of as the one who leads prisoners out of their confinement. Alternate translation: “God frees prisoners and makes them sing with happiness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

This nominal adjective refers to rebellious people and can be translated with either an adjective or a noun. Alternate translation: “rebellious people” or “people who rebel against him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
God’s punishment of the rebellious is spoken of as if he forces them to live in a hot desert land. Alternate translation: “a very hot and dry land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
# General Information:\n\nDavid begins to tell the story of God leading the Israelites through the desert to Mt. Sinai.

Quote: when you went out & when you marched through
Note: These two phrases refer to the same event. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: you went out before your people
Note: Alternate translation: “you led your people”

Quote: when you marched through the wilderness
Note: God is spoken of as if he was a soldier marching ahead of the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the heavens also dropped rain & God’s presence
Note: Alternate translation: “God caused it to rain”
This idiom here refers to God’s appearance before the Israelites. Alternate translation: “when God appeared to the Israelites” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: you strengthened your inheritance when it was weary
Note: The land of Israel is spoken of as if it was a person who could be weary, or could gain strength. Alternate translation: “you caused the land to produce good crops” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

The land that God gave to the Israelites is spoken of as if it was an inheritance that a father passed on to his children. Alternate translation: “the land that you gave to us Israelites” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This refers to poor people in general. Alternate translation: “poor people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

The large number of people told the Lord’s message to others. They are spoken of as if there were a large army. Since this phrase is feminine, some versions translate it as, “the women who announced them … army.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Kings of armies flee, they flee
Note: The kings represent themselves and their entire armies. It is understood that they flee because they are defeated by Israel’s army. Alternate translation: “Kings and their armies flee from us because they are defeated” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
things that are taken from the defeated army and brought to the victorious army’s home.
This means that some of the plunder is very valuable because it is covered with precious metals.

Quote: When some of you people stayed among the sheepfolds, why did you do this?
Note: This question is used to rebuke the people who did not participate in the battle. Alternate translation: “Those who stayed among the sheepfolds should not have stayed; they should have gone to the battle.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: scattered kings there & snowed on Mount Zalmon
Note: There were so many dead kings and soldiers on the mountain that they are spoken of as if they were snow covering the mountain. Alternate translation: “defeated so many enemy kings and soldiers there that they were like snowflakes covering Mount Zalmon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
Here “kings” refers to their armies as well. Alternate translation: “scattered the enemy kings and their armies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
This is the name of a mountain. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: A mighty mountain is the & a high mountain is the
Note: These two phrase have similar meanings and are used together to strengthen each other. Alternate translation: “a mighty and high mountain is the hill country of Bashan” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Why do you look in envy & for the place he will live?
Note: If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “The high hill country of Bashan should not look in envy at the mountain which God desires for the place he will live.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
This is probably not meant to be an exact number, but to indicate a large number. Alternate translation: “many thousands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
To “ascend” is to move up, to go toward the sky.
“carries our heavy loads every day.” The Lord’s care for his people is spoken of as if he was physically carrying their troubles as a burden. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the God who is our salvation
Note: The words “is our salvation” can be translated with the verb “save.” Alternate translation: “the God who saves us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: will strike through the heads of his enemies
Note: God is spoken of as a warrior who will kill his enemies by striking them in their heads in order to kill them. Alternate translation: “will kill his enemies by striking them in the head” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
It seems to have been the custom for soldiers not to cut their hair during the time of war. Alternate translation: “the long-haired skulls” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Offending God is spoken of as walking among the offenses. Alternate translation: “habitually offend him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The word “them” refers to God’s enemies.
This speaks of the most remote parts of the earth where people might try to escape from God as if they were the depths of the sea. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

The total destruction of Israel’s enemies is spoken of as if the Israelites had crushed them under their feet. Alternate translation: “totally defeat your enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

The violence of from the destruction of the enemies is spoke of in very graphic form, as if the Israelites would be standing in the blood of their dead enemies. Alternate translation: “stepping in their blood” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the tongues of your dogs may have their share
Note: The bloodshed from the battle against Israel’s enemies is spoken of as if it is so extensive that the dogs will lap up the flowing blood with their tongues. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
A procession is a group of people walking together in an orderly manner as part of a ceremony.
people who play musical instruments

Quote: Bless God in the assemblies; praise Yahweh, you who are from the fountain of Israel
Note: It may be helpful to change the order of these phrases. Alternate translation: “You who are from the fountain of Israel, praise Yahweh and bless God in the assembly”

The word “fountain” is a metaphor for the ability of the man Israel to be the ancestor of many people: as much water comes from a fountain, so Israel is the ancestor of many people. This also implies that the call is to those who serve God as the man Israel did. Alternate translation: “true descendants of Israel” or “all of you descendants from Israel”(See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
“their group.” The word “their” refers to the leaders of Judah.

Quote: Your God, Israel, has decreed your strength
Note: Some versions understand the Hebrew text differently: “Summon your strength, God” or “Use your strength, God”
Alternate translation: “People of Israel, your God has decreed”
The word “us” refers to the writer and the people of Israel, but not to Yahweh, to whom he is speaking. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])
The word “us” refers to the writer and the people of Israel, but not to Yahweh, to whom he is speaking. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])

Quote: Reveal your power to us from your temple at Jerusalem
Note: Alternate translation: “When you are present in the temple at Jerusalem, show us your power”

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **power**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “strong.” Alternate translation: “Show us that you are strong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: the wild beasts in the reeds
Note: Many scholars believe these wild beasts are a metaphor that refers to the people of Egypt. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “the people of Egypt who are like wild beasts in the reeds” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: the peoples, that multitude of bulls and calves
Note: The peoples of other nations are spoken of as if they were a large group of cattle. Alternate translation: “the powerful nations, who are like herds of bulls” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
to disperse or to cause something to spread quickly in different direction

Quote: Princes will come out of Egypt
Note: It is implied that these princes come from Egypt in order to offer gifts to God in Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “Then the leaders of Egypt will bring gifts to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
This refers to the people of Cush. Alternate translation: “The Cushites” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: reach out with her hands to God
Note: This is a symbolic action that represents worship to God. Alternate translation: “lift up her hands to praise God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
Here “kingdoms” refers to the citizens of the kingdoms. Alternate translation: “you people who are citizens of kingdoms all over the world” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: To him who rides on the heaven of heavens
Note: The word “Sing” is implied as the beginning of this verse. Here God is described as if he rides in a chariot in the sky. Alternate translation: “Sing to God who rides across the sky in his chariot” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: he lifts up his voice with power
Note: This idiom means he speaks powerfully. Alternate translation: “he shouts powerfully” or “he speaks loudly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Here, **Ascribe** means to give credit to someone. Alternate translation: “Strength belongs to God”

Quote: his strength is in the skies
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **strength**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “powerful.” Alternate translation: “in the skies he also shows that he is powerful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: God, you are fearsome in your holy place
Note: Here the author speaks directly to God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
These two words mean basically these same thing. They emphasize how much strength God provides to his people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

# Psalm 069 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 69 is a psalm of deliverance. The author prays to be saved from his enemies and for them to be punished. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/deliverer]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/save]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Deliverance
The author prays for God to rescue him from his enemies. They show him no mercy, and he asks God to show them no mercy. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/mercy]])
# General Information:\n\nThis psalm is a prayer for help. Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “This is for the director of music to use in worship”
This may refer to a style of music. See how you translated this in [Psalms 45:1](../045/001.md).

Quote: for the waters have put my life in danger
Note: The writer describes the troubles in his life as if he were drowning in a flood of water. Alternate translation: “for it feels like I am drowning in the waters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

The writer describes the troubles in his life as if he were sinking in deep mud. Alternate translation: “For it feels like I am sinking in deep mud and will die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
thick mud

Quote: there is no place to stand
Note: The writer uses a negative statement to stress how unstable and uncertain his condition is. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])

Quote: I have come into deep waters, where the floods flow over me
Note: The writer describes his problems as if he was drowning in a deep, raging river. Alternate translation: “t feels like I am in deep waters, and the floodwaters flow over me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
very tired
This idiom means the writer has cried so much that his eyes do not see well any longer. Alternate translation: “my eyes are swollen from tears” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: more than the hairs on my head
Note: This is an exaggeration to express how many enemies the writer has. Alternate translation: “more than I can count, like the hairs on my head” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
This idiom means “kill me.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **foolishness**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “foolish.” Alternate translation: “the foolish things that I have done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: my sins are not hidden from you
Note: This can be expressed as a positive statement. Alternate translation: “you know all my sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])

Quote: Let not those & let not those
Note: Alternate translation: “Do not let those … do not let those”

Quote: Let not those who hope in you be put to shame because of me
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Please do not allow anyone to put those who wait for you to shame because of me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: let not those who seek you be brought to dishonor because of me
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Please do not allow anyone to bring dishonor on those who seek you because of me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Here, seeking **God** could mean: (1) asking God for help or (2) thinking about God and obeying him. Alternate translation: (1) “those who ask you for help” or (2) “those who worship and obey you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “On your behalf” or “For you”

The rebukes of the writer’s enemies are spoken of as if they are a heavy load that he has had to carry. Alternate translation: “I have endured the insults of my enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

The writer speaks of the shame that he feels as if it is a foul thing on his face that everyone can clearly see. Alternate translation: “I am thoroughly humiliated” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I have become a stranger to my brothers
Note: The writer speaks of himself as if he were not part of his own family. Alternate translation: “My brothers no longer know or accept me at all” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: a stranger to my brothers & an alien to my mother’s children
Note: These two phrases mean the same thing. They are repeated to stress his separation from his own family. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: an alien to my mother’s children
Note: It is implied that “I have become” should be understood here. The writer speaks of himself as if he were not part of his own family. Alternate translation: “my brothers no longer know or trust me at all” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the zeal of your house has eaten me up
Note: The writer speaks of his zeal for God’s temple as if it was a wild animal that devours the writer. Alternate translation: “the zeal I have for your house consumes me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

This idiom means that the writer’s zeal for the temple takes over all of his thoughts and actions. Alternate translation: “completely controls all that I think and do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: the rebukes & have fallen on me
Note: The writer speaks of the rebukes of Gods’ enemies as if they were rocks that were thrown at the writer. Alternate translation: “those who rebuke you have also thrown their rebukes at me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I wept and did not eat food
Note: The fact that the writer was fasting indicates that he was sad about the way people treated God’s temple. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Alternate translation: “my enemies rebuked me because of it”
Wearing rough, cheap clothing was a symbol of mourning over sin. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

Quote: I became the object of a proverb
Note: The writer speak of himself as if he was the sad or foolish person in a proverb. Alternate translation: “I became the example of a sad person spoken of in their proverbs” or “they laugh at me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Those who sit in the city gate
Note: Here “city gate” is associated with leadership of a town. Alternate translation: “The important people of the city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: I am a song of drunkards
Note: The writer speaks of himself as if he was the person about whom the drunkards sing mocking songs. Alternate translation: “the drunkards of the city sing disgusting songs about me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: at a time that you will accept
Note: Alternate translation: “in your accepted time” or “when you are willing”

Quote: answer me in the trustworthiness of your salvation
Note: The abstract nouns “trustworthiness” and “salvation” can be stated as “faithfully” and “rescue.” Alternate translation: “rescue me because you faithfully love me, as you have promised to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: Pull me out & do not let me sink
Note: These two phrases mean the same thing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Pull me out of the mire, and do not let me sink
Note: The writer speaks of his danger from his enemies as if he was sinking into a pit of mud. “Do not allow me to sink anymore in the mud” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Here “take away” refers to being removed from danger. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “take me away” or “rescue me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

It is understood that “let me be” is implied here. It can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “please rescue me out” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: rescued out of the deep waters
Note: The writer speaks about his danger from his enemies as if he was drowning in deep water. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the floods of water overwhelm me
Note: The writer speaks about his danger from his enemies as if flood waters were covering him completely. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

The writer speaks of the deep as if it was a deadly animal that was about to eat him. Alternate translation: “the deep waters swallow me up like a dangerous animal” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Do not let the pit shut its mouth on me
Note: Here the “pit” is spoken of as if it has a mouth like a person and could eat the writer. Alternate translation: “Do not let the pit consume me” or “Do not let the pit of death close over me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “you are good and faithful to your covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: your mercies for me are many
Note: Alternate translation: “you are very merciful to me”
The idea of turning towards someone means to pay attention to them or help them. Alternate translation: “help me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Do not hide your face from your servant
Note: To hide one’s face means to refuse to hear or help someone. Alternate translation: “Please help your servant” or “Please help me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Alternate translation: “in great trouble”
The writer asks God to redeem him as if the writer were a slave whose freedom God could purchase. Alternate translation: “free me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The writer asks God to ransom him as if the writer were a captive whose release could be paid for with money. Alternate translation: “rescue me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: my rebuke, my shame, and my dishonor
Note: These abstract nouns can be stated as actions. Alternate translation: “how people have rebuked me, shamed me, and dishonored me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: my adversaries are all before you
Note: Here “before you” means that God sees and knows all about them. Alternate translation: “you know who all my enemies are” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This idiom means a person is extremely sad. Alternate translation: “offended me deeply” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
The writer’s great sadness is spoken of as if he was full of a heavy weight. Alternate translation: “I am heavy with sorrow” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
to feel sorrow or sadness

Quote: They gave me poison for my food
Note: This is probably figurative. The food that people gave to the writer was so bad that it tasted like poison. Alternate translation: “They gave me food that tasted like poison” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Let their table before them become a snare & let it become a trap
Note: The writer would like for his enemies’ food to completely ruin them as if they were small animals caught in a snare or a trap. Alternate translation: “May their food ruin them like a snare … may it destroy them like a trap” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This refers to food that was served on the tables, possibly at a feast. Alternate translation: “their own food” or “sacrificial feasts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

The writer speaks of eyes that cannot see well as if they were darkened. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Weak backs are spoken of as if they are shaking in weakness. Alternate translation: “cause their backs to be too weak for them to do anything” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “their sides” or “their backs”

Note: God’s demonstration of his anger is described as if he poured it out on his enemies like water. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
anger of a person who has suffered injustice
Alternate translation: “your burning anger” or “your strong anger”
God’s judgment on his enemies is described as if he ran after them and caught them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This abstract noun can be stated as “abandoned.” Alternate translation: “become abandoned” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
Alternate translation: “they persecuted the man”

Here to be “wounded” refers to causing them to suffer. Alternate translation: “those you have caused to suffer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Note: Alternate translation: “Keep making a record of all their sins”
Alternate translation: “very many sins”

Note: Here “them” refers to the names of the enemies. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Wipe out their names in” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **salvation**, you could express the same idea with the verb “save.” Here “on high” refers to a place of safety.” Alternate translation: “God, save me and put me in a safe place” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

This abstract noun can be stated with the verb “thank.” Alternate translation: “by thanking him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Note: This phrase distinguishes the full grown bulls from other younger cows. Alternate translation: “a bull that is full grown with horns and hooves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-distinguish]])
This refers to meek people in general. Alternate translation: “Meek people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

Here “hearts” refer to the people. Here “live” is an idiom that means to be encouraged. Alternate translation: “may you be encouraged” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])

This refers to needy people in general. Alternate translation: “needy people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

# Psalm 071 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 71 is a psalm of deliverance. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/deliverer]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s help
God has helped the psalmist all his life. Now that he is old, his enemy thinks that God has abandoned him; but the psalmist trusts in God and will praise Yahweh with songs of praise. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/trust]])
# General Information:\n\nThis psalm is a prayer for help. Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: In you, Yahweh, I take refuge
Note: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. Alternate translation: “go to you, Yahweh, for protection” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: let me never be put to shame
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. See how “do not let me be humiliated” is translated in [Psalms 25:2](../025/002.md). Alternate translation: “never let my enemies put me to shame” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Note: This could mean: (1) “make me safe because you always do what is right” or (2) “make me safe as I do what you want me to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Here “your ear” refers to God’s willingness to hear someone who prays to him. See how this is translated in [Psalms 17:6](../017/006.md). Alternate translation: “pay attention to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Note: This could mean: (1) the word “hand” is a metonym for power. Alternate translation: “from the power of the wicked, from the power of the unrighteous” or (2) “hand” refers to the person himself. Note: “wicked; rescue me out of the hand of the unrighteous.” You can make clear the understood information. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Note: Alternate translation: “I do not completely understand your righteousness and your salvation, but my mouth will tell about them all the day”

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **salvation**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “how you have saved me” or “how you save people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
This could mean: (1) “I will go to where people worship Yahweh” or (2) “I will go to my enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-go]])

Note: This could mean: (1) “I will tell them of the mighty deeds the Lord Yahweh has done” or (2) “because the Lord Yahweh has given me strength to do mighty acts.”

Note: The psalmist speaks of the good things God has done as though they were put together as a high building or a mountain. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# Psalm 072 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 72 is a psalm for the king when he begins to be the king. David wrote it as a blessing on his son, Solomon. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/bless]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Blessings for the king
May the king be honored throughout the world. May he help the poor. May there be prosperity while he is king.

### Close of Book Two
The whole collection of Psalms has been divided into several “books.” This is the last psalm of the second book. It is attributed to Solomon, the son of David.

# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. Possible meanings for the header **a psalm of Solomon** are: (1) David wrote this psalm about Solomon (“the king’s son”) or (2) Solomon (who, as David’s son, was “the king’s son”) wrote this psalm as a prayer about himself or (3) another king wrote it about his son in the style of Solomon. People in those days would often speak of themselves as if they were someone else. However, it would be best to translate this as though the psalmist is speaking of someone else, not of himself. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

Quote: Give the king your righteous decrees, God, your righteousness to the king’s son
Note: This could mean: (1) “Give me, the king, your righteous decrees, God, your righteousness to my son” or (2) “Give me, the king, your righteous decrees, God, your righteousness to me, the king’s son.” People in those days would often speak of themselves as if they were someone else. However, it would be best to translate this as though the psalmist is speaking of someone else, not of himself. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

Quote: Give the king your righteous decrees
Note: Alternate translation: “Enable the king to judge rightly”

Quote: your righteousness to the king’s son
Note: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. Here the word “righteousness” refers to making righteous decisions. Alternate translation: “give your righteousness to the king’s son” or “enable the king’s son to rule with righteousness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

If David wrote this, he is talking about his son, “the king’s son,” he is speaking of the time when his son will be king. If Solomon wrote it, even though he is writing about himself, it would be best to translate as though he were writing about someone else. Either way, “May the king judge” is the best translation.
The psalmist is speaking to God.

The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. The adjective “poor” refers to poor people. Alternate translation: “may he judge your poor people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

Quote: May the mountains produce peace & may the hills produce righteousness
Note: The psalmist speaks of the people of Israel as if they were the mountains and hills on which they live. He speaks of the mountains and the hills as if they were the entire land of Israel, as if that land were a garden that produces fruit, and of peace and righteousness as if they are that fruit. Alternate translation: “May the people of the land live in peace … may they do everything in a righteous way” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
These refer to the one who will “judge” ([Psalms 72:2](../072/002.md)).

The writer speaks of the king defeating or punishing people who oppress others as if those people were objects that the king would break into pieces. Alternate translation: “punish the person who oppresses others” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: while the sun endures, and as long as the moon lasts
Note: The sun and the moon are metonyms for the day and the night, which together are a merism for all time. Alternate translation: “forever, and without ending” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

Quote: May he come down like rain on the mown grass
Note: The king will be good, and he will do good things for his people as if he were rain doing good for freshly cut grass. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
Alternate translation: “I desire that he come”

“May he come down like showers that water.” The king will be good, and he will do good things for his people as if he were rain doing good for the ground. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
The adjective “righteous” can be translated as a noun phrase. Alternate translation: “righteous people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
This could mean: (1) “while the king rules” or (2) “as long as the righteous person lives” or “as long as the righteous people live.”

Quote: may there be an abundance of peace
Note: The psalmist speaks as if peace were a physical object like food. An “abundance” is when there is much of something. This can be restated to remove the abstract nouns “abundance” and “peace.” Alternate translation: “may righteous people live peacefully” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: till the moon is no more
Note: “as long as the moon shines” or “forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Alternate translation: “May the king have dominion”

Quote: from sea to sea, and from the River to the ends of the earth
Note: Both of these expressions are merisms and refer to the whole earth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
from the Dead Sea and the Sea of Kinnereth in the east to the Mediterranean Sea in the west.
“the Euphrates River,” which the Israelites would travel to on land by going north

as far as people could travel on land by different routes to the south. The Israelites spoke of the earth as if it were a flat surface with ends. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This is a metaphor for extreme humiliation. Alternate translation: “do everything they can so he will allow them to live” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This is the name of a place. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

# Psalm 073 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 73 is a wisdom psalm. It explains the problem of wicked people who seem to prosper. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/wise]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/evil]])

## Special concepts in this chapter
### Evil people
Sometimes it seems that wicked people have no problems and everything works for them. Despite this, they will be destroyed. In contrast, the righteous always have God to help them through problems. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/righteous]])

### Psalms by Asaph
There are twelve psalms attributed to Asaph; the first one is Psalm 50, which is in Book Two, and the other eleven (Psalm 73–83) are at the beginning of Book Three.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: my feet almost slipped; my feet almost slipped out from under me
Note: The psalmist speaks of being unable to trust God and wanting to sin as if he had almost fallen while walking on a slippery path. Alternate translation: “I almost stopped trusting in God; I was almost guilty of committing a great sin against him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I was envious of the arrogant
Note: Alternate translation: “I envied the arrogant” or “I did not want arrogant people to have the good things that they had”
The adjective “arrogant” can be translated as a noun phrase. Alternate translation: “arrogant people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
The word “prosperity” can be translated as a verb. Alternate translation: “how the wicked have so many good things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
The adjective “wicked” can be translated as a noun phrase. Alternate translation: “wicked people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
# General Information:\n\nAsaph begins to describe how he sometimes wants to complain to God about those who are “arrogant” and “wicked” ([Psalms 73:3](../073/003.md)).
The words “burdens” is a metonym for the struggles of daily life (need for food, shelter, clothing, and health). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Note: Alternate translation: “they do not suffer the way other people do”

Note: This means the wicked show everyone how proud and violent they are as if they were wearing a necklace or beautiful robe. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
This refers to things that rich and important people wear.

Note: Because they are like blind people who cannot see where they are going, they sin without knowing it. Being blind is a metaphor for a person being unable to see how wicked he is. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Note: Here the psalmist describes people’s thoughts as if they were people. He also describes the inner beings of wicked people as if they were a building in which those people could walk. Note: Here “their mouth” is a metonym for their speech, and “heavens” is a metonym for God, who lives in the heavens. Alternate translation: “They speak against God, who is in the heavens” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Note: The word “tongues” represents the people themselves. This could mean: (1) “they go through the earth saying bad things about God” or (2) “they go everywhere and boast about themselves.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

# Psalm 074 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 74 is a psalm of deliverance. The people have been completely conquered and they pray for God to deliver them. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/deliverer]])

## Special concepts in this chapter
### God’s power
The enemies have destroyed God’s temple and are insulting the people. God is powerful. He made everything and he chose Israel for his people. He should avenge himself on these enemies that have burnt his temple. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/temple]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/peopleofgod]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/avenge]])

### Superscription
This is called a “Maschil.” The word in the original language has caused scholars to have various opinions about its meaning. Some say it means to instruct, while others say that the word is referring to the skill used in creating the psalm. Still others think it means that meditation should be used in reading this psalm.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
This may refer to a style of music. See how you translated this in [Psalms 32:1](../032/001.md).

Quote: God, why have you rejected us forever?
Note: If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “God, we have done nothing wrong, but you have rejected us forever!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Why does your anger burn against the sheep of your pasture?
Note: If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “We are the ones you have promised to care for, and we have done nothing wrong, but now you are angry with us!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Asaph speaks of the people of Israel as if they were sheep. Alternate translation: “against Israel, who are like the sheep whom you feed in your pasture” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
“Pay attention to.” God has not forgotten his people, but he does not seem to be thinking about them.
Alternate translation: “yours forever”
# General Information:\n\nThese verses describe an actual event, a physical attack on the temple of Israel in Jerusalem.
Asaph is addressing God, asking him to come look at the destruction.

This refers to carvings on wood, metal, or stone in the temple.

This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “They said to themselves” or “They thought to themselves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Note: This could mean: (1) “We do not see any more miraculous signs from God” or (2) “All our sacred symbols are gone” or (3) the “signs” are the flags and symbols of an army representing the army itself. Alternate translation: “They have completely destroyed our army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Note: If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “God, the enemy has been throwing insults at you for too long!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Note: If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “It seems as if you will never stop the enemy from blaspheming your name!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
The word “name” is a metonym for God himself. Alternate translation: “say that you are bad” or “insult you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Why do you hold back your hand, your right hand?
Note: The psalmist speaks of God as if he had a physical body. If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Note: The psalmist speaks of God as if he had a physical body. “Stop hiding your power and take action” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: God has been my king from ancient times
Note: This could mean: (1) Asaph is speaking as Israel’s representative, “God has been our king since we Israelites first became a nation” or (2) “God, my king, was alive even in ancient times.”

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **salvation**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “to save.” Here Yahweh saving people is spoken of as if salvation were an object that he brings with him. Alternate translation: “saving people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Note: Asaph is speaking of God as if God had a physical body. “You are so strong you were able to make dry land in the middle of the sea.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Note: Asaph is probably speaking of Pharaoh and his army as if they were sea monsters. If possible, translate these words literally. Alternate translation: “when you killed Pharaoh’s army, it was as if you smashed the heads of sea monsters in the waters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Note: Yahweh causing springs and streams to flow out of the ground as if he broke open the ground so that they could flow. Alternate translation: “You caused springs and streams to flow out of the ground” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Note: Asaph speaks of insulting words as if they were physical objects, like stones, which the enemy was throwing at Yahweh. Alternate translation: “the enemy insulted you many times” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Note: “Do not continue forever to do nothing to help your oppressed people.” This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “Come soon to help your oppressed people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])

Note: Asaph speaks of “regions” as if they were containers in which one could put “places of violence.” Alternate translation: “violent people do evil deeds in dark places in the land wherever they can” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Note: The word “dark” is probably a metaphor for a place where bad things happen or for the lands to which the Israelites had been sent in exile, but these words should be translated literally if possible. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# Psalm 075 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 75 is a wisdom psalm; teaching what will happen to evil people. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/wise]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/evil]])

## Special concepts in this chapter
### Punishment
God has warned the evil people that they will be punished. He will strengthen the good people. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/good]])

# General Information:\n\nThe people of God are speaking in 75:1, and God speaks in 75:2-3. Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “This is for the director of music to use in worship”
This may refer to a style of music. See how you translated this in [Psalms 57:1](../057/001.md).
“This is a psalm that Asaph wrote.” See how this is translated in [Psalms Psalm 53](../053/001.md).
Alternate translation: “all the people who live on it”
“keep the earth from being destroyed” or Alternate translation: “keep my people safe” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I said to the arrogant & and to the wicked
Note: The words “the arrogant” and “the wicked” are nominal adjectives that can be translated with nouns. The verb for the second phrase may be supplied from the first. Alternate translation: “I said to the arrogant people … and I said to the wicked people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
This could mean: (1) God is speaking or (2) Asaph is speaking.

Quote: Do not be arrogant & Do not lift
Note: The speaker is speaking to many wicked people, so these forms are plural. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pronouns]])

Note: Asaph speaks of wicked people as if they were animals with horns on their heads, stretching their necks and holding their heads high to frighten other animals. Alternate translation: “Do not be confident” or “Do not boast about how strong you are” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Do not lift up your & do not speak
Note: The speaker is speaking to many wicked people, so these forms are plural. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pronouns]])

Quote: Do not lift up your horn to the heights
Note: Asaph speaks of wicked people as if they were animals with horns on their heads, stretching their necks and holding their heads as high as they can to frighten other animals. Alternate translation: “Be especially sure not to boast that you are greater than God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Asaph speaks of wicked people who defy or challenge God as if they were animals with horns on their heads, stretching their necks and holding their heads high to frighten other animals. Alternate translation: “arrogantly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: It is not from the east & that lifting up comes
Note: Asaph speaks of the one who lifts up as if he were the action of lifting up. He also speaks of God giving strength and honor to a person as if God were physically lifting that person up. Alternate translation: “The one who will lift you up will not be someone who comes from the east” or “The one who will make you strong and have people honor you will not be someone who comes from the east” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
# General Information:\n\nAsaph speaks about God.

Quote: he brings down and he lifts up
Note: The objects of the verbs can be stated clearly: “he brings some people down and he lifts other people up.” The words “brings down” and “raises up” are metaphors for God making people powerful and taking away their power. Alternate translation: “he makes one man king in place of another man” or “he takes away one man’s power and gives power to another man” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: a cup of foaming wine & mixed with spices
Note: When Yahweh punishes the people they will be like people who have drunk strong wine and become ill. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The foam is a metaphor for the power of the wine to make people drunk, Alternate translation: “strong wine” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
dried leaves or ground seeds
pours it from a large container into the cups that the people will drink from

Quote: drink it to the last drop
Note: Alternate translation: “drink every drop of it”
God says

Quote: cut off all the horns of
Note: The horns of an animal are a metaphor for the power of a person. Alternate translation: “take away all power from” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
