Note: The horns of an animal are a metaphor for the power of a person. This can be translated as a statement in active form. Alternate translation: “I will raise up the horns of the righteous” or “I will make the righteous powerful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

# Psalm 076 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 76 is a worship psalm.

## Special concepts in this chapter
### Yahweh’s greatness
God is great. He has conquered all the nations surrounding Israel. Everyone should bring him gifts.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “This is for the director of music to use in worship”
Alternate translation: “people should play stringed instruments with this song.”
“This is a psalm that Asaph wrote” See how this is translated in [Psalms 53:1](../053/001.md).
Alternate translation: “caused the people of Judah to know who he is” or “made himself famous in Judah”

Quote: his name is great in Israel
Note: The words “his name” are a metonym for his reputation. Alternate translation: “the people of Israel consider him good and powerful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Alternate translation: “the place where he has chosen to live”

Quote: There he broke the arrows of the bow, the shield, the sword, and the other weapons of war
Note: These words are probably a metaphor for God causing the people of Judah to live in peace without being afraid of enemies making war on them, but the words should be translated literally. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
# General Information:\n\nAsaph speaks of God as if God was a soldier returning from a mountain after winning a great battle.

Quote: You shine brightly and reveal your glory
Note: The second phrase strengthens the first phrase in that Yahweh’s glory relates to Yahweh shining brightly. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
The words “shine brightly” are a metaphor for being great. Alternate translation: “You show how extremely great you are” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Your people killed the brave soldiers of their enemies and then took all their possessions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Here “fell asleep” is a euphemism for died. Alternate translation: “died” or “fell down dead” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])

Here, **rebuke** refers to saying something in an angry or critical way. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **rebuke**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “When you rebuked them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
This phrase is a polite way to say that they died. Alternate translation: “died” or “fell down dead” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])

Quote: who can stand in your sight when you are angry?
Note: If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “No one can stand in your sight when you are angry.” or “You can destroy anyone at whom you are angry.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
Alternate translation: “you pronounced judgment” or “you announced how you were going to punish wicked people”
Here “the earth” is a metonym for the people living on the earth. Alternate translation: “the people of the earth were” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Alternate translation: “carry out judgment” or “punish wicked people”
Alternate translation: “It is certain that your angry judgment”

Quote: your angry judgment against humanity will bring you praise
Note: This could mean: (1) “people will praise you because you are angry at the wicked and judge them” or (2) “people who are angry with you will do things that cause people to praise you.”

Quote: you gird yourself with what is left of your anger
Note: Yahweh’s anger is spoken of as something that he can tie around himself like a belt. Alternate translation: “you tie your remaining anger around you like a belt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: him who is to be feared
Note: Alternate translation: “Yahweh, whom they should fear”

Quote: He cuts off the spirit of the princes
Note: The phrase “He cuts off the spirit” is an idiom that means He breaks the spirit or He humbles. Alternate translation: “He humbles the princes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: he is feared by the kings of the earth
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the kings of the earth fear him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

# Psalm 077 General Notes

## Type of psalm

The author felt abandoned by God. This is a psalm of lament. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/lament]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Lament
God used to be close to the psalmist, but now it seems that God has completely abandoned him. Long ago, God took care of Israel and brought the people safely through the sea.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “This is for the director of music to use in worship”
One of David’s chief musicians had this same name. This may refer to him. See how you translated this in [Psalms 39:1](../039/001.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
Alternate translation: “I prayed with my arms extended”

Quote: My soul refused to be comforted
Note: The “soul” represents the person. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I would not allow anyone to try to comfort me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: I thought of God as I groaned; I thought about him as I grew faint
Note: These two phrases share similar meanings and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “as my spirit grew faint” or “as my spirit was overwhelmed”
# General Information:\n\nAfter speaking about God, Asaph speaks to God in verse 4 and then returns to speaking about God.
Alternate translation: “I said to God, ‘You held my eyes open.’”
Open eyes is a metonym for being unable to sleep. Alternate translation: “kept me from sleeping” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: the days of old, about times long past
Note: If necessary, “days of old” and “times long past” can be combined. Alternate translation: “about things that happened a very long time ago” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
This is an idiom for remembering. Alternate translation: “I remembered” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Another possible meaning is “what was happening.”

Quote: Will the Lord reject me forever? Will he never again show me favor?
Note: These two phrases express feeling rejection from the Lord. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
Alternate translation: “do things that show that he is pleased with me”
# General Information:\n\nBecause Asaph was not sure of the answer to these questions, they are probably literal questions and should be translated literally.

Quote: Was his covenant faithfulness gone forever?
Note: Asaph speaks of Yahweh no longer acting faithfully to his covenant as if Yahweh’s covenant faithfulness had gone away. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “Has he stopped being faithful to his covenant forever?” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: Had God forgotten to be gracious? Had his anger shut off his compassion?
Note: These are two expressions stating similar concept of God not showing compassion. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

Quote: Had his anger shut off his compassion
Note: Asaph speaks of anger as if it were a person shutting a door to keep another person, compassion, from coming out, Alternate translation: “Had God stopped showing us compassion because he was angry with us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
This could mean: (1) the psalmist was speaking to himself or (2) the psalmist was speaking to Yahweh.

Quote: the changing of the right hand of the Most High toward us
Note: The “right hand” is a metonym for power, authority or strength. Alternate translation: “the Most High no longer uses his power to help us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
# General Information:\n\nThe writer begins to speak to Yahweh.
“remember” See how this is translated in [Psalms 74:2](../074/002.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Alternate translation: “the wonderful things you did long ago”

Quote: I will ponder all your deeds and will reflect on them.
Note: These two phrases express the concept of meditating on what Yahweh has done. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
think deeply about
Alternate translation: “think of what they mean”

Quote: what god compares to our great God?
Note: If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “no god compares to our great God.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: revealed your strength among the peoples
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **strength**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “shown people from many people groups how strong you are” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: gave your people victory & the descendants
Note: Alternate translation: “gave us, your people, victory … us who are the descendants”

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **victory**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “caused your people to be victorious” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: the descendants of Jacob and Joseph
Note: This refers to the entire nation of Israel.

Quote: The waters saw you & they were afraid & the depths trembled
Note: Asaph speaks of the water as if it were a person who saw something that terrified him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: the waters saw you, and they were afraid; the depths trembled
Note: “water” and “depth” refers to large bodies of water such as the sea or ocean. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
deepest waters

Asaph speaks of the clouds as if they were people pouring water out of containers. Alternate translation: “Much rain fell” or “It rained very hard” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
This is a metaphor that describes lightning as God’s arrows. Alternate translation: “the lightning you made flashed like arrows” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Use your language’s word for what an arrow does after someone shoots it.

This is personification, referring to the thunder as the voice of God. Alternate translation: “voice, which was as loud as thunder” or “very loud voice” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

This is an exaggeration to emphasize that the lightning lit up everything the writer could see. Alternate translation: “lightning lit up everything as far as you could see” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
These two phrases have similar meanings and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
Asaph is speaking of Yahweh as if Yahweh was a person with feet. While this is personification, it should be translated literally, if possible. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “no one saw your footprints” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: You led your people like a flock
Note: This simile compares God’s people to a flock of animals. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
The phrase “by the hand of” here means “by the action of” or “through the action of.”
Here “hand” is synechdoche for the whole person. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

# Psalm 078 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 78 is a wisdom psalm using Israel’s history. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/wise]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Israel’s complaining
Although God did one miracle after the other, the people of Israel still complained and failed to believe Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/believe]])

### Superscription
This is called a “Maschil.” The word in the original language has caused scholars to have various opinions about its meaning. Some say it means to instruct, while others say that the word is referring to the skill used in creating the psalm. Still others think it means that meditation should be used in reading this psalm.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
This may refer to a style of music. See how you translated this in [Psalms 32:1](../032/001.md).
The noun “teaching” can be translated with a verb. Alternate translation: “Hear what I teach” or “Hear me as I teach you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
The word “mouth” represents the person. Alternate translation: “my words” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
The idiom “open my mouth” means to speak. Alternate translation: “speak in parables” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
“tell.” See how “pours out” is translated in [Psalms 19:2](../019/002.md).
If your language has a word for sayings that are purposely difficult to understand, you might use it here.

Note: This can be written in positive form. Alternate translation: “We will certainly tell our descendants about them”
Alternate translation: “the things we praise Yahweh for”
Alternate translation: “Yahweh established”
Other possible meanings are “testimonies” or “laws.”
# General Information:\n\nThe writer speaks of the “children” of [Psalms 78:5-6](./005.md).

Alternate translation: “The Ephraimite soldiers”
The soldiers probably also had arrows. Alternate translation: “had bows and arrows for weapons” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
This refers to the area around the city of Zoan, which was in Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
Alternate translation: “God split”

Quote: enough to fill the depths of the sea
Note: This is probably hyperbole. Alternate translation: “more water than they could possibly drink” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
small rivers

Alternate translation: “with their whole hearts”
Alternate translation: “so they could eat as much as they desired”
the Israelites spoke

Note: If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. much water came out quickly

Note: The people are laughing at God to insult him with these questions. Alternate translation: “But we will not believe that he can give us bread also or provide meat for his people until we see him do it.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
food from plants or food from animals. Though this is a merism for all kinds of food, it is best to translate it literally if possible. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

This refers to the nation of Israel

Quote: did not trust in his salvation
Note: Alternate translation: “did not trust him to save them”

Note: Asaph speaks of the sky as if it were a storeroom with doors. Alternate translation: “opened the sky as if it were a storeroom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Note: These two lines speak of the same event.

birds

to ask him what they needed to do so he would protect them (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

The words “right hand” are a metonym for power. Alternate translation: “he won for himself using his own power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

This could mean: (1) God assigned the Israelites their inheritance in the land in which the other nations had once lived or (2) God assigned to the nations he had driven out an inheritance somewhere else. “gave them land that would always be theirs”

This could mean: (1) he settled Israel in their own tents in the land or (2) he settled Israel in the tents from which he had driven the other nations. Most of these “tents” were actually houses, both when the other nations lived in them and when the Israelites lived in them. Alternate translation: “in their homes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

These words mean almost the same thing. The writer uses them both to emphasize that the Israelites did not believe that God would either provide for them or punish evil as he had said he would. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
They wanted God to prove that he could do what he said he would do before they would believe him. See how you translated this idea in [Psalms 78:18](../078/018.md).
refused to obey
These words mean almost the same thing. The writer uses them both to emphasize that the Israelites did not do for God what they had said they would do. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

Quote: made him angry with their high places and provoked him to jealous anger with their idols
Note: These two phrases are in parallel and have similar meanings. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: He allowed his strength to be captured and gave his glory into the enemy’s hand
Note: Asaph speaks of God’s strength and glory as if they were physical objects that people could capture and hold. The words “strength” and “glory” are probably mentonyms for the ark of the covenant. The word “hand” is a metonym for the enemy’s power. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “He allowed his enemies to capture the glorious ark of his covenant; he simply gave it to them so they could do whatever they wanted with it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: He handed his people over to the sword
Note: Asaph speaks of God’s people as if they were a small object God would give as a gift, and of the sword, a metonym for death in war, as if it were a person who could receive a gift. Alternate translation: “He allowed people to kill all his people in war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: he was angry with his heritage
Note: Alternate translation: “he was angry with the people he had said would be his forever”

This could mean: (1) “The enemy used fire to kill all their young men” or (2) “Their young men died quickly in battle like a fire burns dry grass.” Do not communicate that these people used guns. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
To “devour” is to eat everything very quickly.
the celebration when people marry

Quote: Their priests fell by the sword
Note: Here the word “sword” represents soldiers who fought with swords. The phrase “fell by the sword” is an idiom that means to die in battle. Alternate translation: “Their priests died in battle” or “Enemies killed their priests with swords” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This could mean: (1) someone forced the widows not to weep or (2) so many priests died that there was no time for proper funerals.
women whose husbands have died

Quote: the Lord awakened as one from sleep
Note: The Lord not acting for a period of time is spoken of as if he were asleep, and his beginning to act is spoken of as if he awakened. Alternate translation: “the Lord began to act as if he had awakened from sleep” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: like a warrior who shouts because of wine
Note: This could mean: (1) like a warrior who had drunk too much wine and has become angry because he was awakened and so wants to fight or (2) like a warrior who drank much wine but is now able to think and fight well because he has slept.

Here the word “tent” is a metonym for a family. In this phrase it refers to the descendants of Joseph. Alternate translation: “the descendants of Joseph” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Ephraim was Joseph’s son.
Mount Zion was in the land where the tribe of Judah lived.

Quote: He built his sanctuary like the heavens
Note: This simile could mean: (1) Yahweh has made his sanctuary as high as the heavens. Alternate translation: “He built his sanctuary high, like the heavens” or (2) Yahweh has made his sanctuary as permanent as the heavens. Alternate translation: “He built his sanctuary to last permanently, like the heavens last forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

The verb may be supplied from the previous line. The writer compares the permanence of Yahweh’s sanctuary to the permanence of the earth. Alternate translation: “He built his sanctuary to last permanently, like the earth lasts permanently” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
“from where he was working in the sheepfolds” [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]]
spaces with walls around them where sheep are kept safe

Quote: to be shepherd of Jacob, his people, and of Israel, his heritage
Note: The word “shepherd” is a metaphor for one who leads and protects other people. Alternate translation: “to lead and protect the descendants of Jacob, his people, and of Israel, his heritage” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
“the ones he had chosen to be his forever” See how this is translated in [Psalms 78:62](../078/062.md).
The word “shepherded” is a metaphor for leading and protecting. Alternate translation: “David led them and protected them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# Psalm 079 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 79 is a deliverance psalm and a prayer for revenge against their enemies. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/deliverer]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/avenge]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Destruction
Jerusalem has been destroyed and its people killed. God should destroy these enemy nations who do not pray to him.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
“the land that was to be yours forever” See how this is translated in [Psalms 68:9](../068/009.md).

Quote: They have shed their blood like water
Note: The word “blood” is a metonym for innocent life. To shed blood is to kill innocent people. Most people saw water every day, so for blood to be as common as water, many innocent people would have to die. Alternate translation: “They have killed so many innocent people that the blood is everywhere, like water after it rains” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: We have become a reproach for our neighbors, mocking and derision to those who are around us
Note: The words “reproach,” “mocking,” and “derision” are metonyms for those whom others reproach, mock, and deride. Alternate translation: “We have become people whom our neighbors reproach; those around us mock and deride us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
The pronoun “We” refers to God’s people.
strong laughter to shame a person

Quote: How long will your jealous anger burn like fire?
Note: If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “It seems as though your jealous anger will never stop burning like fire.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **anger**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “angry.” Alternate translation: “will you be jealous and angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

This simile compares the expression of God’s anger to a fire that destroys things. Alternate translation: “destroy us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
# General Information:\n\nThese two pairs of phrases each share similar meanings and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Pour out your wrath on the nations
Note: Asaph speaks of God’s wrath as if it were a liquid. Alternate translation: “Since you are angry, punish the nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: do not call upon your name
Note: The word “name” is a metonym for the person’s power and authority. Alternate translation: “do not belong to you” or “do not ask you to help them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
The word “Jacob” is a mentonym for his descendants, the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “they have completely destroyed the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Do not hold the sins of our forefathers against us
Note: Alternate translation: “Do not continue to remember the sins of our forefathers and punish us for them” or “Forgive us for the sins of our forefathers”

The writer speaks of the people being weak and discouraged as if they were in a low position. Alternate translation: “we are very weak” or “we are very discouraged” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The word “salvation” can be translated with the verb “save”: “God who saves us.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: for the sake of the glory of your name
Note: The word “name” is a metonym for his reputation, for what people know about him. Alternate translation: “so that people will know about your glory” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

God’s name here represents his whole being and the honor that he deserves. Alternate translation: “so that people will honor you” or “for your own sake” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Why should the nations say, “Where is their God?”
Note: If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “The nations should not be able to say, ‘Where is their God?’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
This taunt can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: “Their God cannot do anything!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: May the blood of your servants that was shed be avenged on the nations before our eyes
Note: To shed blood is a metonym for killing innocent people. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “Avenge your innocent servants whom the nations killed where we can see you do it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
Alternate translation: “in our sight” or “while we are present”

Quote: May the groans of the prisoners come before you
Note: Asaph speaks of the sound made by prisoners in pain and sorrow as if it were a person who appears before a king. Alternate translation: “Listen carefully to the groans of the prisoners and help them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
This is an idiom that refers to people who are condemned to death. Alternate translation: “those who are condemned to die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Asaph speaks of the evil deeds that the neighboring countries did against Israel as “insults,” and as if they were physical items. He asks the Lord to count those deeds, and for every one that the neighboring countries committed, he asks the Lord to have someone do seven evil deeds to the neighboring countries. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “Return” or “Give back”
onto their knees and thighs as they are sitting. This is a metaphor for “directly and personally.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: we your people and sheep of your pasture will give you thanks
Note: The word “sheep” is a metaphor for helpless people whom a shepherd protects and leads. Alternate translation: “we who are your people, whom you protect and lead, will thank you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: tell your praises to all generations
Note: Alternate translation: “make sure that all generations to come know all the good things you have done”

This represents the things that people will praise them the Lord for. Alternate translation: “continue to praise you for the things that you have done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

# Psalm 080 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 80 is a deliverance psalm. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/deliverer]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s help
Israel’s enemies threaten them. The psalmist asks Yahweh to look down with joy on them, then they will be saved. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/save]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Metaphor

The author uses an extended metaphor of Israel as a vine planted by God which is being uprooted. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
“This is for the director of music to use in worship” See how this is translated in [Psalms 4:1](../004/001.md).
This may refer to a style of music. See how you translated this in [Psalms 45:1](../045/001.md).
Asaph is referring to God as the one who leads and protects Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: you who lead Joseph like a flock
Note: The word “Joseph” refers to the nation of Israel. Asaph speaks of the people as if they were a flock of sheep that Yahweh, who is the shepherd, leads. Alternate translation: “you who lead the descendants of Joseph as though they were a flock of sheep” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here Joseph represents the nation of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: you who sit above the cherubim
Note: You may need to make explicit that the cherubim are those on the lid of the ark of the covenant. The biblical writers often spoke of the ark of the covenant as if it were Yahweh’s footstool upon which he rested his feet as he sat on his throne in heaven above. Alternate translation: “you who sit on your throne above the cherubim on the ark of the covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Asaph speaks of God as if he were the sun, giving light, a metaphor for moral goodness. Alternate translation: “give us light” or “show us the right way to live” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The phrase “stir up” means to “put into action.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: make your face shine on us
Note: The writer speaks of Yahweh acting favorably towards them as if Yahweh’s face shone a light on them. Alternate translation: “act favorably towards us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “and please save us” or “so that you can save us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Israel

Quote: You have fed them with the bread of tears and given them tears to drink in great quantities
Note: The words “bread of tears” and “tears to drink” are metaphors for continual sadness. Alternate translation: “You have made sure that they are very sad all the time” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: make your face shine on us
Note: The writer speaks of Yahweh acting favorably towards them as if Yahweh’s face shone a light on them. See how you translated this in [Psalms 80:3](../080/003.md). Alternate translation: “act favorably towards us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “you will save us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: You brought a vine out of Egypt
Note: Asaph compares the nation of Israel to a vine made ready to transplant. Alternate translation: “You brought us, like a vine, out of Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: you drove out nations and transplanted it
Note: The psalmist speaks of his people as if they were a plant that Yahweh was transplanting. Alternate translation: “you drove out nations from their land and gave it to us, the vine, and planted us there” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: You cleared the land for it
Note: Alternate translation: “You cleared the land for the vine”
Alternate translation: “the vine took root” or “the vine began to grow”
Alternate translation: “its branches covered the land”

Quote: The mountains were covered with its shade, the cedars of God by its branches
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Its shade covered the mountains, its branches the cedars of God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: the cedars of God by its branches
Note: “and the cedars of God were covered by its branches,” which copies the verb from the previous sentence. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “and its branches covered the cedars of God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
This could mean: (1) “the highest cedar trees,” the cedar trees that grew on the “mountains” in the land of Lebanon north of Israel, or (2) “God’s own cedar trees.”
the Mediterranean Sea to the west of Israel
the parts of new plants that are just starting to grow above the ground
walls of stone, not of wood

wild pigs that ruin gardens and farms and attack people. If your readers do not know what these are, use the word for a wild animal that ruins gardens and farms and attacks people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
land where there are many trees
wild animals of any kind
land where there are many plants but no trees
# General Information:\n\nAsaph finishes speaking of Israel in their land as if Israel were a grapevine in a vineyard.

The writer wants God to turn back in order to help them. This can be stated explicitly. Alternate translation: “Turn back to us” or “Come and help us again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Alternate translation: “look at”
The writer continues comparing the nation of Israel to the vine. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: This is the root that your right hand planted
Note: The right hand represents the Yahweh’s power and control. Alternate translation: “This is the root that you, Yahweh, planted” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
the part of a new plant that is just starting to grow above the ground. See how you translated this in [Psalms 80:11](../080/011.md).

Quote: down; they perish because of your rebuke
Note: This could mean: (1) “down; your people perish because of your rebuke.” or (2) “down. May your enemies perish because of your rebuke!”
This refers to Yahweh’s power and control. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: the man of your right hand
Note: the nation of Israel, which Yahweh has chosen as his people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
When a man in Israel wanted to honor another man, he would have that other man stand at his right side, close to his right hand. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: we will not turn away from you
Note: Here “turn away” is a metaphor for rejecting someone. This can also be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “we will not stop worshiping and obeying you” or “we will always worship and obey you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

The writer speaks of Yahweh acting favorably towards them as if Yahweh’s face shone a light on them. See how you translated this in [Psalms 80:3](../080/003.md). Alternate translation: “act favorably towards us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “you will save us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

# Psalm 081 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 81 is a wisdom psalm. It is meant to be sung at “new moon” and “full moon” ceremonies. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/wise]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Obedience
If Israel would obey and worship God, he would destroy their enemies.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
A psalm that Asaph wrote.
Alternate translation: “This is for the director of music to use in worship;”
This may refer to a style of music. See how you translated this in [Psalms 8:1](../008/001.md).

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **strength**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “strong.” Alternate translation: “God who causes us to be strong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
Here “Jacob” represents all of his descendants. Alternate translation: “the God of Israel, the nation of Jacob’s descendants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: play the tambourine, the pleasant lyre with the harp
Note: These are musical instruments.
a musical instrument with a head like a drum that can be hit and with pieces of metal around the side that sound when the instrument is shaken (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
This is the beginning of the lunar month.

Quote: the day of the full moon
Note: This is the middle of the lunar month.
Alternate translation: “and on the days when our feasts begin”
Here “it” refers to the feast day.

Quote: a decree given by the God of Jacob
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the God of Jacob decreed it” or “the God of Jacob commanded it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Here “Jacob” represents all of his descendants. Alternate translation: “the God of Israel, the nation of Jacob’s descendants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
Alternate translation: “gave it as a law”
Here “Joseph” represents all of the Israelites. Alternate translation: “to the Israelites” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: when he went against the land of Egypt
Note: This refers to the historical events in Egypt when the people of Israel were enslaved and God rescued them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Here “land” represents the people. Alternate translation: “the people of Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
# General Information:\n\nHere God begins speaking.

Quote: removed the burden from his shoulder
Note: Here “the burden from his shoulder” represents the forced labor the Israelites had to do as slaves in Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: his hands were freed from holding the basket
Note: Here “holding the basket” represents the forced labor the Israelites had to do as slaves in Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
Alternate translation: “In your great suffering”

Quote: I answered you from a dark thundercloud
Note: When God came to the Israelites, he hid the fullness of his presence and glory in a dark and threatening cloud. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: I tested you at the waters of Meribah
Note: God tested the children of Israel to see if they would trust him to supply water in the desert of Meribah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
# General Information:\n\nYahweh reminds the people what he said while they were in the desert.
Alternate translation: “because I am giving you a warning”
Here “Israel” represents the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “Israelites” or “people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: if you would only listen to me!
Note: Alternate translation: “how I wish you would listen to me” or “but you must start listening to me!”

Quote: Open your mouth wide, and I will fill it
Note: God taking care of all the needs of the people is spoken of as if he were a mother bird feeding her baby birds. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
# General Information:\n\nNow Yahweh tells what actually happened after he warned the people.
Alternate translation: “to what I said” or “to me”

Quote: So I gave them over to their own stubborn way
Note: God allowing the people to remain stubborn is spoken of as if God were giving them over to an enemy to let the enemy harm them. Alternate translation: “Therefore, I let them be stubborn” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: oh, that my people would walk in my paths
Note: God wanting the people to obey him is spoken of as if he wanted the people to walk on his paths or roads. Alternate translation: “I wish that they would obey my laws” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here “hand” represents Yahweh’s power. Alternate translation: “I would destroy” or “I would defeat” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Yahweh is speaking about himself in the third person. Alternate translation: “who hate me … before me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
Alternate translation: “bow down in fear” or “fall down in fear”

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I would humiliate them forever” or “I will punish them forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: I would feed Israel with the finest wheat
Note: God causing the best wheat to grow in Israel is spoken of as if he would literally feed the wheat to the people. Alternate translation: “I would allow the Israelites to eat the finest wheat” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Both “Israel” and “you” refer to the Israelites.
This refers to wild honey. Bees would build hives in the holes in rocks and make the honey there. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

# Psalm 082 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 82 is a psalm of judgment against the leaders of the other nations. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/judge]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Favoritism
The leaders of the nations need to protect the poor and needy and not to favor the evil rich people. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/favor]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/evil]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Metonymy

The leaders of the nations are represented by their gods. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/falsegod]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “the heavenly council” or “the meeting in heaven”

“he gives judgment.” If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **judgment**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “he judges” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

This could mean: (1) these are other spiritual beings who dwell in heaven. Alternate translation: “the divine beings” or “the heavenly judges” or (2) these are human judges that God has appointed. Either way, it does not mean they are gods like Yahweh is god. It means God has given them great power and authority. Alternate translation: “the rulers”

Quote: How long will you judge unjustly and show favoritism to the wicked?

Note: Here “glory” represents God’s presence. Alternate translation: “then his glorious presence will remain in our land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Note: The abstract nouns “faithfulness” and “trustworthiness” are spoken of as if they were persons who meet together. # Psalm 087 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 87 is a psalm about Jerusalem.

### Pride
People will be proud to have been born in Jerusalem.

Psalm 46, 48, and 76 are part of a group of psalms that celebrate Jerusalem.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Here “gates of Zion” represents the entire city of Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “city of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: Glorious things are said of you, city of God
Note: The writer speaks to the city of Jerusalem as if it were listening to him. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “You people in Jerusalem, other people say wonderful things about your city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
“I tell about.” Here “I” refers to Yahweh.

Here “Rahab” is a poetic way of referring to Egypt. Both “Rahab” and “Babylon” represent the people. Alternate translation: “the people of Egypt and Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
Alternate translation: “to those who worship me”

“This one” refers to the people from the nations that the writer mentions. Although they were not physically born in Zion, those who follow God are natives of Jerusalem spiritually. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Of Zion it will be said
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “People will say about Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Each of these was born in her
Note: People from other nations that worship Yahweh are spoken of as if they were born in Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “It is as though all of these people were born in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
It was common to refer to cities as “her.” Alternate translation: “in Jerusalem” or “in Zion”
The writer uses the reflexive pronoun “himself” to emphasize that it is the Most High who is doing this. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
Alternate translation: “will make Jerusalem strong”

Quote: Yahweh writes in the census book of the nations
Note: Yahweh acknowledging that the people from other nations belong to him is spoken of as if he were a king writing down the names of the people who live in his city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

“This one” refers to the people from the nations that the writer mentions. Although they were not physically born in Zion, those who follow God are natives of Jerusalem spiritually. See how you translated this in [Psalms 87:4](../087/004.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: All my fountains are in you
Note: Jerusalem being a place where people receive all their blessings is spoken of as if Jerusalem were a spring that provided water to the people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# Psalm 088 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 88 is a psalm of deliverance from sickness. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/deliverer]])

## Special concepts in this chapter
### Abandon
Ever since he was a child, the psalmist has been sick, and now all his friends have abandoned him. If he dies he cannot testify about God’s healing.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: A song, a psalm of the sons of Korah
Note: Alternate translation: “This is a psalm that the sons of Korah wrote”
Alternate translation: “this is for the director of music to use in worship”

Quote: set to the Mahalath Leannoth style
Note: This may refer to a style of music. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-transliterate]])
This may refer to a style of music. See how you translated this in [Psalms 32:1](../032/001.md).
This is the name of a man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **salvation**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “you are the one who saves me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
The writer uses these words with opposite meanings to say that he cries out continually. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

Quote: For I am filled with troubles
Note: The writer speaks of himself as if he were a container and troubles are the contents that fill the container. Alternate translation: “For I am very troubled” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Here “life” represents the writer. And “Sheol” represents death. The writer speaks about himself possibly dying soon as if Sheol were a place and he has arrived at that place. Alternate translation: “I am about to die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: People treat me like those who go down into the pit
Note: The word “pit” means the same as “Sheol.” The phrase “go down into the pit” represents dying. Alternate translation: “people treat me like I have already died” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: I am abandoned among the dead
Note: People treating the writer as if he were already dead is spoken of as if he were a corpse that they left unburied. Alternate translation: I am left alone as if I were dead” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I am like the dead who lie in the grave
Note: The writer feeling like people and God have abandoned him speaks about himself as if he were already a dead person lying in a grave. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
The nominal adjective “the dead” can be stated as an adjective. Alternate translation: “a dead person who lies” or “dead people who lie” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

Quote: about whom you care no more
Note: Alternate translation: “who no longer receive your care” or “people you have stopped caring about”

Quote: they are cut off from your power
Note: God no longer using his power to help dead people is spoken of as if God literally cut him off or removed him from his power. Alternate translation: “you no longer use your power to help them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: You place me in the lowest part of the pit, in the dark and deep places
Note: The writer feeling like God has abandoned him speaks about himself as if God has put the him in the deepest and darkest grave. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Your wrath lies heavy on me
Note: This speaks about God being very angry with the writer as if God’s wrath were a heavy object lying on top of the writer. Alternate translation: “I feel your great anger” or “I feel how very angry you are with me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: all your waves crash over me
Note: This speaks about God being very angry with the writer as if God’s anger were large waves rising up from the sea then landing on the writer. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “those who know me”

Quote: You have made me a shocking sight to them
Note: Alternate translation: “You have made me a disgusting sight to them” or “Because of you, they are shocked when they see me”

The writer’s physical condition that makes him repulsive to his friends is spoken of as if he were in closed into a confining space. Alternate translation: “It is as though I were in a prison” or “I am trapped” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: My eyes grow weary from trouble
Note: Here “eyes” represents a person’s ability to see. For his eyes to grow weary from trouble is a way of saying that he his troubles cause him to cry so much that it is hard for him to see. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: I spread out my hands to you
Note: “I lift up my hands to you.” This is an action that shows that he totally depends on God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

Quote: Will you do wonders for the dead?
Note: The writer uses a question to emphasize that if God lets him die then God will no longer be able to do wonderful things for him. Alternate translation: “You do not do wonders for dead people.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Will those who have died rise and praise you?
Note: The writer uses a question to emphasize that if God lets him die then he will not be able to praise God any longer. Alternate translation: “You know that those who have died will not stand up and praise you.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Will your covenant faithfulness be proclaimed in the grave, your loyalty in the place of the dead?
Note: Both questions mean the same thing. The writer uses questions to emphasize that a dead person is not able to praise God’s faithfulness. The abstract nouns “faithfulness” and “loyalty” can be translated as adjectives. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Nobody will proclaim your covenant faithfulness or loyalty from the grave.” or “Nobody will proclaim from the grave that you are faithful to your covenant and loyal to your people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: the grave & the place of the dead
Note: These represent the place where people go after they die.

Quote: your loyalty in the place of the dead?
Note: This can be translated as a separate sentence. Alternate translation: “Will your loyalty be proclaimed in the place of the dead?” or “Those who are dead will not proclaim your loyalty.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: in the darkness & the place of forgetfulness
Note: These represent the place where people go after they die.

Quote: Will your wonderful deeds be known in the darkness, or your righteousness in the place of forgetfulness?
Note: Both questions mean the same thing. The writer uses questions to emphasize that those who are dead are not able to experience or proclaim the great things God does. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “People will not talk about your wonderful deeds and righteousness in the dark place of the forgotten dead.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: or your righteousness in the place of forgetfulness?
Note: This can be translated as a separate sentence. Alternate translation: “Will your righteousness be known in the place of forgetfulness?” or “Those who are in the place of forgetfulness will not know about the righteous things you do.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
The writer praying to Yahweh is spoken of as if the prayer itself goes to speak with Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Why do you hide your face from me?
Note: This speaks of the writer feeling like God has rejected or abandoned him as if God were hiding his face or physically turning away from the writer. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Your angry actions have passed over me
Note: This speaks of God punishing the writer as if God’s actions are a large wave rising out of the sea that fall on and crush the writer. Alternate translation: “It is as if your angry actions crush me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: your terrifying deeds have annihilated me
Note: This exaggeration speaks about God punishing the writer as if God has completely destroyed the writer. Alternate translation: “the terrifying things you do have destroyed me” or “the terrifying things you do have almost destroyed me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])

Quote: They surround me like water all the day long
Note: The writer compares God’s “angry actions” and “terrifying deeds” to a flood of water. Alternate translation: “All day long they threaten to destroy me like a flood” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
The word “They” refers to God’s “angry actions” and “terrifying deeds” from the previous verse.

The writer speaks of God’s “angry actions” and “terrifying deeds” as if they were enemies who were trying to capture and kill him. Alternate translation: “they have surrounded me like enemy soldiers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “every person I love and know”

Quote: My only acquaintance is the darkness
Note: This speaks about darkness as if it were a person that could be friends with someone else. The writer is emphasizing that he feels completely alone. Alternate translation: “Everywhere I go it is dark” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

# Psalm 089 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 89 is a worship and a deliverance psalm. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/deliverer]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s promises
God is mighty and has promised David an eternal kingdom. But now that kingdom is being destroyed. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/promise]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/eternity]])

### Parallelism
This psalm exhibits the kind of parallelism where the second line often emphasizes the first line. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
This may refer to a style of music. See how you translated this in [Psalms 32:1](../032/001.md).
This is the name of the writer. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “faithful acts” or “loving acts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: Covenant faithfulness has been established forever
Note: God always doing what he promised to do is spoken of as if his faithfulness were a building that God has built and made firm. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “You will always be faithful because of your covenant with us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: your truthfulness you have established in the heavens
Note: God always doing what he promised to do is spoken of as if his faithfulness were a building that God has built and made firm. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

This could mean: (1) this refers to God’s dwelling place. This would mean God rules from heaven and he always does what he promises or (2) this refers to the sky. This would mean that God’s promises are as constant and permanent as the sky .

Quote: I have made a covenant with my chosen one
Note: You can make explicit that “chosen one” refers to David. Alternate translation: “I made a promise to David, the one I chose” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Yahweh is speaking in 89:3-4.

Quote: I will establish your descendants forever
Note: Yahweh always causing one of David’s descendants to be king is spoken of as if David’s descendants are a building that Yahweh will build and make firm. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I will establish your throne through all generations
Note: Here “throne” represents the power to rule as king. The psalmist speaks of God promising that one of David’s descendants will always rule as king as if God will build David’s throne and make it firm. Alternate translation: “I will make sure that one of your descendants will rule as king over every generation of my people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here “heavens” represents those who are in heaven. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Alternate translation: “praise you, Yahweh, because of the wonderful things you do”

Quote: your truthfulness is praised in the assembly of the holy ones
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **truthfulness**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “you always do what you promise to do.” This can also be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “The assembly of the holy ones praises you because you always do what you promise to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: the assembly of the holy ones
Note: This refers to the angels in heaven.

Quote: For who in the skies can be compared to Yahweh? Who among the sons of the gods is like Yahweh?
Note: Both questions mean the same thing. The writer is using question to emphasize that there in no one in heaven like Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Here “sons of” means having the characteristics of. This is a way of referring to other spiritual beings that live in heaven. Alternate translation: “angels” or “divine beings” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: He is a God who is greatly honored in the council of the holy ones
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The council of the holy ones greatly honors God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: the council of the holy ones
Note: Alternate translation: “the gathering of heavenly beings” or “the gathering of angels”

Quote: who is strong like you, Yahweh?
Note: The writer asks the question to emphasize there is no one as strong as Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
Yahweh always dong what he promises to do is spoken of as if his truthfulness were a cloak or garment that wraps around him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “You control the raging sea”

Quote: You crushed Rahab as one who is killed
Note: The word “Rahab” here refers to a monster of the sea. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
Here “arm” represents power. Alternate translation: “with your great power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
The writer uses the words “north” and “south” together to mean that God created everything everywhere. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

Quote: Tabor and Hermon rejoice in your name
Note: Tabor is a mountain southwest of the sea of Galilee and Hermon is a mountain northeast of the sea of Galilee. The writer describes these mountains as if they were persons who could rejoice. Alternate translation: “It is as if Mount Tabor and Mount Hermon were rejoicing in your name” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
Here “name” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “in you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: You have a mighty arm and a strong hand, and your right hand is high
Note: The words “mighty arm,” “strong hand,” and “right hand” all represent God’s power. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
To raise the right hand high into the air is a gesture that indicates power. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

Quote: Righteousness and justice are the foundation of your throne
Note: God ruling as king and doing what is right and just is spoken of as if God’s throne were a building, and righteousness and justice were its foundation. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The throne represents God’s rule as king. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Covenant faithfulness and trustworthiness come before you
Note: God always being faithful and doing what he promises to do is spoken of as if covenant faithfulness and trustworthiness come and meet with God. The abstract nouns can be translated as adjectives. Alternate translation: “You are always faithful to your covenant and are worthy of people trusting you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here the word “worship” implies shouting and blowing horns. These were common acts of worship during Israelite festivals. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Here people living their lives is spoken of as if they were walking. Alternate translation: “they live” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: in the light of your face
Note: The writer speaks of Yahweh acting favorably towards them as if Yahweh’s face shone a light on them. Alternate translation: “knowing that you act favorably towards them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here “name” represents the person. Alternate translation: “in you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: in your righteousness they exalt you
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **righteousness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “they exalt you because you always do what is right” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **strength**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “You make them wonderfully strong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
Here “their” refers to the Israelites. The writer would have included himself as a member of the Israelites. Alternate translation: “You are our” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Here “we” refers to the writer and the Israelites but not to Yahweh, to whom he speaks. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])

Quote: For our shield belongs to Yahweh
Note: The king who protects his people and whom Yahweh chose is spoken of as if he were a shield that belongs to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
# General Information:\n\nThe writer assumes that the reader knows the history of how David became the chosen king. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: I have set a crown on a mighty one
Note: To place a crown on a person’s head is a sign of making him king. Alternate translation: “I have made a mighty man king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

Quote: set a crown on a mighty one
Note: Some Bible translations have “given strength to a mighty one” or “helped a mighty one.”

Quote: I have raised up one chosen from among the people
Note: Here “raised up” means appointed. It is implied that God chose this person to be king. Alternate translation: “I have chosen one from among the people to be king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: with my holy oil have I anointed him
Note: Here to pour oil on someone’s head is a sign that God is appointing the person to be king. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

Quote: My hand will support him; my arm will strengthen him
Note: Here “hand” and “arm” both means the power and control of Yahweh. Alternate translation: “I will support him and make him strong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
The writer refers to those who have the nature or character of wickedness as “sons of wickedness.” Alternate translation: “wicked person” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
# Connecting Statement:\n\nYahweh continues speaking about David.

Quote: My truth and my covenant faithfulness will be with him
Note: God always being loyal and doing what he promises for David is spoken of as if truth and faithfulness were objects that would be with David. The abstract nouns “truth” and “faithfulness” can be translated as adjectives. Alternate translation: “I will always be truthful with him and I will always act faithfully towards him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: by my name he will be victorious
Note: Here “name” represents God’ power. Alternate translation: “I, God, will cause him to be victorious” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: I will place his hand over the sea and his right hand over the rivers
Note: Here “hand” and “right hand” represent power and authority. Here “the sea” seems to refer to the Mediterranean Sea west of Israel, and “rivers” refers to the Euphrates river in the east. This means David will have authority over everything from the sea to the river. Alternate translation: “I will give him authority over everything from the Mediterranean sea to the Euphrates river” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

Quote: He will call out to me, ‘You are my Father, my God, and the rock of my salvation.’
Note: This has a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. Alternate translation: “He will say that I am his Father, his God, and the rock of his salvation.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-quotesinquotes]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-quotations]])
Yahweh protecting and saving David is spoken of as if Yahweh were a high rock that David could stand on top of for protection from enemies. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
# Connecting Statement:\n\nYahweh continues speaking about David.

Quote: I also will place him as my firstborn son
Note: Yahweh giving David special rank and privileges over all other people is spoken of as if David would be Yahweh’s firstborn son. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I will extend my covenant faithfulness to him forever
Note: Yahweh speaks of continuing to act faithfully towards David is spoken of as if Yahweh’s covenant faithfulness were an object that he extends or makes longer. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adverb. Alternate translation: “I will continue to act faithfully towards him forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: his throne as enduring as the skies above
Note: Someone from David’s family always ruling as king is spoken of as if his throne would last as long as the sky will last. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
Here “throne” represents the power to rule as king. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Alternate translation: “David’s descendants”

Quote: punish their rebellion with a rod
Note: God punishing David’s descendants is spoken of as if he would hit them with a rod. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **rebellion**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “punish them for rebelling against me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

God punishing David’s descendants is spoken of as if God would literally hit them. This can be stated as a complete sentence. Alternate translation: “I will punish them because they sinned against me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: I will not remove my steadfast love from him or be unfaithful to my promise
Note: This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “I will always love David, and I will do what I promised to him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])
Here “lips” represent the whole mouth and the person speaking. Alternate translation: “what I said” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: his throne as long as the sun before me
Note: The words “will continue” are understood. Alternate translation: “his throne will continue as long as the sun before me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
Here “throne” represents the power to rule as king. God is promising that one of David’s descendants will always be king. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: as long as the sun before me
Note: God compares David’s rule as king to the sun to emphasize that someone from David’s descendants will always rule as king. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Here “It” stands for David’s throne or power to rule as king. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will cause it to last forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
God compares David’s rule as king to the moon to emphasize that someone from David’s descendants will always rule as king. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: the moon, the faithful witness in the sky
Note: The moon is spoken of as if it were a person who witnesses God making this promise to David. Alternate translation: “the moon, which is like a faithful witness in the sky” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
The words “the king” are understood. Alternate translation: “you have refused and rejected the king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
Alternate translation: “with the king you chose”
Alternate translation: “You have rejected the covenant”

Quote: You have desecrated his crown on the ground
Note: To push down into the ground or dust is a sign of great humiliation. Alternate translation: “You have defiled his crown on the ground” or “You have caused his crown to fall into the dirt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
This represents the king’s power as king and his right to rule. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: You have broken down all his walls. You have ruined his strongholds
Note: This implies that God allowed enemies to destroy the defenses at Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “You have allowed enemies to break down his walls and ruin his strongholds in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Here “neighbors” means people of nearby nations.

Quote: raised the right hand of his enemies
Note: Here “right hand” represents power. To “raise the right hand” means that Yahweh has made his enemies strong enough to defeat God’s chosen king. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

Quote: turn back the edge of his sword
Note: Here “sword” represents the king’s power in battle. To turn the sword back represents making the king unable to win in battle. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Here “edge” represents the whole sword. Alternate translation: “his sword” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: have not made him stand when in battle
Note: Here “stand” represents being victorious in battle. Alternate translation: “You have not helped him to be victorious in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: you have brought down his throne to the ground
Note: Here “throne” represents the power to rule as king. Alternate translation: “you, Yahweh, have ended his reign as king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: You have shortened the days of his youth
Note: This is a way of saying God made the king seem old even while he was still young. Alternate translation: “Even while he is young you have made him weak like an old man” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Yahweh completely humiliating the king is spoken of as if shame were a garment that God used to cover the king. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: How long, Yahweh? Will you hide yourself, forever?
Note: The writer uses these questions to emphasize that he does not want God to continue to refuse the king. Alternate translation: “Please, Yahweh, do not refuse to help the king forever.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
God not helping the king is spoken of as if God were hiding from him. Alternate translation: “Will you refuse to help the king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: How long will your anger burn like fire?
Note: The writer uses a question to emphasize that he does not want God to remain angry. Alternate translation: “Please do not continue being angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
God being very angry is spoken of as if his anger were a hot fire. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: for what uselessness you have created all the children of mankind
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **uselessness**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “uselessly.” Alternate translation: “that you have created all people to die uselessly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
This refers to humans in general. Alternate translation: “humans” or “people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-gendernotations]])

Quote: Who can live and not die, or rescue his own life from the hand of Sheol?
