Note: The writer uses these questions to emphasize that all people will die. Alternate translation: “No one can live forever or bring himself back to life after dying” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: rescue his own life from the hand of Sheol
Note: Here “hand” refers to power. The writer speaks of Sheol as if it were a person who has power over those who die. This could mean: (1) a person cannot bring himself back to life after dying or (2) a person cannot keep himself from dying. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: Lord, where are your former acts of covenant faithfulness that you swore to David in your truthfulness?
Note: The writer uses a question to request the Lord to be faithful to his covenant with David. Alternate translation: “Lord, be faithful to your covenant with David as you have been in the past” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: your former acts of covenant faithfulness
Note: The abstract nouns “acts” and “faithfulness” can be translated with a verb and an adverb. Alternate translation: “the things that you did before that showed that you are faithful to your covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
The writer asks Yahweh to bring this up in his memory. Alternate translation: “Remember” or “Consider” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: the mocking directed against your servants
Note: Here “your servants” refers to the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “how they mock us, your servants”

Quote: how I bear in my heart so many insults from the nations
Note: Here “heart” represents the person’s emotions. Alternate translation: “I endure so many insults from the people of the nations” or “I suffer because the people from the nations insult me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here “nations” represents the people of the nations. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
The enemies shouting insults at the king is spoken of as if insults were an object that the enemies throw violently at the king. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: they mock the footsteps of your anointed one
Note: Here “footsteps” represents where the king goes. Alternate translation: “they mock your anointed one wherever he goes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
# General Information:\n\nThis verse is more than the end of this psalm. It is the closing statement for all of Book 3 of the Psalms, which starts at Psalm 73 and ends with Psalm 89.

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “May people praise Yahweh forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
The word “Amen” is repeated to emphasize approval of what has been said. See how you translated this in [Psalms 41:13](../041/013.md).

# Psalm 090 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm is a wisdom psalm. God is eternal but a human’s life is short. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/wise]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/eternity]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Life’s shortness
Because life is so short, people need to spend it as God wants them to spend it.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Lord, you have been our refuge
Note: God protecting his people is spoken of as if God were a refuge or shelter. Alternate translation: “Lord, you have been like a shelter for us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “always”

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Before you formed the mountains” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Alternate translation: “were created” or “were shaped”
This represents everything that is in the world. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
This phrase represents all time past, present, and future.

This implies that just as God created the first man, Adam, from the soil, God will cause people’s bodies to turn back into soil after they die. Alternate translation: “You return people to dust when they die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Here “man” means people in general. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-gendernotations]])
The words “to dust” or “to soil” are understood. Alternate translation: “Return to dust, you descendants” or “Return to soil, you descendants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
This is a way of referring to humans in general. Alternate translation: “you humans” or “you people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: For a thousand years in your sight are as yesterday when it is past, and as a watch in the night
Note: The writer means that a long period of time seems like a short period of time to God. Alternate translation: “You consider a thousand years the same as one day in the past, or as a few short hours in the night” or “Even a thousand years is not a long time to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
“1,000 years” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: “to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: You sweep them away as with a flood and they sleep
Note: God causing people to die suddenly is spoken of as if he swept them away with a broom. This sweeping is also spoken of as if it were a flood that carried people away. Alternate translation: “Lord, you destroy the people as with a flood and they die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
This is a polite way of speaking of people dying. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
Both of these phrases refer to how the grass grows. Alternate translation: “it begins to grow and develop” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
Both of these phrases refer to how the grass dies. Alternate translation: “it fades and dries up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

Quote: we are consumed in your anger
Note: God destroying people in his anger is spoken of as if God’s anger were a fire that completely burns up the people. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “You destroy us in your anger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: in your wrath we are terrified
Note: Alternate translation: “when you are angry we are greatly afraid”

Quote: You have set our iniquities before you, our hidden sins in the light of your presence
Note: God considering people’s sins is spoken of as if sins were an objects he could place in front of himself and look at them. Alternate translation: “You see every sinful thing we do, even the sinful things we do in secret” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Our life passes away under your wrath
Note: The word “because” can be used to make clear that God’s wrath causes human life to end. Alternate translation: “Our lives come to an end because of your wrath” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/grammar-connect-words-phrases]])
The writer compares human life to a sigh to emphasize that life is very brief. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
“70” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
“80” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])

Quote: even our best years are marked by trouble and sorrow
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Even in our best years we experience trouble and sorrow” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
This is a polite way of referring to people dying. Alternate translation: “we die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])

Quote: Who knows the intensity of your anger, and your wrath that is equal to the fear of you?
Note: The writer uses a question to emphasize that no one has fully experienced God anger. Therefore no one truly reveres God and fears his anger when people sin. Alternate translation: “No one knows the intensity of your anger. Therefore no one fears your wrath when they sin.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Turn back, Yahweh! How long will it be?
Note: Asking Yahweh to no longer be angry is spoken of as if the writer wants God to turn physically away from his anger. Alternate translation: “Yahweh, please do not be angry any longer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The writer uses a question to state that he wants God to stop being angry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
Here “your servants” refers to the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “Be merciful to us, your servants”
Alternate translation: “Satisfy us every morning”

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “by being faithful because of your covenant with us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: in proportion to the days you afflicted us and to the years we have experienced trouble
Note: Both of these phrases mean the same thing. The writer is asking Yahweh to make them happy for the same amount of time he punished them. Alternate translation: “for the same amount of time that you afflicted us and caused us to suffer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Here “your servants” refer to the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “Let us, your servants” or “Let us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Here “children” means children and descendants.

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **majesty**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “great things.” Alternate translation: “see the great things you do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: May the favor of the Lord our God be ours
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **favor**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “be kind.” Alternate translation: “May the Lord our God be kind to us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: prosper the work of our hands
Note: Here “hands” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “cause us to be successful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

# Psalm 091 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 91 is a wisdom psalm. Those who depend on God are protected by him. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/wise]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Fear
No matter what dangers befall a person, they do not need to fear. God is protecting them from all harm.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: He who lives & will stay & of the Almighty
Note: Because “live” and “stay” mean almost the same thing, as do “shelter” and “shadow,” which are both metaphors for protection, you may need to combine the two lines into one. Alternate translation: “The Most High, the Almighty, will care for all those who live where he can protect them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

Quote: who lives in the shelter of the Most High
Note: The word “shelter” is a metaphor for protection. Alternate translation: “who lives where the Most High protects him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The words “the Most High” refer to Yahweh. See how this is translated in [Psalms 18:13](../018/013.md).

Quote: will stay in the shadow of the Almighty
Note: The word “shadow” here is a metaphor for protection. Alternate translation: “will stay where the Almighty can protect him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
the one who has power and control over everything. See how this was translated in [Psalms 68:14](../068/014.md)
Alternate translation: “I will say about Yahweh”

A “refuge” is any place a person can go and have someone or something protect him. A “fortress” is something that people make so they can protect themselves and their property. Asaph uses them here as metaphors for protection. Alternate translation: “the one to whom I can go and he will protect me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: For he will rescue you from the snare of the hunter and from the deadly plague
Note: The words that have been left out can be put in. Alternate translation: “For God will rescue you from the snare of the hunter and he will rescue you from the plagues that can kill” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
Alternate translation: “from the snare that the hunter has set to catch you”

Quote: He will cover you with his wings, and under his wings you will find refuge
Note: God’s protection is here referred to as “wings” which a bird uses to cover its’ young from danger. “Cover you with his wings” and “under his wings” mean basically the same thing. Alternate translation: “He will keep you safe and protect you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: His trustworthiness is a shield and protection
Note: God’s trustworthiness is here referred to as a “shield” which can protect people who rely on him. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **trustworthiness**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “trust.” Alternate translation: “You can trust him to protect you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

No one knows for sure what this word means. This could mean: (1) a small shield strapped to the forearm that soldiers used to defend themselves against arrows and swords or (2) a wall of stones set in a circle inside which soldiers could hide and shoot arrows.

The psalmist speaks of “terror” as if it were a spirit or fierce animal that could attack at night and so terrify people. Alternate translation: “things attacking you at night” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
These two phrases taken together refer to all possible times of night and day. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

Quote: the arrow that flies by day
Note: “Arrow” here is a metonym for the people who shoot the arrows. Alternate translation: “people attacking you with arrows during the day” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: or of the plague that roams
Note: The psalmist speaks of illness as if it were a person who went about at night killing other people. Alternate translation: “You will not be afraid of dying from illness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
goes wherever he wants to go at any time
These two phrases taken together refer to all possible times of night and day. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
an illness that makes many people ill at the same time

Quote: A thousand may fall at your side and ten thousand at your right hand
Note: “Many people may fall all around you.” If translating the exact numbers confuses the readers, you may omit them.
Alternate translation: “the evil will not harm you”

Quote: You will only observe and see
Note: Alternate translation: “You yourself will not suffer, but you will watch carefully, and you will see”

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **punishment**, you could express the same idea with a verbal phrase. Alternate translation: “how God punishes the wicked” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

The writer speaks of Yahweh protecting him as if Yahweh were a safe place for him to find protection from his enemies. Alternate translation: “Yahweh protects me, like a person finds protection in a place of refuge” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Make the Most High your refuge also
Note: “You should make the Most High your refuge also.” The psalmist stops speaking to God and speaks to the reader.

The writer speaks of a person experiencing bad or evil things as if evil were a person who overtakes another person. Alternate translation: “Nothing evil will happen to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: no affliction will come near your home
Note: The psalmist speaks of people who afflict others as though they were the harm they cause. Alternate translation: “no one will be able to harm your family” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Alternate translation: “Yahweh will command”

The psalmist speaks of the way a person lives his life as if it were a path down which the person walked. Alternate translation: “in everything you do” or “at all times” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “Yahweh’s angels will lift you”

Quote: you will not hit your foot on a stone
Note: The angels will protect not only the reader’s foot but the rest of his body as well. The words “not … hit your foot on a stone” is an exaggerated metonym to say that not even small bad things will happen. This should probably not be taken as a promise that no bad things will ever happen again. Alternate translation: “you will not even hit your foot on a stone” or “not even the smallest bad thing will happen to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: You will crush lions and adders under your feet; you will trample on young lions and serpents
Note: Where “hit your foot on a stone” is a minor problem, lions and snake are examples of great dangers. The psalmist speaks of lions and snakes as if they were small enough to be crushed under a person’s foot. Alternate translation: “You will be able kill lions and adders as if they were small animals you could crush under your feet” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
types of poisonous snake.
crush by walking heavily on

Quote: Because he is devoted to me
Note: Alternate translation: “Because he loves me”

Quote: I will be with him in trouble
Note: This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “I will be with him when he is in trouble” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **victory**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “I will cause him to be victorious” or “I will enable him to defeat his enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: will satisfy him with the length of his days
Note: The idiom “the length of his days” here refers to the duration of his life. It may imply a long life. Alternate translation: “I will satisfy him by giving him a long life” or “I will make him happy by letting him live a very long time” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

“and I will show him my salvation.” The psalmist speaks of the work God does to save people as if it were a physical object. Alternate translation: “I will save him so that he knows I am the one who saved him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# Psalm 092 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 92 is a psalm of praise for God’s kindness and faithfulness. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/faithful]])

## Special concepts in this chapter
### Justice
God causes evil people to be destroyed and good people to be happy and useful, even after they grow old. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/justice]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/evil]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: to sing praises to your name
Note: The words “your name” are a metonym for “you.” Alternate translation: “to sing praises to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: proclaim your covenant faithfulness in the morning
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective such as “faithful.” Alternate translation: “proclaim in the morning that you are faithful to your covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **truthfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective such as “true.” Alternate translation: “proclaim every night that everything you say is true” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
happy

The abstract noun phrase “your deeds” can be translated with the relative clause “what you have done.” Alternate translation: “by what you have done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

The abstract noun phrase “the deeds of your hands” can be translated with the relative clause “what your hands have done.” The word “hands” is a synecdoche for the whole person. Alternate translation: “What you have done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
The abstract noun phrase “your deeds” can be translated with a relative clause. Alternate translation: “what you have done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
Alternate translation: “We cannot understand what you plan to do until you do it”
The abstract noun phrase “your thoughts” can be translated with a relative clause. Alternate translation: “What you think” or “What you plan” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
animal-like

Quote: When the wicked sprout like the grass
Note: This compares evil people to grass, which grows quickly and in many places. Alternate translation: “When evil people appear quickly and seem to be everywhere, like grass” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: they are doomed to eternal destruction
Note: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “God has decided that he will destroy them completely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Indeed, look at your enemies, Yahweh
Note: Many texts do not have these words.
Alternate translation: “They will die” or “You will kill them”

Quote: All those who do evil will be scattered
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “you will scatter all those who do evil” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Many texts read, “have been scattered.”
Alternate translation: “driven away”

Quote: You have lifted up my horn like the horn of the wild ox
Note: The psalmist speaks of God as if he had made him as strong as a wild animal. Here his “horn” represents his strength. Alternate translation: “You have made me as strong as a wild ox” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: I am anointed with fresh oil
Note: Possible meanings are that the oil that God has put on the psalmist is a metaphor for God: (1) making him happy “you have made me very happy” or (2) making him strong, “you have made me strong” or (3) enabling him to defeat his enemies, “you have enabled me to defeat my enemies.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: My eyes have seen the downfall of my enemies; my ears have heard of the doom of my evil foes
Note: The words “eyes” and “ears” are synecdoches for the person who sees and hears. The lines may be combined. Alternate translation: “I have seen and heard of the defeat of my evil enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: The righteous will flourish like the palm tree
Note: Possible meanings are that righteous people will be like a healthy palm tree because they will: (1) be strong or (2) live for long time. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: they will grow like a cedar in Lebanon
Note: Possible meanings are that righteous people will be like a healthy cedar tree growing in the land of Lebanon because: (1) they will be strong or (2) people will honor them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has planted them” or “Yahweh takes care of them as if they were trees he had planted” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: in the house of Yahweh & in the courts of our God
Note: The psalmist speaks of people who truly worship God as if they were trees growing in Yahweh’s house. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The psalmist speaks of righteous people as if they were healthy trees. Alternate translation: “they are growing well” or “they are very strong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: in the courts of our God
Note: in the courtyard of the temple in Jerusalem.
The psalmist speaks of righteous people as if they were trees that produce food. Alternate translation: “They please God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

The psalmist speaks of righteous people as if they were trees. Alternate translation: “they remain strong and healthy” or “they always do what pleases God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

These words continue the thought begun by the words “they stay fresh and green” in ([Psalms 92:14](../092/014.md)). This could mean: (1) “they stay fresh and green, so that they can proclaim” or (2) “they stay fresh and green. This shows that.”

“Yahweh is the one who protects me.” The psalmist speaks of Yahweh as if he were a rock that would protect him. See how this is translated in [Psalms 18:2](../018/002.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# Psalm 093 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 93 is a worship psalm about the power of Yahweh.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s power
Yahweh is all powerful; He even controls the ocean.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: he is robed in majesty; Yahweh has clothed and girded himself with strength
Note: The psalmist speaks of Yahweh’s strength and majesty as if they were things Yahweh wears. Alternate translation: “he shows everyone that he is a powerful king” or “his majesty is there for all to see, like the robe a king wears; everything about Yahweh shows that he is strong and he is ready to do great work” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
the power of a king and the way a king acts
put on a belt—a band of leather or another material that a person wears around his waist—to prepare for work or battle

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “You have firmly established the world” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “no one will ever move it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Your throne is established from ancient times
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “You established your throne in ancient times” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Alternate translation: “you have always existed”

Some versions read “floods … floods’.” The word often refers to a river (See: “the River” in [Psalms 72:8](../072/008.md)), but “oceans … oceans’” has been chosen here because oceans, not rivers, have “waves” that “crash and roar.”

Quote: have lifted up their voice; the oceans’ waves crash and roar
Note: The psalmist speaks of the ocean as if it were a person who could speak. Alternate translation: “have made a mighty noise because their waves crash and roar” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
make a long, loud sound.

Quote: Above the crashing of many waves, the mighty breakers of the sea
Note: The phrase “the mighty breakers of the sea” means basically the same thing as “many waves” and emphasizes how great these waves are. Alternate translation: “Above the crashing of all of the very great waves of the sea” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
large waves coming to land
The psalmist speaks of where God lives as if it were high above the earth. Alternate translation: “in heaven” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
very serious
Alternate translation: “always stay the same” or “never change”

The psalmist speaks of Yahweh’s house as if it were a woman wearing beautiful clothing or jewelry and of Yahweh’s holiness as the beautiful clothing or jewelry. Alternate translation: “your house is beautiful because you are holy” or “your holiness makes your house beautiful the way beautiful clothes and jewelry make a woman more beautiful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
makes beautiful
This refers to the temple in Jerusalem.

Quote: for the length of your days
Note: This idiom refers to the duration of God’s life. Since God lives forever, it can also be translated as forever. Alternate translation: “for as long as you live” or “forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

# Psalm 094 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 94 is a prayer requesting that evil people be punished. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/evil]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Justice
Evil people expect God to ignore their injustices. But God knows what they are doing and will punish them for their evil deeds. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/justice]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/works]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Here “shine” is a metaphor for God revealing himself. Alternate translation: “show yourself” or “reveal your glory” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Rise up, judge of the earth, give to the proud what they deserve
Note: Alternate translation: “Come, judge of the earth, and punish the proud”

The psalmist speaks of starting to do something as getting up. If your language has a word for beginning to act, use it here. Alternate translation: “Take action” or “Do something” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: How long will the wicked, Yahweh, how long will the wicked rejoice?
Note: The psalmist repeats the question to show that he is unhappy with how long Yahweh has allowed the wicked to rejoice. If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “You have waited too long Yahweh; you have waited too long to stop the wicked from rejoicing.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Why the wicked rejoice can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “will the wicked rejoice because you never punish them for the evil deeds they do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Alternate translation: “All those who do evil pour out”

Quote: They pour out their arrogant words
Note: The psalmist writes of the wicked speaking as if their words were a liquid being poured out. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: all those who do evil boast
Note: The translation can make explicit that these people boast about their evil actions. Alternate translation: “all those who do evil boast about their evil deeds” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Here the metonym “nation” refers to the people of the nation. Alternate translation: “afflict the people of the nation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

The psalmist speaks of powerful people treating powerless people badly as if it were crushing them or breaking them in pieces. See how “break in pieces” is translated in [Psalms 72:4](../072/004.md). Alternate translation: “They completely destroy” or “They greatly harm” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “women whose husbands have died”
Alternate translation: “children without fathers”

Quote: the God of Jacob does not take notice of it
Note: Alternate translation: “the God of Israel does not see what we do”
# General Information:\n\nThe writer now instructs the wicked people.

This rhetorical question emphasizes the anger of the writer with the wicked people he is speaking to. If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “stop your foolish ways!” or “learn from your mistakes!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: He who made the ear, does he not hear? He who formed the eye, does he not see?
Note: These rhetorical questions can be translated as statements or commands. Alternate translation: “God made ears, so he can hear. God made eyes, so he can see.” or “God made ears, so stop acting as if he does not hear. God made eyes, so stop acting as if he does not see.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: He who disciplines the nations, does he not correct?
Note: If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. It is implied that Yahweh corrects his people. Alternate translation: “You know that Yahweh corrects the nations, so you can be sure that he will correct his people!” or “he will punish his people!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
This can be stated in positive form. This could mean: (1) God corrects. Alternate translation: “he corrects” or (2) God punishes. “he punishes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])
Here the thoughts of men are compared to vapor or steam that disappears into the air. This metaphor shows how unimportant and useless they are. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
“mist.” See how this word is translated in [Psalms 39:11](../039/011.md)
# General Information:\n\nNow the writer again talks to Yahweh.

Quote: until a pit is dug for the wicked
Note: The psalmist speaks of Yahweh’s punishing the wicked as if Yahweh were trapping an animal in a pit. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “until you dig a pit for the wicked” or “until you destroy the wicked” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “those whom he has chosen to be with him forever”

The psalmist speaks of those who judge as if they were the decisions they make. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **judgment**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “judge.” Alternate translation: “judges will again judge righteously” or “judges will again make righteous decisions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
The adjective phrase “upright in heart” can be translated as a noun phrase. Alternate translation: “those whose hearts are right with God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
Alternate translation: “will want the judges to judge righteously”

Quote: Who will rise up to defend me against the evildoers? Who will stand up for me against the wicked?
Note: If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “No one will defend me against the evildoers. No one will help me fight against the wicked.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
The adjective “wicked” can be translated as a noun phrase. Alternate translation: “wicked people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

Quote: Unless Yahweh had been my help & silence
Note: This is a hypothetical situation. Yahweh did help him, so he was not lying in the place of silence. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])

Quote: Unless Yahweh had been my help
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **help**, you could express the same idea with a verb. Alternate translation: “If Yahweh had not helped me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: I would soon be lying down in the place of silence
Note: Here “would be lying down” refers to “death” and “in the place of silence” refers to the grave.” Alternate translation: “in a short time, I would be dead, lying in a silent grave” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])

Quote: Your covenant faithfulness, Yahweh, held me up
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “You, Yahweh, held me up because you are faithful to your covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: When cares within me are many, your consolations make me happy
Note: The psalmist speaks of care as if he could count separate cares. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **consolations**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “console” or “comfort.” Alternate translation: “When I have been worried about many things, you have comforted me and made me happy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: Can a throne of destruction be allied with you, one who creates injustice by statute?
Note: This rhetorical question is used to make a point. If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “A wicked ruler who makes unjust laws is not your friend” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
Here the metonym “throne” refers to a king or ruler. Alternate translation: “a wicked ruler” or “corrupt judge” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
secretly plan with a person something harmful or illegal
This is an idiom which means to kill someone. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: Yahweh has been my high tower
Note: Here “tower” is a metaphor for protection. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has protected me from my enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: God has been the rock of my refuge
Note: The psalmist speaks of having God protect him as if God were a place where the psalmist could go to be safe. See how “rock” and “refuge” are translated in [Psalms 62:7](../062/007.md). Alternate translation: “I have asked God to protect me, and he has kept me safe by his power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: will bring on them their own iniquity
Note: This could mean: (1) “will do to them the evil things they have done to others” or (2) “will punish them for all the evil things he has done to others.”
This is an idiom which means “kill them.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This could mean: (1) “while they are doing wicked things” or (2) “because they have done wicked things.”

# Psalm 095 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 95 is the first in a series of six worship psalms (Psalms 95-100).

## Special concepts in this chapter

### God’s care
God made everything and takes good care of people. People should not be stubborn like the Israelites were in the days of Moses. The Israelites with Moses wandered in the desert for forty years.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

The psalmist speaks of Yahweh as if Yahweh were a mountain the people could climb so they would be safe. See how “rock” and “of my salvation” are translated in [Psalms 18:46](../018/046.md). Alternate translation: “the rock where we can go and God will save us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The psalmist speaks as if he is telling the readers to go into the throne room of a king. Alternate translation: “go to where he is” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “thanking him as we enter his presence”
Possible meanings are that Yahweh is a great king: (1) “who rules over all other gods,” or (2) “who is much better than all gods.”
This is an idiom which means “in his control” or “he is responsible for.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
deep places
high places
The word “hands” is a metonym for Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “he himself formed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
put both knees on the ground, often to show submission (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

The word “pasture” is a metonym for the food that animals eat in the pasture, which in turn is a synecdoche for everything that Yahweh provides for his people. Alternate translation: “we are the people whose needs he meets” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
an area where animals find grass to eat

The word “hand” here refers to how Yahweh protects his people the way a shepherd protects his sheep. Alternate translation: “the people whom he protects like a shepherd protects his sheep” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Today—oh, that you would hear his voice!
Note: “Oh, that you would hear his voice today!” The psalmist purposely interrupts what he is saying.
Here “his voice” represents God speaking or what he says. Alternate translation: “listen to God speak” or “hear what God says” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
# General Information:\n\nNow the writer writes the words that Yahweh spoke.
Alternate translation: “become stubborn”
These are places in the desert that Moses named because the Israelites rebelled against God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

These two phrases are both metaphors for the people seeing how much evil they could do before Yahweh would punish them. The phrases say basically the same thing and can be combined. Alternate translation: “tested me” or “wanted to see if they could do evil things without my punishing them … tested whether I would continue to be patient with them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
Alternate translation: “the amazing things I had done”
“40 years” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
Alternate translation: “all of those people” or “that entire generation of people”

God speaks of the people as if they were sheep, which will go wherever they want to and not stay near their shepherd. Alternate translation: “move away from me” or “go their own way” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: they have not known my ways
Note: Yahweh’s commands are spoken of as if they were paths on which the people should walk. The people not obeying Yahweh’s commands is spoken of as if they did not know these paths. Alternate translation: “they have not obeyed my commands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “the place where I would have allowed them to rest”

# Psalm 096 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 96 is one of six worship psalms (Psalms 95-100).

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh, the king
Yahweh is king over all the earth and is worthy of all praise.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
a song no one has ever sung before
This refers to the people of the earth. Alternate translation: “all you people who live on the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

The word “name” is a metonym for Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “bless Yahweh” or “do what makes Yahweh happy” See how “may his glorious name be blessed” is translated in [Psalms 72:19](../072/019.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **salvation**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “save.” Alternate translation: “announce that he has saved us” or “tell people that he is the one who saves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: Declare his glory among the nations
Note: Alternate translation: “Tell all the people in every nation about his great glory”

Quote: Yahweh is great and is to be praised greatly
Note: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “Yahweh is great. Praise him greatly” or “Yahweh is great, and people should praise him greatly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: He is to be feared above all other gods
Note: This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “Fear him above all other gods” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Alternate translation: “where he is”

Quote: Splendor and majesty are in his presence
Note: The psalmist speaks as if splendor and majesty are people who can stand before a king. Alternate translation: “Everyone knows of his splendor and majesty” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: Strength and beauty are in his sanctuary
Note: The words “strength” and “beauty” are metonyms for the ark of the covenant decrees, which is found in the sanctuary. Alternate translation: “It is his sanctuary that contains the ark of the covenant decrees” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Ascribe to Yahweh & ascribe praise to Yahweh for his glory and strength
Note: This can be restated to removed the abstract nouns “praise,” “glory,” and “strength.” See how these words are translated in [Psalms 29:1](../029/001.md). Alternate translation: “Praise Yahweh … praise Yahweh because he is glorious and strong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: Give to Yahweh the glory that his name deserves
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **glory**, you could express the same idea with a verb or adjective. See how these words are translated in [Psalms 29:2](../029/002.md). Alternate translation: “Honor Yahweh just as his name deserves” or “Proclaim that Yahweh is glorious just as his name deserves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
Here “name” refers to the person of God. Alternate translation: “he deserves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
the temple courtyard where the priests sacrificed animals to Yahweh

The implied information is that the people were to bow down in worship. Alternate translation: “Bow down to worship Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

The abstract nouns “splendor” and “holiness” can be translated as adjectives. Alternate translation: “because he is gloriously beautiful and holy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
to shake because of fear
Here “earth” represents the people. Alternate translation: “all the people of the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “He also established the world” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “nothing can shake it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Let the heavens be glad, and let the earth rejoice
Note: This could mean: (1) the heavens and the earth are spoken of as if they have emotions like people. Alternate translation: “Let it be as if the heavens are glad and the earth rejoices” or (2) “the heavens” and “the earth” are metonyms for those who dwell in those places. Alternate translation: “Let those who live in the heavens be glad and let those who live on the earth rejoice” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: that which fills it shout with joy
Note: The implied information is that this refers to all the creatures living in the sea. They are spoken of as if they should shout with joy like people might do. Alternate translation: “the sea creatures shout joyfully” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: Let the fields rejoice and all that is in them
Note: “Let the fields and all that is in them rejoice.” The psalmist speaks as if “the fields” and the animals that live in them have emotions like people. Alternate translation: “Let it be as if the fields themselves and all the animals that live in them are rejoicing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: let all the trees in the forest shout for joy
Note: This speaks about the trees as if they were people who could shout for joy. Alternate translation: “let it be as if all the trees in the forest shout for joy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: He is coming to judge the earth. He will judge the world & and the peoples
Note: The three phrase have similar meanings; the last two phases are used to strengthen the first. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Another possible meaning is “to rule … will rule.”

Quote: He will judge the world with righteousness
Note: Here “the world” is a metonym for all the people in the world. See how these words are translated in [Psalms 9:8](../009/008.md). Alternate translation: “He will judge all the people of the world righteously” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
The words “he will judge” are understood. Alternate translation: “he will judge the peoples with his faithfulness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. This could mean: (1) Alternate translation: “fairly, according to what he knows is true” or (2) Alternate translation: “using the same standard for all people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

# Psalm 097 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 97 is one of six worship psalms (Psalms 95-100)

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s authority
All people who worship idols are disgraced because Yahweh rules over all the world.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: let the earth rejoice; let the many coastlands be glad
Note: The earth and the coastlands are said to have emotions like people. Alternate translation: “Rejoice and be glad every person on the earth and near the seas” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
This could mean: (1) “lands near the seas” or (2) “islands.”
Alternate translation: “We cannot see him; it is as if he were sitting in the dark with clouds all around him”

Quote: Righteousness and justice are the foundation of his throne
Note: The word “throne” is a metonym for the deeds and words of the one who sits on it. The psalmist speaks as if righteousness and justice were physical objects that made the throne secure. Alternate translation: “He is righteous and just in everything he does” or “He is able to rule because he rules righteously and justly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here “the foundation of his throne” refers to how Yahweh rules his kingdom. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
The psalmist speaks as if fire were a person walking before King Yahweh and telling people that the king was coming. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
Alternate translation: “burns up his enemies”

The writer speaks of the earth as if it were a person who sees what Yahweh does and trembles in fear. Alternate translation: “like a person, the earth sees and trembles” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
shakes with fear

Quote: The mountains melt like wax before Yahweh
Note: The writer speaks of the mountains crumbling before Yahweh as if they were wax that was exposed to a fire. Alternate translation: “The mountains are unable to stand as Yahweh comes near” or “The mountains crumble in Yahweh’s presence” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

This could mean: (1) the psalmist speaks as if the skies are Yahweh’s messengers who declare that Yahweh is just. Alternate translation: “Everyone can see that God is just, the same way that everyone can see the skies” or (2) the skies refer to the beings that live in the heavens. Alternate translation: “All those who live in heaven declare that Yahweh is just” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Zion heard & the towns of Judah
Note: This refers to the people who live in these lands. Alternate translation: “The people of Zion heard … the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

The psalmist speaks as if those who were strong enough to rule were the physically higher than others. Alternate translation: “rule over all the people who live on” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
The psalmist speaks as if those who were strong enough to rule were the physically higher than others. Alternate translation: “You are high, far” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: he takes them out of the hand of the wicked
Note: Here the word “hand” represents power. Yahweh rescuing people from the power of wicked people is spoken of as if he took them out of their hands. Alternate translation: “he rescues them from the power of the wicked” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Light is sown for & and gladness for
Note: These two phrases have similar meanings and are used together for emphasis. Alternate translation: “Yahweh sows light for those who do right, and he sows gladness for those with honest hearts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: Light is sown for the righteous
Note: The word “sown” is a metaphor for actions with future results. “Light” is a metaphor for good things. Alternate translation: “Yahweh plans for good things to happen to the righteous in the future” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The adjective “righteous” can be translated as a noun phrase. Alternate translation: “righteous people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

Quote: gladness for those with honest hearts
Note: The words “is sown” are understood. The word “sown” is a metaphor for actions with future results. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **gladness**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “happy.” Alternate translation: “gladness is sown for those with honest hearts” or “Yahweh plans for people with honest hearts to be happy in the future” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
The heart is a synecdoche for the whole person. Alternate translation: “honest people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

# General Information:\n\nThis verse has a command followed by the reason for the command. If your language requires the reason to precede the command: “Because of what Yahweh has done for you, you righteous people, be glad and give thanks when you remember his holiness.”
This idiom means to be glad because of what Yahweh has done. Alternate translation: “Be glad because of what Yahweh has done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This could mean: (1) “when you remember how holy he is” or (2) “to his holy name,” a metonym for “to him.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

# Psalm 098 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 98 is one of six worship psalms (Psalms 95-100).

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Praise
Everyone and every thing should sing praises to Yahweh because he is worthy of all praise.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
a song no one has ever sung before. See how this is translated in [Psalms 96:1](../096/001.md).

Quote: his right hand and his holy arm have
Note: The words “right hand” and “holy arm” refer to Yahweh’s strength. Together they emphasize how great his strength is. Alternate translation: “his very great power has” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
the more powerful and skilled hand
Here “arm” is a metonym for power. Alternate translation: “the power that is his alone” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word ****, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “have enabled him to be victorious over his enemies” or “has enabled him to defeat his enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **salvation**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “save.” Alternate translation: “showed people that he saves his people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: showed his justice to all the nations
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **justice**, you could express the same idea with an adjective such as “just.” The word “nations” is a metonym for “the people who live in all the nations.” Alternate translation: “showed the people who live in all the nations that he is just” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
“remembers.” See how “call to mind” is translated in [Psalms 20:3](../020/003.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: all the ends of the earth
Note: This is a metonym for the people of the earth. Alternate translation: “people from all over the world” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: will see the victory of our God
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **victory**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “defeat.” Alternate translation: “will see our God defeat his enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
This is a metonym for the people of the earth. Alternate translation: “all people in the world” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Alternate translation: “suddenly begin singing happily”
Alternate translation: “sing because you are happy”
Alternate translation: “sing praises to God”
delightful or pleasing musical sound
an animal horn used as a musical instrument
“raise a shout.” See how “shout” is translated in [Psalms 47:1](../047/001.md).

Quote: Let the sea shout and everything in it
Note: The psalmist speaks as if the sea were a person who could shout to God. Alternate translation: “Let it be as if the sea and everything in it were shouting” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: the world and those who live in it
Note: The psalmist speaks as if the world were a person. Alternate translation: “and let it be as if the world and those who live in it were shouting” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
This is a metonym for the people who live in the world. Alternate translation: “the people in the world” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Let the rivers clap their hands, and let the mountains shout for joy
Note: The psalmist speaks as if the rivers and mountains were people who could clap and shout. Alternate translation: “Let it be as though the rivers are clapping their hands and mountains were shouting for joy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “he will judge the nations with fairness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
This is a metonym for “the people who live in the nations.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Alternate translation: “honestly” or “using the same standard for everyone”

# Psalm 099 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 99 is one of six worship psalms (Psalms 95-100).

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s justice
God is just and fair. Moses, Aaron and Samuel each prayed to him and obeyed him and he answered their prayers. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/justice]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
This refers to the people of all nations. Alternate translation: “the people of all nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
shake with fear

Quote: He sits enthroned above the cherubim
Note: You may need to make explicit that the cherubim are those on the lid of the ark of the covenant. The biblical writers often spoke of the ark of the covenant as if it were Yahweh’s footstool upon which he rested his feet as he sat on his throne in heaven above. Alternate translation: “He sits on his throne above the cherubim on the ark of the covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
shakes

Quote: Yahweh is great in Zion; he is exalted above all the nations
Note: Alternate translation: “Not only is Yahweh great in Zion, he is exalted above all the nations” or “Not only does Yahweh rule in Zion, he rules over all the nations”

Quote: he is exalted above all the nations
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “people in all the nations exalt him” or “people in all nations praise him greatly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Let them praise your great and awesome name
Note: Here the author shifts from speaking about God, to speaking to God. After this phrase though, he shifts back to speaking about God.

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **justice**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “what is just.” Alternate translation: “he loves doing what is just” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Here, **fairness** is a metonym for the laws that are fair. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **fairness**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “The laws you have established are fair” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Here the word “footstool” likely refers to the ark of the covenant, which the biblical writers often spoke of as if it were Yahweh’s footstool upon which he rested his feet as he sat on his throne in heaven above. The translation can make explicit that the people are to worship Yahweh. Alternate translation: “worship Yahweh at his footstool” or “worship Yahweh before his throne in the temple” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
important, given seriously
Alternate translation: “You answered your people”
Alternate translation: “Mount Zion”

# Psalm 10 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 100 is the last of six worship psalms (Psalms 95-100).

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s care for his creation
God made mankind and takes good care of people.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
“Raise a shout to Yahweh.” See how “shout” is translated in [Psalms 47:1](../047/001.md).
This refers to all the people of the earth. Alternate translation: “everyone on the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

The psalmist speaks as if he is telling the readers to go into the throne room of a king. Alternate translation: “go to where he is with joyful singing” or “he can hear you, so sing joyfully” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
God’s people are like his sheep. Alternate translation: “the people God provides for and protects” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
a grassy area for feeding animals
Alternate translation: “while thanking him” or “while giving thanks to him”

The word “name” is a metonym for Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “bless Yahweh” or “do what makes Yahweh happy” See how “may his glorious name be blessed” is translated in [Psalms 72:19](../072/019.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “he is faithful to his covenant forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **truthfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective.
