“generation after generation.” See how this is translated in [Psalms 89:4](../089/004.md).

# Psalm 11 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 101 is a psalm asking God’s help in living as a person should.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Encouragement
The psalmist wanted to encourage all the good people in the land restrain all the evil people. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/evil]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: I will sing of covenant faithfulness and justice
Note: The abstract nouns “faithfulness” and “justice” can be translated with adjectives. Alternate translation: “I will sing that you are faithful to your covenant and that you are just” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: I will walk in the way of integrity
Note: Here David speaks about “living” as if it were “walking.” Alternate translation: “I will live in a way that is honest and right” or “I will live a life full of integrity” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I will walk with integrity within my house
Note: Here David speaks about “living” as if it were walking.” Also, David speaks of overseeing his house with integrity, as if integrity were a physical object residing in his house. Alternate translation: “I will oversee my house with integrity” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I will not put wrongdoing before my eyes
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word ****, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. The idiom, “put evil before my eyes,” means to approve of it. Alternate translation: “I will not approve of anyone doing anything that is wrong in my presence” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: it will not cling to me
Note: David describes “evil” as if it were something unable to cling to him. This means that he would avoid evil things and people doing evil things. Alternate translation: “I will completely avoid evil” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
hold on to something or someone very tightly
Alternate translation: “to anything that is evil”

Quote: a proud demeanor and an arrogant attitude
Note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize how prideful such people are. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
“a proud outward appearance.”” This refers to a person being so proud that anyone who looks at him can see how proud he is.

Quote: I will look to the faithful of the land to sit at my side
Note: This means that David would allow those people to be around him and live with him. Alternate translation: “I will allow the faithful of the land to live with me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This refers to the people who are faithful to God. Alternate translation: “the faithful people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

Quote: walk in the way of integrity
Note: Here David speaks about “living” as if it were “walking.” Alternate translation: “live in a way that is honest and right” or “live lives full of integrity” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Deceitful people will not & liars will not
Note: These two phrases have the same idea and are used together to emphasize how David will not tolerate deceitful people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will not welcome liars” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Here “my eyes” refers to David himself. Alternate translation: “before me” or “in my presence” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
Alternate translation: “Every day”
This refers to wicked people. Alternate translation: “the wicked people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

David is referring to the city that he is in as “the city of Yahweh.” This can be made clear. Alternate translation: “from this city, which is Yahweh’s city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

# Psalm 12 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 102 is a psalm of deliverance from sickness. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/deliverer]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Salvation
The author does not want to die young. He also wants to see Jerusalem saved. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/save]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
This refers to a man who is afflicted. Alternate translation: “the afflicted man” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

Quote: my days pass away like smoke
Note: Here “my days” refers to the author’s life and the idea of “smoke” is something that quickly disappears. Alternate translation: “my life passes away quickly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Here the author refers to his “body” as his “bones.” Alternate translation: “my body feels like it is burning” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Here the author refers to himself as his “heart.” If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I am in despair” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: I am like grass that has withered
Note: This is another way to describe his despair. Alternate translation: “I feel like I am drying up like withered grass” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: I am like a pelican of the wilderness
Note: He compares his loneliness to that of a pelican, which is often seem alone instead of with other birds. Alternate translation: “I am lonely and despised like a pelican in the wilderness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
a large fish-eating bird

Quote: I have become like an owl in the ruins
Note: The author continues to describe loneliness by comparing himself to an owl in abandoned ruins. Alternate translation: “I have become alone like an owl in abandoned ruins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
This is a bird that is awake at night. Alternate translation: “a night bird”

Quote: I lie awake like a solitary bird
Note: The writer compares himself to a bird to emphasize his feeling of loneliness. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

David would have sat in ashes as an act of mourning, therefore ashes would have fallen on his food. Alternate translation: “I eat ashes like I eat bread” or “As I mourn, ashes fall on the bread that I eat” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

David did not purposefully mix his drink with tears; rather his tear would have fallen into his cup while he mourned and wept. Alternate translation: “my tears fall into the cup that I drink” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: you have lifted me up to throw me down
Note: God has not literally lifted and thrown David’s body to the ground; rather David says this to describe what he is feeling and experiencing. Alternate translation: “it is like you have lifted me up to throw me down” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: My days are like a shadow that fades
Note: David compares his time left to live on earth to a fading shadow. Alternate translation: “My time to remain alive is short like an evening shadow that will soon be gone” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

As David’s body becomes weak and he is nearing the end of his life, he compares himself to withering grass. Alternate translation: “my body has become weak like withered grass” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
dry and wrinkled

Quote: your fame is for all generations
Note: Alternate translation: “you will be recognized for all generations to come”
being known by many people
Here “Zion” refers to the people who live in Zion. Alternate translation: “have mercy on the people of Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
The word “her” refers to Zion.

The “stones” refer to the stones that were part of the city walls before they were destroyed. Alternate translation: “still love the stones that were formerly in the city walls” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Here “your name” refers to Yahweh. Alternate translation: “you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

The people will honor Yahweh because of his glory. Here Yahweh is referred to by his glory. Alternate translation: “will honor you because you are glorious” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
Alternate translation: “will be seen as glorious” or “people will see his glory”
This refers to destitute people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

Quote: he will not reject their prayer
Note: This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will accept their prayers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])

Quote: This will be written for future generations
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will write this for future generations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: For he has looked down from the holy heights; from heaven Yahweh has viewed
Note: These two phrases have similar meaning and are used together for emphasize how God looks down from heaven. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “his holy place high above the earth”

Quote: those who were condemned to death
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “those whom the authorities had sentenced to die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: proclaim the name of Yahweh in Zion and his praise in Jerusalem
Note: These two phrases have the same meaning and emphasize the idea of praising the name of Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

David describes God causing him to become weak as if his strength were a physical item that could be taken away from him. Alternate translation: “has caused me to become weak” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The word “days” here refers to his life. Alternate translation: “my life” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
David is asking God to not let him die. Alternate translation: “do not take me away from the earth” or “do not let me die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: you are here throughout all generations
Note: Alternate translation: “you are present throughout all generations”
The word “they” refers to “the earth” and “the heavens.”

Quote: your years will have no end
Note: Here David describes the length of time that God is alive as his “years.” This can be written in positive form. Alternate translation: “you will live forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])
Alternate translation: “will continue to live”

Here David describes the descendants being protected by Yahweh as being in his presence. Alternate translation: “be protected as they live in your presence” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# Psalm 13 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 103 is the first in a series of five psalms of praise to God. (Psalm 103-107)

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s grace
God is good to us by forgiving our sins and not punishing us as much as we deserve. His loving-kindness goes on from generation to generation. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/grace]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/forgive]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: I give praise to Yahweh with all my life, and with all that is within me, I give praise to his holy name
Note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize how much he will praise Yahweh. Alternate translation: “I will praise Yahweh with all that I am” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: give praise to his holy name
Note: This refers to praising Yahweh’s name as Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
“all of me” or “all that I am.” David uses this phrase to refer to himself and to emphasize his devotion to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
David is speaking to himself, so he uses the words “your” and “you” to refer to himself. Many translations express this with “my” and “me” as the UST does.
David is speaking to himself, so he uses the words “your” and “you” to refer to himself. Many translations express this with “my” and “me” as the UST does.

Quote: He redeems your life from destruction
Note: This means that Yahweh keeps him alive. Alternate translation: “He saves me from dying” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: he crowns you with covenant faithfulness and acts of tender mercy
Note: Here blessing someone and treating them with great honor is described as if it were placing a crown on that person’s head. The abstract nouns “faithfulness” and “mercy” can be translated with adverbs. Alternate translation: “he blesses you by acting faithfully and mercifully towards you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: He satisfies your life with good things

Quote: your youth is renewed like the eagle
Note: Having your “youth renewed” means to feel young again. Here David compares this feeling of youth to the swiftness and strength of an eagle. Alternate translation: “you feel young and are strong like an eagle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
The word “youth” refers to the strength one had as a young adult. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Alternate translation: “causes justice to happen to”
Who is doing the oppressing can be stated explicitly. Alternate translation: “all who are oppressed by men” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: his deeds to the descendants of Israel
Note: The words “he made known” are understood from the previous phrase. They may be repeated here. Alternate translation: “he made known his deeds to the descendants of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
Alternate translation: “is full of mercy and love”

Quote: He will not always discipline; he is not always angry
Note: These two phrases have similar meanings. The second one strengthens the thought in the first. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: He does not deal with us & or repay us
Note: These two phrases are parallel and emphasize that God does not punish us as we deserve. Alternate translation: “He does not repay us with the punishment we deserve for our sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “punish us”

Quote: For as the skies are high & toward those who honor him
Note: The simile compares the great distance between heaven and earth to the greatness of God’s love for his people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: so great is his covenant faithfulness
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “so he is very faithful to his covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: As far as the east & removed the guilt of our sins from us
Note: The distance between east and west is so far that it cannot be measured. In this simile, that distance is being compared to how far God moves our guilt away from us. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: As a father has compassion & on those who honor him
Note: Here the author compares a father’s compassion for his children to Yahweh’s compassion for those who honor him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “what our bodies are like” or “how he formed our bodies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: he knows that we are dust
Note: When Yahweh created Adam the first man he created him from dust. Alternate translation: “he remembers that he created us from dust” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: As for man, his days are like grass
Note: In this simile, the length of man’s life is being compared to the short length of time that grass grows before it dies. Alternate translation: “The length of man’s life is short like that of grass” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: he flourishes like a flower in a field
Note: In this simile, how man grows over time is compared to how a flower grows. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
To “flourish” is to grow well or be healthy.

Quote: The wind blows over it, and it disappears & where it once grew
Note: These phrases continue to talk about flowers and grass. They compare how flowers and grass die to how man dies. Alternate translation: “The wind blows over the flowers and grass and they disappear, and no one can tell where they once grew—it is the same way with man” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: the covenant faithfulness of Yahweh is
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “Yahweh is faithful to his covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
This means that Yahweh’s love continues forever. Alternate translation: “will continue forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
Alternate translation: “the descendants of those who honor him”

Quote: They keep his covenant and remember to obey his instructions
Note: These two phrases have similar meanings. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Yahweh has established his throne in the heavens
Note: Here Yahweh’s reign as king is referred to as his “throne.” Alternate translation: “Yahweh has taken his seat in the heavens where he rules as king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Alternate translation: “has made”
Here Yahweh is referred to by “his kingdom” to emphasize his authority as king. Alternate translation: “he rules” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
This is an idiom meaning to “do his will.” Alternate translation: “do his will” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: in all the places where he reigns
Note: Alternate translation: “praise him in all the places where he reigns”

This phrase means that he will praise Yahweh wholeheartedly and is used to emphasize his devotion to him. Alternate translation: “with all of me” or “with all my soul” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

# Psalm 14 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 104 is the second in the series of five psalms of praise to God. (Psalm 103-107)

## Special concepts in this chapter
### Yahweh’s creation
God has created everything good on earth, in the sky and in the sea.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. This psalm is a song of praise. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

This phrase means that he will praise Yahweh wholeheartedly and is used to emphasize his devotion to him. Alternate translation: “with all of me” or “with all my soul”(See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: you are clothed with splendor and majesty
Note: The words “splendor” and “majesty” have similar meanings and emphasize the greatness of Yahweh’s glory. They are described as clothing Yahweh like a garment. Alternate translation: “you have splendor and majesty all around you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: You cover yourself with light as with a garment
Note: Yahweh is described as being covered with light as if the light were a garment around him. Alternate translation: “You are covered in light” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: you spread out the heavens like a tent curtain
Note: Here God is described as spreading out the heavens like someone spreads out a tent when setting it up. Alternate translation: “you spread out the heavens like someone sets up a tent” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: You lay the beams of your chambers on the clouds
Note: “You build your upper rooms in the heavens.” This is referring to his house is so tall that the upper floor extends into the clouds.

Quote: you make the clouds your chariot
Note: Here the clouds are described as carrying Yahweh as if they were a chariot. Alternate translation: “you make the clouds carry you like a chariot” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: you walk on the wings of the wind
Note: Here the blowing of the wind is described as wings on which Yahweh walks. Alternate translation: “you walk upon the wind” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: He makes the winds his messengers
Note: This could mean: (1) he causes the wind to be able to carry a message like a messenger, “He makes the winds to be like his messengers” or (2) “He makes his messengers swift like the wind” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

This could mean: (1) “he causes flames of fire to be like his servants.” He causes fire to serve him like a servant would or (2) “he makes his servants to be like flames of fire”and (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This can be stated with the implied information from the previous line. Alternate translation: “He makes the flames of fire his servants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: He laid the foundations of the earth
Note: Here the phrase “laid the foundations” means “created.” Alternate translation: “He created the whole earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: You covered the earth with water like a garment
Note: Here the water that covered the earth is being compared to how a large garment is able to completely cover something. Alternate translation: “You completely covered the earth with water” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: Your rebuke made the waters & they fled
Note: These two phrases have basically the same meaning and are used together to emphasize how God spoke and the waters went away. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
move back, go down

Here the psalmist speaks about the waters receding as if they fled like an animal after hearing Yahweh’s voice. The word “fled” means to run away quickly. Alternate translation: “rushed away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: The mountains rose, and the valleys spread out
Note: Here the psalmist speaks of God causing the mountains and valleys to move and change as if they chose to move themselves. They are described this way to emphasize God’s power. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
The word “them” refers to the waters.

Quote: a boundary for them that they will not cross
Note: Here the psalmist speaks of God causing the waters not to cross the boundary that he created for them as if the waters themselves chose not to cross it. border
small rivers

Quote: the wild donkeys quench their thirst
Note: It can be stated clearly that they quench their thirst by drinking the water. Alternate translation: “the wild donkeys drink the water to quench their thirst” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
the ground at the edges of a river
Here David describes birds chirping as if they were singing. Alternate translation: “they chirp among the tree branches” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: He waters the mountains from his water chambers in the sky
Note: This means that God causes it to rain. The waters are described as residing in chambers in the sky. Alternate translation: “He waters the mountains by causing the rains to fall from the sky” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “the many good things that you create”

Note: The words “he makes” and “grow” are understood from the previous phrase, and can be repeated here. Alternate translation: “and he makes the plants grow for man to cultivate” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: The trees of Yahweh get plenty of rain
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh provides plenty of rain for his trees” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: There the birds make their nests
Note: They makes their nests in the cedars. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “The birds make their nests in the cedars” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
This is a type of bird. Alternate translation: “bird”

“Yahweh, you make.” Here the authors switches from speaking about Yahweh to speaking to him.
an animal that is food for another animal

Quote: and seek their food from God
Note: Alternate translation: “but they rely on God to provide their food”
go back to their dens
the homes of some mammals and small animals

“it is very deep and very wide.” The depth and width of the sea emphasizes how large it is. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

more than anyone can count

Alternate translation: “All these creatures”

Quote: give them their food on time
Note: Alternate translation: “give them their food when they need it”

Note: It may be helpful to state that it is food that is given. Alternate translation: “When you give food to them, they gather it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
collect
This describes Yahweh as opening his hand to give food to the creatures. Alternate translation: “when you open your hand to feed them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

This means that Yahweh does not look at them or pay attention to them. Alternate translation: “when you do not look upon them” or “when you ignore them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
This means that their bodies decay and are and become soil again. Alternate translation: “their bodies decay and return to the ground” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Note: This refers to his Spirit being sent to give life to creatures. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
It is Yahweh’s spirit that created them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Psalm 105 is the third in a series of five psalms of praise to God. (Psalm 103-107)

God protected Abraham and Jacob. He worked throughout Israel’s history to bring Israel into the Promised Land. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/promisedland]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Here “name” represents Yahweh. Alternate translation: “call on him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
This refers to the people in the nations. Alternate translation: “the people of the nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

remember and think about

# Psalm 17 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 107 is the last in a series of five psalms of praise to God (Psalm 103-107).

## Special concepts in this chapter
### Praise
The psalmist praises Yahweh for saving people lost in the desert, in prison, sick, in a storm at sea, homeless and oppressed. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/save]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/oppress]])

# Psalm 18 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 108 is a psalm of war.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Victory
God promised success to the psalmist, but Yahweh failed to help him conquer the country of Edom. He needed God to give him victory over Edom.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Here David is referring to himself by his heart. Also, the word “fixed” means to trust completely. Alternate translation: “My heart is fixed on you, God” or “I am trusting completely in you, God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: I will sing praises also with my honored heart
Note: Here David is represented by his “heart.” David refers to himself as having the honor of praising God. Alternate translation: “You honor me by allowing me to sing praises to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Here David describes playing his instruments as waking them up from sleep. Alternate translation: “I will praise you by playing the lute and the harp” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: I will wake up the dawn
Note: Here David is describing the dawn waking up like a person waking up in the morning. Alternate translation: “I will be praising you when the dawn comes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
when the sun rises

Note: These two phrases have similar meanings. They speak of the greatness of Yahweh’s covenant faithfulness and trustworthiness as if they were objects that were tall enough to reach up to the sky. The abstract nouns “faithfulness” and “trustworthiness” can be translated as adjectives. Alternate translation: “For your covenant faithfulness and trustworthiness are greater than the distance between heaven and earth” or “For you are more faithful to your covenant and more worthy of people trusting you than the sky is higher than the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Note: The psalmist is asking God to show that he is exalted. Being exalted above the heavens represents being great. Alternate translation: “God, show that you are exalted above the heavens” or “God, show that you are great in the heavens” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here Yahweh is referred to by his “glory.” Alternate translation: “may you be exalted” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: So that those you love may be rescued
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: Because those you love need rescuing” or “Rescue those you love” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Here Yahweh’s “right hand” refers to his power. Alternate translation: “by your power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Answering here represents responding to his request. Alternate translation: “respond to my request” or “answer my prayer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
# General Information:\n\nThis verse is the same as [Psalms 60:6](../060/006.md).

Quote: God has spoken in his holiness
Note: Here David describes God speaking something because he is holy as speaking “in his holiness,” as if his holiness were something that he was physically inside of. Alternate translation: “God, because he is holy, has said” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I will divide Shechem and apportion out the Valley of Succoth
Note: Here God is speaking about dividing the land of Shechem and the Valley of Succoth.
to divide into portions
# General Information:\n\nThis verse is the same as [Psalms 60:7](../060/007.md).

God speaks of the tribe of Ephraim as if it were his army. The helmet symbolizes equipment for war. Alternate translation: “Ephraim is like a helmet I have chosen” or “The tribe of Ephraim is my army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
a hard hat that soldiers wear to protect their heads from injury

God chose men from the tribe of Judah to be the kings of his people, and he speaks of that tribe as if it were his scepter. Alternate translation: “The tribe of Judah is like my scepter” or “Judah is the tribe through whom I rule my people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
# General Information:\n\nThis verse is the same as [Psalms 60:8](../060/008.md).

God speaks of Moab being unimportant as if Moab were a washbasin or a lowly servant. Alternate translation: “Moab is like a bowl that I use for washing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: over Edom I will throw my shoe
Note: God was probably speaking of taking ownership of Edom as if he were symbolically throwing his shoe onto that land to show that he owns it. However some versions have other interpretations. Alternate translation: “I take ownership of the land of Edom” or “I throw my shoe onto the land of Edom to show that it is mine” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
# General Information:\n\nThis verse is the same as [Psalms 60:9](../060/009.md).
# General Information:\n\nThis verse is almost the same as [Psalms 60:10](../060/010.md).

Quote: God, have you not rejected us?
Note: The psalmist uses this question to express his sadness that it seems that God has rejected them. Alternate translation: “It seems like you have rejected us!” or “God, you seem to have abandoned us!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: You do not go into battle with our army
Note: The psalmist speaks of God helping their army as if God were to go and fight with them. Alternate translation: “you do not help our army when we go into battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
# General Information:\n\nThis verse is the same as [Psalms 60:11](../060/011.md).
Alternate translation: “is worthless”
# General Information:\n\nThis verse is the same as [Psalms 60:12](../060/012.md).
Alternate translation: “will defeat our enemies”

Quote: he will trample down our enemies
Note: The psalmist speaks of God helping their army defeat their enemies as if God were to trample down the enemies. Alternate translation: “he will enable us to trample down our enemies” or “he will make us able to defeat our enemies. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# Psalm 19 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 109 is a psalm of vengeance against an enemy who has lied about him. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/avenge]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Enemies destroyed
This enemy lied about the psalmist. So he asked God to completely destroy his enemy and his enemy’s family.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “This is for the director of music to use in worship.”

The words “wicked” and “deceitful” refer to people. They have similar meanings and emphasize how bad these people are. Alternate translation: “For wicked and deceitful men” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
Alternate translation: “Although I loved them”
Alternate translation: “my love for them”

The word “they” refers to the people who are wicked and deceitful. You may need to make explicit that those who accuse the psalmist do so falsely. Alternate translation: “they accuse me falsely” or “they slander me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: Appoint a wicked man & appoint an accuser
Note: These two phrases are parallel and the phrases “a wicked man” and “an accuser” refer to the same person. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “at my enemy’s right hand”

Quote: When he is judged, may he be found guilty
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “When he is on trial, may the judge find him guilty” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: may his prayer be considered sinful
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “consider his prayer sinful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
The phrase “his days” refers to the length of his life. Alternate translation: “May he not live a long time” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Alternate translation: “his position of authority”
food or money given to beggars
Alternate translation: “their destroyed homes”
someone who lends money to another person but expects that the person will pay the money back
steal by force

Quote: May his children be cut off; may their name be blotted out
Note: These two phrases have similar meanings and emphasize his children being destroyed. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: May his children be cut off
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Cause his children to be cut off” or “Cause his children to die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: may their name be blotted out in the next generation
Note: Here the idea of there being no one to carry on the family name is spoke of as “their name being blotted out.” Alternate translation: “may there be no one to carry on his name” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: May his ancestors’ sins be mentioned to Yahweh
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “May you remember the sins of his ancestors, Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: may the sin of his mother not be forgotten
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “May you not forget the sins that his mother committed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: May their guilt always be before Yahweh
Note: Here David speaks about Yahweh thinking about their guilt as if their guilt is something physically present before him. Alternate translation: “May Yahweh continually think about their sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: may Yahweh cut off their memory from the earth
Note: David uses the word “earth” to refer to all the people that live on the earth. Also, the phrase “their memory” refers to people remembering them after they have died. Alternate translation: “may Yahweh make it so that no one on earth remembers them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: this man never bothered to show any covenant faithfulness
Note: This refers to him showing covenant faithfulness to people. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “this man never bothered to show any covenant faithfulness to people” or “this man never did anything to show that he was faithful to his covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
This refers to oppressed and needy people. Alternate translation: “oppressed people, needy people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
This refers to people who are disheartened. Alternate translation: “disheartened people” or “people who have lost hope” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
“until they died.” This means that he harassed them until they died.

Quote: may it come back upon him
Note: Alternate translation: “may his curses come upon him”

Quote: He clothed himself with cursing as his garment
Note: David speaks of the wicked person’s behavior as if it were his clothing. Alternate translation: “He cursed other people as often as he wore clothing” or “He cursed people all the time” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “as if they were his clothing”

Quote: his curse came into his inner being like water, like oil into his bones
Note: Possible meanings are: (1) He spoke curses so often that they became a part of his identity. “the curses that he speaks are part of who he is” or (2) the curse that he spoke happened to him. “his whole being was cursed by the curse he spoke” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This refers to how a person drinks water. Alternate translation: “like water a person drinks” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

This refers to how oil soaks into bones when rubbed on the skin. Alternate translation: “like olive oil soaks into a person’s bones when it is rubbed on his skin” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: May his curses be to him like the clothes he wears to cover himself
Note: People wore their clothes everyday. David speaks of a wicked person always being cursed as if his curses always covered him as his clothing does. Alternate translation: “Let his curses be on him every day like the garment he wears” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: like the belt he always wears
Note: The words “may his curses be to him” are understood from the previous phrase. They may be repeated here. Alternate translation: “may his curses be to him like the belt he always wears” or “and let his curses always be on him like the belt he always wears” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
Alternate translation: “May these curses be the reward”
This is a request for Yahweh to treat him kindly. Alternate translation: “treat me kindly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Alternate translation: “the sake of your reputation”

Quote: Because your covenant faithfulness is good
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “Because you are good and are faithful to your covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
These two words have similar meanings and emphasize that he is unable to help himself. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

Quote: my heart is wounded within me
Note: Here David speaks of being in great despair as his heart being wounded. Alternate translation: “I am full of grief and despair” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I am fading away like the shadow & like a locust
Note: David feels like he is going to die soon and describes this feeling by comparing himself to a fading shadow and to how the wind blows away locust. Alternate translation: “I feel like I am about to die, like an evening shadow that will soon disappear, like a locust is easily blown away by the wind” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This means that he is weak and it is difficult for him to stand. Alternate translation: “I have difficulty standing” or “My body is weak” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Alternate translation: “because I am not eating any food”

Quote: I am turning to skin and bones
Note: This means that he has lost a lot of weight. Alternate translation: “my body has become very thin” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: I am disdained by my accusers
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “My accusers ridicule me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
This is an act of disapproval.

Quote: save me by your covenant faithfulness
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “save me because you are faithful to your covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
The word “they” refers to David’s accusers and the people who say bad things about him.
Alternate translation: “have saved me”
The word “they” refers to the people who accuse David and say bad things about him.

Quote: may they be put to shame
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “may they be ashamed” or “let them be ashamed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
“but may I, your servant, rejoice” or “I am your servant, let me rejoice.” David uses the phrase “your servant” to refer to himself.

Quote: May my adversaries be clothed & may they wear
Note: These two phrase have them same meaning and are used together for emphasize how greatly he wishes for them to be ashamed. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Here David speaks of them being ashamed as if were clothing they wore. Alternate translation: “be very ashamed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: may they wear their shame like a robe
Note: David speaks of them being ashamed as if it were a robe that they wore. Alternate translation: “may their shame cover them just like their robe is wrapped around them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
This means that he will speak. Alternate translation: “I will speak and give” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: will stand at the right hand of the one who is needy
Note: This means that he will help and defend the poor person. Alternate translation: “will defend the one who is needy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

# Psalm 110 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 110 is a psalm honoring the king as he becomes king and also a prophecy about Christ. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/christ]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### King
The king will be able to conquer his enemies. Christ is seen as both high priest and king. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/highpriest]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
The phrase “my right hand” refers to the place of honor. Alternate translation: “Sit at the place of honor which I have for you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Here David describes Yahweh placing his master’s enemies under his power and control as putting them under his feet like a footstool. Alternate translation: “put your enemies under your power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Yahweh will hold out the scepter of your strength
Note: Here David speaks of Yahweh extending the area that the king rules as holding out his scepter. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will extend the area over which you powerfully rule” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
“King, rule among your enemies.” This is spoken to the king as a command.
“by their own choice.” This means that they will chose to follow the king.

Quote: on the day of your power
Note: This refers to the day that the king will lead his armies into battle. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “on the day that you lead your armies into battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: from the womb of the dawn & like the dew
Note: David describes the dew as a baby to whom the dawn gives birth. Alternate translation: “in the morning … like the dew” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: from the womb of the dawn your youth will be to you like the dew
Note: David is telling the king that he will have youthful strength each morning by comparing it to how the dew appears early each morning. Alternate translation: “each morning you will be filled with youthful strength to sustain you just like each morning the dew appears to water and sustain the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Yahweh is speaking to the lord, the one David calls “my master” in [Psalms 110:1](../110/001.md).
This means that he will not change what he has said. Alternate translation: “will not change his mind” or “will not change what he has said” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

The idea of being priest is understood from the previous phrase. It can be stated clearly here. Alternate translation: “after the manner that Melchizedek was priest” or “in the same way that Melchizedek was priest” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: The Lord is at your right hand
Note: When the lord goes to battle, Yahweh stands at his right hand in order to help him. Alternate translation: “The Lord helps you in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
The word “Lord” refers to Yahweh.

The word “He” refers to Yahweh. He will cause the kings to be defeated and die, but he will allow the king’s armies to kill the enemy kings. Alternate translation: “He will cause the kings to die” or “He will allow your armies to kill the kings” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
This refers to his enemies. Alternate translation: “enemy kings” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: on the day of his anger
Note: Here David speaks of the day when Yahweh will become angry and defeat the kings as “the day of his anger.” Alternate translation: “on the day of judgment when his patience turns to anger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: he will fill the battlegrounds with dead bodies
Note: This means that Yahweh will cause this to happen, not that he will personally kill all of the people who die on the battleground. Alternate translation: “he will cause the battlegrounds to be filled with death bodies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: he will kill the leaders in many countries
Note: This means that Yahweh will cause this to happen, not that he will personally kill the leaders. Alternate translation: “he will cause the leaders in many countries to be killed” or “he will allow the leaders in many countries to die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: He will drink of the brook along the road
Note: The king only stops briefly for a drink and then he continues the pursuit of his enemies. Alternate translation: “As he pursues his enemies, he will only stop to drink quickly from a brook” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
This means the he will drink water from the brook. A brook is a small stream. Alternate translation: “he will drink water from the brook” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
Alternate translation: “and so” or “therefore”
This could mean: (1) the king lifts up his own head or (2) Yahweh lifts up the head of the king.

Quote: he will lift his head up high after victory
Note: People raised their heads when they are victorious, confident, and joyful. Alternate translation: “he will confidently lift his head after victory” or “he will be victorious” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

# Psalm 111 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 111 is a psalm of praise to God for his miracles and care. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/miracle]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s character
God is great. He has given his people food and a land always keeps his promises to his people. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/promise]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/peopleofgod]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Here the word “heart” represents the person’s entire inner being and emotions. Alternate translation: “with all that I am” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: in the assembly of the upright, in their gathering
Note: These two phrases mean that same thing and may be combined if necessary. Alternate translation: “in the gathering of upright people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

Quote: eagerly awaited by all those who desire them
Note: The word “them” refers to the “works of Yahweh.” If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “all those who desire the works of Yahweh eagerly await them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
This could mean: (1) “sought after” or (2) “studied.”

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “that people will always remember” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
This is an idiom that means to remember. Alternate translation: “remember” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Alternate translation: “his works that demonstrated his power”

The writer speaks of the land that belonged to the nations in Canaan as if it were their inheritance. Alternate translation: “the land that belonged to other nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here the word “hands” refers to Yahweh, himself. Alternate translation: “The works that he does” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

This means that Yahweh’s instructions are unchangeable and will last forever. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “He has established them forever” or “They will last forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: to be observed faithfully and properly
Note: This could mean: (1) Yahweh has given his instructions in a faithful and proper manner or (2) his people are to observe Yahweh’s instructions in a faithful and proper manner. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “for his people to observe them faithfully and properly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: holy and awesome is his name
Note: Here the word “name” refers to Yahweh, himself. Alternate translation: “Yahweh is holy and awesome” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

The word “wisdom” can be translated as “wise.” Alternate translation: “the first step to becoming wise” or “the most important thing to become wise” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: those who carry out his instructions
Note: Alternate translation: “those who obey his instructions”
The word “praise” can be translated as a verb. Alternate translation: “People will praise him forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

# Psalm 112 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 112 is a wisdom psalm teaching the value of a righteous life. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/wise]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/righteous]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Righteous people
The righteous people will be well-known for their generosity and they will not have to worry about bad news because God is taking care of them.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “takes great pleasure”

Quote: the descendants of the godly man will be blessed
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will bless the descendants of the godly man” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Wealth and riches are in his house
Note: Here the word “house” represents the family. The words “Wealth” and “riches” mean basically the same thing and indicate an abundance of wealth. Alternate translation: “His family is very wealthy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

Quote: Light shines in the darkness for the godly person
Note: The writer speaks of God blessing the godly person in difficult times as if it were a light shining in darkness. Alternate translation: “The blessings that a godly person receives from God are like a light that shines in the darkness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The understood information can be made clear. Alternate translation: “lends his money to other people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: For he will never be moved
Note: he will not be troubled or overwhelmed by circumstances for his trust is in Yahweh? If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “For nothing will ever move him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: the righteous person will be remembered forever
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “people will remember the righteous person forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
“His heart is supported.” Here the word “heart” refers to the person. This could mean: (1) “He is at peace” or (2) “He is confident” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
“his righteous deeds will endure forever.” See how you translated this in [Psalms 112:3](../112/003.md).

Quote: he will be exalted with honor
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will exalt him by giving him honor” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
“will see that things go well for the godly person.” The word “this” refers to everything good that the writer has described in the previous verses about the godly person.

Quote: he will grind his teeth in rage
Note: The grinding of teeth is an expression of extreme anger. See how you translated a similar phrase in [Psalms 35:16](../035/016.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

The writer speaks of the wicked person’s eventual death as if that person were something, such as ice, that can melt. Alternate translation: “eventually die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the desire of the wicked people will perish
Note: Here, **desire** could mean: (1) the emotional desire that wicked people have. Alternate translation: “the things that wicked people want to do will never happen” or (2) it is a metonym for the things that wicked people have desired. Alternate translation: “wicked people will lose the things that they desired” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

# Psalm 113 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 113 is a psalm of praise to God for his goodness. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/good]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s help
God helps the poor and gives children to the wife who cannot conceive children.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Here the word “name” represents Yahweh, himself. Alternate translation: “Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: From the rising of the sun to its setting
Note: This phrase refers to the directions east, where the sun rises, and west, where the sun sets. The writer uses these two extremes to represent everywhere on earth. See how you translated this in [Psalms 50:1](../050/001.md). Alternate translation: “Everywhere on earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

Here the word “name” represents Yahweh, himself. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “people should praise Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: his glory reaches above the skies
Note: The glory of God is spoken of as if it was very high. Alternate translation: “his glory is higher than the skies” or “his glory is enormously great” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Who is like Yahweh our God, who has his seat on high
Note: This is the first part of a rhetorical question that the writer asks to emphasize that there is no one like Yahweh. It may be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: “There is no one like Yahweh our God, who has his seat on high” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: who has his seat on high
Note: Alternate translation: “who is enthroned on high” or “who rules in the highest position”

Quote: who looks down at the sky and at the earth
Note: This is the second part of a rhetorical question that the writer asks to emphasize that there is no one like Yahweh. It may be translated as a statement that begins a new sentence. Alternate translation: “There is no one like Yahweh our God, who looks down at the sky and at the earth.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: He raises up the poor & from the ash heap
Note: These two phrases are parallel. The writer speaks of Yahweh helping and honoring people who are poor as if Yahweh caused them to stand up from sitting in dirt and ashes. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: out of the dirt & from the ash heap
Note: Sitting in dirt and ashes represents either poverty or despair. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

Quote: so that he may seat him with princes, with the princes of his people
Note: Here the second phrase clarifies that the first phrase refers to the princes of Yahweh’s people. These two statements can be combined. Alternate translation: “so that Yahweh may seat him next to rulers of his people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: He gives a home to the barren woman of the house
Note: Here “home” refers to the children that live in a home. Alternate translation: “He gives children to the woman who had none” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

# Psalm 114 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 114 is a psalm of praise to God for his miracles in bringing the people of Israel to the promised land. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/miracle]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/promisedland]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Praise
The psalmist praised God for opening up the Red Sea for the people to cross, for providing the earthquake that stopped the Jordan River so the people could cross and providing water from a rock for the people to drink.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: When Israel left Egypt, the house of Jacob from a people who spoke a foreign language
Note: These two lines are parallel, with “Israel” and “the house of Jacob” meaning the same thing and “Egypt” and “that foreign people” referring to the same people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: the house of Jacob from a people who spoke a foreign language
Note: The word “house” here represents the family or descendents. The verb may be supplied to this phrase. Alternate translation: “the descendants of Jacob left people who spoke a language that the descendants of Jacob did not understand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: Judah became his holy place, Israel his kingdom
Note: Possible meanings for **Judah** and **Israel** are: (1) they refer to the land. Alternate translation: “The land of Judah became Yahweh’s holy place, the land of Israel became his kingdom” or (2) they are metonyms for the people of Judah and Israel. Alternate translation: “The people of Judah became those among whom Yahweh lived, the people of Israel became those over whom he ruled” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

The writer speaks of the Sea of Reeds as if it were a person who fled away as Yahweh led the people of Israel through on dry ground. Alternate translation: “It was as though the sea looked and fled” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

The writer speaks of the Jordan River as if it were a person who retreated as Yahweh led the people of Israel through on dry ground. Alternate translation: “it was as though the Jordan retreated” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: The mountains skipped like rams, the hills skipped like lambs
Note: The writer speaks of the mountains and hills as if they are alive. He is probably speaking of an earthquake when he describes their fear at the presence of Yahweh as if they were jumping like rams and lambs. Alternate translation: “It was as if the mountains shook like jumping rams and the hills shook like jumping lambs” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# General Information:\n\nVerses 5-6 contain four rhetorical questions. The expected answer to each question is found in verse 7, “because of the presence of the Lord.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: skip like rams & skip like lambs
Note: The writer speaks of the mountains and hills as if they are alive. He is probably speaking of an earthquake when he describes their fear at the presence of Yahweh as if they were jumping like rams and lambs. See how you translated similar phrases in [Psalms 114:4](./004.md). Alternate translation: “shake like jumping rams … shake like jumping lambs” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Tremble, earth, before the Lord, at the presence of the God of Jacob
Note: The last two phrases are parallel. The verb may be supplied in the second line. Alternate translation: “Tremble, earth, before the Lord, tremble at the presence of the God of Jacob” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

This could mean: (1) the writer is speaking to the earth as if it were a person and commands it to tremble with fear before God or (2) the word “earth” is a metonym for those who live on the earth. Alternate translation: “Tremble, everyone one earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: He turned the rock into a pool of water, the hard rock into a spring of water
Note: These two phrases are parallel. The writer describes Yahweh causing water to flow from the rock as if he turned the rock into water. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the hard rock into a spring of water
Note: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “He turned the hard rock into a spring of water” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

# Psalm 115 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 115 is a psalm of praise.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s power
God is in heaven and is able to do whatever he wants. Idols can not do anything. Therefore, people and priests should trust God for their protection. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/heaven]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/priest]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/trust]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Not to us, Yahweh, not to us
Note: The writer repeats the phrase “Not to us” in order to emphasize that they are not worthy to receive the honor that is due only to Yahweh. If necessary, a verbal phrase may be supplied here. Alternate translation: “Do not bring honor to us, Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
The word “us” refers to the people of Israel.

Quote: but to your name bring honor
Note: Here the word “name” represents Yahweh, himself. Alternate translation: “but bring honor to yourself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: for your covenant faithfulness and for your trustworthiness
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **trustworthiness**, you could express the same idea with a verbal phrase. Alternate translation: “because you are faithful to your covenant and you are worthy of people trusting you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: Why should the nations say, “Where is their God?”
Note: This rhetorical question emphasizes that there should be no reason for the nations to say what they say. If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “The people of the nations should not be able to say, ‘Where is their God?’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

The people of other nations use this question to mock the people of Israel and to express that they do not see Yahweh helping them. If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “Your God is not here to help you.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
Here the word “hands” represents the people who made the idols. Alternate translation: “things which men have made” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

The idols do not have real mouths, eyes, ears, or noses. Rather, people made them with the likeness of mouths, eyes, ears, and noses. The writer is emphasizing that these idols are not really alive. You can make clear the implied information. Alternate translation: “People have given mouths to those idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

The idols do not have real hands, feet, or mouths. Rather, people made them with the likeness of hands, feet, and mouths. The writer is emphasizing that these idols are not really alive. You can make this implicit information clear. Alternate translation: “People have given hands to those idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Alternate translation: “but those hands do not feel”

Quote: Those who make them are like them, as is everyone who trusts in them
Note: Those who make and worship idols become lifeless and powerless, just like those idols. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “Those who make them become lifeless like they are, as does everyone who trusts in them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
The word “Israel” represents the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “People of Israel, trust in Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

The writer speaks of Yahweh as if he were a shield because he protects his people as a shield would protect them from harm. Alternate translation: “the one who helps you and protects you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Here the word “House” represents the family or descendants. This phrase refers to the priests, who were descendants of Aaron. Alternate translation: “Descendants of Aaron” or “Priests” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Alternate translation: “has paid attention to us”
This refers to the people of Israel, who are descendants of Jacob, who also called Israel. Alternate translation: “the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
This refers to the priests, who are descendants of Aaron. Alternate translation: “the descendants of Aaron” or “the priests” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

“both small and great.” Possible meanings are that this refers: (1) to social status or (2) to age. In either case, the two extremes represent every person, regardless of age or social status. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

Quote: May Yahweh increase your numbers more and more
Note: The writer is speaking of the number of children that the people of Israel would have. Alternate translation: “May Yahweh increase the number of your children more and more” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
“both your children and your descendants’ children.” The writer clarifies that his request for more children applies not only to the present generation, but to their descendants, as well.

Quote: May you be blessed by Yahweh, who made heaven and earth
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “May Yahweh, who made heaven and earth, bless you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: the earth he has given to mankind
Note: This does not mean that the earth does not belong to Yahweh, but that has given the earth to mankind as a dwelling place.
The adjective “dead” may be translated with a noun phrase. Alternate translation: “People who are dead” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

Quote: nor do any who go down into silence
Note: This parallel phrase has a similar meaning to phrase before it. The verb may be supplied from that previous phrase to make the meaning clear. Alternate translation: “nor do any who go down into silence praise Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: nor do any who go down into silence
Note: The writer speaks of the grave or the place of the dead as a place of silence where no one can speak. This is a euphemism for death. Alternate translation: “nor do any who go to the place of the dead” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
The word “we” refers to the people of Israel who are still alive.

# Psalm 116 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 116 is a psalm of praise for saving the psalmist’s life. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/save]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Healing
The author was very sick and expected to die but God healed him. So he will pay his vow and sacrifice an offering of thanks. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/vow]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: he hears my voice and my pleas for mercy
Note: Here the word “voice” represents the person who is speaking. The abstract nouns “pleas” and “mercy” can be stated as “plead” and “merciful.” Alternate translation: “he hears me when I plead for him to be merciful to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: The cords of death surrounded me
Note: The writer speaks of death as if it were a person who could capture him and bind him with ropes. See how you translated this in [Psalms 18:4](../018/004.md). Alternate translation: “I felt like I was about to die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the snares of Sheol confronted me
Note: The writer speaks of “Sheol,” the place of the dead, as if it were a person who could trap him with snares. Alternate translation: “I felt as if I were ready to enter the grave” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: called on the name of Yahweh
Note: Here the word “name” represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “called out to Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here the word “life” represents the person. Alternate translation: “rescue me” or “keep me from dying” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

This refers to people who are inexperienced or who cannot care for themselves. The adjective can be translated as a noun phrase. Alternate translation: “those who are naive” or “those who are helpless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
The writer speaks of being humbled as in being in a lower position. Alternate translation: “I was helpless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: My soul can return to its resting place
Note: The writer speaks of having peace and confidence as if it were a place where his soul can rest. The word “soul” represents the person. Alternate translation: “I can rest in peace again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: you rescued my life from death
Note: Here the word “you” refers to Yahweh. The word “life” represents the person. Alternate translation: “you have saved me from death” or “you have kept me from dying” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

The verbal phrase may be supplied from the previous phrase to make the meaning clear. Alternate translation: “you have rescued my eyes from tears” or “you have kept me from crying” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

The verbal phrase may be supplied from the previous phrase to make the meaning clear. The feet here represent the person. Stumbling here probably represents being killed by his enemies. Alternate translation: “you have rescued me from stumbling” or “you have kept me from being killed by my enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: in the land of the living
Note: “in this world where people are alive.” This is in contrast to the place of the dead.

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I suffer greatly” or “People afflict me very much” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Alternate translation: “I said too quickly” or “I said without considering”
Alternate translation: “Every person is a liar” or “All people are liars”

Quote: How can I repay Yahweh & to me?
Note: The writer asks this leading question to introduce how he will respond to what Yahweh has done for him. If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement.
