Alternate translation: “This is how I will repay Yahweh … to me.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: I will raise the cup of salvation
Note: This is probably a reference to a drink offering, which was a sacrifice that involved pouring wine on the altar, and which the writer will offer in response to Yahweh saving him. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “I will present a drink offering to Yahweh because he saved me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: call on the name of Yahweh
Note: Here the word “name” represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “call on Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Precious in the sight of Yahweh is the death of his faithful ones
Note: The word “Precious” here does not imply that Yahweh values the death of his saints, but that the death of his saints is costly to him and grieves him. Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: “Yahweh considers the death of his saints to be a costly thing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the son of your servant woman
Note: This is likely a reference to the writer’s mother and indicates that she faithfully worshiped Yahweh. The full meaning of this can be made clear. Alternate translation: “as my mother was” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: you have taken away my bonds
Note: The writer speaks of being in danger of dying as if he had been chained in prison. Alternate translation: “you have saved me from death” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “a sacrifice to express my thankfulness”

Quote: will call on the name of Yahweh
Note: Here the word “name” represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “will call on Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: I will fulfill & all his people
Note: See how you translated [Psalms 116:14](../116/014.md).

Quote: in the courts of Yahweh’s house
Note: The word “house” refers to Yahweh’s temple. Alternate translation: “in the courtyards of Yahweh’s temple” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

The writer speaks to Jerusalem as though it were a person. Alternate translation: “in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])

# Psalm 117 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 117 is a psalm of praise.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Praise
Everyone should praise God for his love and unending faithfulness. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/love]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/faithful]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “Because his”

Quote: his covenant faithfulness is great toward us
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “he does great things for us because he is faithful to his covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: the trustworthiness of Yahweh endures forever
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **trustworthiness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective or a verbal phrase. Alternate translation: “Yahweh remains trustworthy forever” or “Yahweh will forever be worthy of people trusting him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

# Psalm 118 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 118 is a psalm of war and is about Christ. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/christ]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Rejected stone
The author praised Yahweh for his rescuing him. God enabled him to overpower his enemies. The new Testament, and even Jesus himself, saw the rejected stone as a reference to the Messiah’s rejection by the Jewish leaders. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/christ]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Give thanks to Yahweh, for he is good
Note: Alternate translation: “Thank Yahweh because of the good things he does”

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “he remains faithful to his covenant forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
The word “Israel” represents the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “Let the people of Israel say” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Let the house of Aaron say
Note: Here the word “house” represents the family and descendants of a person. This phrase refers to the priests, who were descendants of Aaron. Alternate translation: “Let the descendants of Aaron say” or “Let the priests say” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. See how you translated this in [Psalms 118:1-2](./001.md). Alternate translation: “He remains faithful to his covenant forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
Alternate translation: “those who fear Yahweh” or “those who worship Yahweh”

The writer speaks of Yahweh saving him from distress as if Yahweh had taken him from a place of confinement to a wide open space where he could move about freely. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: what can man do to me?
Note: The writer asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that there is nothing that man can do to hurt him since Yahweh is with him. If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “people cannot do anything to harm me.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Yahweh is on my side as my helper
Note: To be on one’s side is an idiomatic expression that indicates that that person approves of and will help another. Alternate translation: “Yahweh approves of me and will help me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: I will look in triumph on those who hate me
Note: It is implied that Yahweh is the one who will defeat the writer’s enemies, while the writer looks on. The full meaning of this can be made clear. Alternate translation: “I will see Yahweh defeating all those who hate me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
God is spoken of as if he were a shelter, a place where people can be protected. Alternate translation: “to seek protection from Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

This verse is parallel to the one preceding it. God is spoken of as if he were a refuge, a place where people can be protected. Alternate translation: “to seek protection from Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Here the word “nations” represents the armies of those nations. The writer uses hyperbole to emphasize the great number of armies that surrounded him. Alternate translation: “The armies of many nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
Here the word “name” represents Yahweh’s power. Alternate translation: “by Yahweh’s power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

The writer speaks of defeating the enemy armies as if he were cutting them off like a person would cut a branch off of a plant. Alternate translation: “I defeated them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The writer compares the enemy armies to a swarm of bees. Alternate translation: “They surrounded me like a swarm of bees would surround a person” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: they disappeared as quickly as fire among thorns
Note: Just like dry thorns burn out quickly, the attack of the enemy armies was quickly over. Alternate translation: “their attack lasted only a short time, as a fire that consumes thorns quickly dies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

The writer speaks of the enemy armies trying to defeat him as if they were trying to push him down onto the ground. Alternate translation: “in order to defeat me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Yahweh is my strength and joy
Note: Alternate translation: “Yahweh gives me strength and joy”

Quote: The joyful shout of victory is heard in the tents of the righteous
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “People hear the joyful shout of victory in the tents of the righteous” or “The righteous shout joyfully for victory in their tents” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: the right hand of Yahweh conquers
Note: Here the word “hand” represents Yahweh’s power. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has conquered by his great strength” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: The right hand of Yahweh is exalted
Note: Here, to raise one’s hand is a gesture of victory. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has exalted his right hand” or “Yahweh has raised his right hand in victory” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: I will not die, but live
Note: The writer states the same idea both negatively and positively to emphasize that he will certainly live. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
Alternate translation: “Yahweh has disciplined me”

Quote: he has not handed me over to death
Note: The writer speaks of death as if it were a person under whose power Yahweh could place the writer. Alternate translation: “he has not allowed me to die” or “he has not allowed my enemies to kill me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: Open to me the gates of righteousness
Note: “Open to me the gates through which the righteous people enter.” This is a reference to the gates of the temple, and the writer is addressing the gatekeepers. The full meaning of this can be made clear. Alternate translation: “Open for me the temple gates” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Alternate translation: “the gate that leads to Yahweh’s presence” or “Yahweh’s gate”

Quote: I will give thanks to you
Note: Here the writer begins to speak to Yahweh.
The word “salvation” can be translated with a verbal phrase. Alternate translation: “you have saved me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: The stone that the builders rejected has become the cornerstone
Note: This is likely a proverb that the writer has used to describe either the king or the nation of Israel. That which others have considered worthless, Yahweh has made to be the most important. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-proverbs]])

Quote: it is marvelous in our eyes
Note: This could mean: (1) “it is a marvelous thing for us to see” or (2) “we consider it to be a marvelous thing.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of joy. Alternate translation: “be very glad” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

Quote: Blessed is he who comes in the name of Yahweh
Note: Here the priests begin to address the king.

Quote: he who comes in the name of Yahweh
Note: Here the word “name” represents Yahweh’s power. Alternate translation: “the one who comes in the power of the Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: we bless you from the house of Yahweh
Note: Here the priests address the people.
The word “house” refers to the temple. Alternate translation: “Yahweh’s temple” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
The writer speaks of Yahweh blessing his people as if Yahweh were shining a light on them. Alternate translation: “he has blessed us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “tie the sacrifice with rope”
Here the writer begins to speak again and addresses Yahweh directly.
This is an exclamation that should be translated with whatever exclamation of emphasis you have in your language to make it sound natural. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclamations]])

Quote: give thanks to Yahweh; for he is good
Note: “thank Yahweh because of the good things he does.” See how you translated this in [Psalms 118:1](../118/001.md).

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. See how you translated this in [Psalms 118:1-2](./001.md). Alternate translation: “he remains faithful to his covenant forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

# Psalm 119 General Notes

## Formatting in this chapter

This is an alphabetic psalm with twenty-two groups of eight verses each all beginning with the same letter of the alphabet in the alphabetical order of the Hebrew alphabet.

## Type of psalm

Psalm 119 is a wisdom psalm about the Law of God. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/wise]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/lawofmoses]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### The Law
The author loved the law of God and was blessed by obeying it. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/love]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/bless]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “How good it is for those”

How a person behaves is spoken of as “ways” or “paths.” Alternate translation: “those whose behavior is blameless” or “those whom no one can blame for doing wrong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: who walk in the law of Yahweh
Note: The way a person lives or behaves is spoken of as walking. Alternate translation: “who live according to the law of Yahweh” or “who obey the law of Yahweh.” This phrase clarifies the meaning of “whose ways are blameless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: who seek him with all their heart
Note: To “seek” God means to want to know him.
This is an idiom which means intensely or sincerely. Alternate translation: “with all their being” or “with everything in them” or “sincerely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
# General Information:\n\nMost of this psalm is addressed to God, and the words “you” and “your” almost always refer to him.
They do not disobey Yahweh.
Here their behavior is spoken of as “walking,” and the way God wants them to behave is spoken of as “his ways.” Alternate translation: “they behave as Yahweh wants them to”
Alternate translation: “obey all the things that you have declared that we should do”
This is to carefully know and understand the commandments and to obey those commandments.
The writer speaks of being established in God’s commandments as if no one could physically make him move. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “in obeying your statutes”

Quote: I would not be put to shame
Note: The writer does not want to be ashamed when he is in God’s presence.
Alternate translation: “all that you have commanded us”

“a sincere heart.” A person who is sincere will do what is right. The heart refers to the center of emotions in a person. See how you translated “uprightness” in [Psalms 25:21](../025/021.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
“Statutes” refers to God’s laws or commands.

Quote: How can a young person keep his path pure?
Note: This question is used to introduce a new value to the word of God. If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “This is how a young person can keep his path pure” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
The writer compares living according to God’s law as a path kept clear of obstructions. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

This is an idiom. The heart refers to all of one’s emotions, feelings, desires, and will. Alternate translation: “with all my being” or “with everything in me” or “sincerely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: Do not let me stray from your commandments
Note: Here to disobey God’s commandments is described as straying off a path. Alternate translation: “Do not let me disobey your commandments” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I have stored up your word in my heart
Note: “I have put your words in my heart.” This is a metaphor that means “I have memorized your word.” The heart is pictured as a container that can hold what people think. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “more than all the wealth”

Quote: I will meditate & and pay attention
Note: These are parallel thoughts that have similar meanings, which are repeated for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “think carefully about what you have instructed us”
This idiom refers to thinking clearly about what is being discussed. Alternate translation: “give careful thought” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
to take pleasure
The writer called himself “your servant” to show his humility.

Quote: Open my eyes so that I may see
Note: The author speaks of gaining understanding, knowledge and wisdom as being able to see. Alternate translation: Help me to understand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The author speaks of insight into the law as objects to marvel at. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “in your instructions” or “in your commands”

Quote: I am a foreigner in the land
Note: This could mean: (1) the writers speaks of his short life on earth as if he were a foreigner who would not stay long in the land. Alternate translation: “I am like a foreigner living a short time in the land” or (2) the writer’s ignorance of God’s law as if he were a foreigner who did not know the laws of the land. Alternate translation: “I am ignorant like a foreigner in the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: My desires are crushed by the longing
Note: The writer speaks of his desires being very strong as if they were in pain. Alternate translation: “My inner being strongly desires to know” or “My soul aches because I want so much to know” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This could mean: (1) God will curse them or (2) they deserve God’s punishment. Alternate translation: “who deserve your punishment”

The writer speaks of disobeying God’s commandments as if they were a path that can be wandered off from. Alternate translation: “who go away from the path of your commandments” or “who disobey your commandments” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “Keep me from” or “Rescue me from”

Quote: Though rulers plot and slander me
Note: Alternate translation: “Though rulers make plans to harm me and say bad things about me”

Quote: Your covenant decrees are my delight
Note: Alternate translation: “Your covenant decrees make me very happy.”
God’s decrees are spoken of as if they were people. Alternate translation: “they are like wise counselors to me” or “they give me wise counsel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: My life clings to the dust
Note: This is an idiom. Possible meanings are that: (1) he thought that he would die soon, or (2) he lay in the dust because he was very sad, or (3) he realized that he desired the worthless things of the earth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: Give me life by your word
Note: This is an idiom. Here “life” refers to purpose and significance, not just biological life. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Alternate translation: “according to your promise”
What a person does or how he behaves is spoken of as if it were a road or way. Alternate translation: “what I have done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “amazing teachings”
Alternate translation: “because I am so sad”
“Make me strong.” This may refer to physical strength or spiritual strength.

Quote: Turn from me the path of deceit
Note: The word “path” here refers to a way of behaving. Alternate translation: “Keep me from following the path of deceit” or “Prevent me from being deceptive” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This could mean: (1) “lying” or (2) “believing lies” or “following lies.”
How a person behaves or acts is spoken as if it were a road or way. Alternate translation: “to be faithful to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I cling to your covenant decrees
Note: Holding tightly to them refers to being committed to obeying them. Alternate translation: “I hold tightly to your covenant decrees” or “I am committed to obeying your covenant decrees” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This refers to the law of Moses.

Quote: I will run in the path of your commandments
Note: The writer speaks of being focused or committed to obeying God’s commands as if one is running on a path. Alternate translation: “I will be committed to obey your commands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

This is an idiom. This could mean: (1) “you help me gain greater understanding of your commands” or (2) “you give me greater desire to obey your commands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This is another way of describing the law of Moses.
This could mean: (1) “completely” or (2) “to the end of my life” or (3) “to the end of time.”
Alternate translation: “obey your law”

Quote: I will observe it with all my heart
Note: Alternate translation: “I will surely observe your law” or “I am completely committed to doing what it says”
This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “with all my being” or “with everything in me” or “sincerely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: Guide me in the path of your commandments
Note: “Guide me according to your commandments” or “Teach me to obey your commandments.” God’s commandments are compared to a path that a person walks in obedience to God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This is an idiom. The “heart” here refers to the will, desires, and choices that directs one’s life. Alternate translation: “Make me want” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
“to obey your covenant decrees.” This is referring to obeying the law of Moses.
“the desire for riches.” This is referring to wealth gained by illegal methods or wrongdoing towards others.

Quote: Turn my eyes from looking at worthless things
Note: This is a metaphor that refers to one desiring things that have no eternal value. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “make me able to live as you wish me to live”
Alternate translation: “make my life strong” or “give me strength”

Quote: Carry out for your servant your promise that you made to those who honor you
Note: Alternate translation: “Do for your servant what you promised to do for those who honor you”
The writer referred to himself as God’s servant to show his humility. Alternate translation: “me, your servant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Alternate translation: “I am very afraid of”
God judges rightly and his decisions are good. Alternate translation: “Your judgments are righteous and good” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
This refers to being aware of the situation. The focus is on knowledge or understanding, rather than just observing.

Quote: I have longed for your instructions
Note: This could mean: (1) “I want very much to know your instructions” or (2) “I want very much to obey what you teach us to do.”
The word “righteousness” is an abstract noun and refers to being righteous. Alternate translation: “revive me because you are righteous” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
This could mean: (1) “Keep me alive” or (2) “Make me strong.”
You may make clear the understood information. Alternate translation: “give me your salvation” or “save me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
Alternate translation: “an answer” or “a response”

Quote: Do not take the word of truth from my mouth
Note: Here the writer is represented by his “mouth.” This could mean: (1) “never prevent me from speaking the message about the truth” or (2) “never prevent me from speaking the true message.”
Alternate translation: “I will obey”
To walk securely is to live one’s life securely. Alternate translation: “I will live securely in God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
To “seek” is to perceive, or gain understanding of God’s instructions as if one can see them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Alternate translation: “serious commands to kings” or “instructions to kings”
This could mean: (1) “I find delight in studying your commandments” or (2) “I am delighted that I have the opportunity to study your commandments.”
This is an idiom which means to honor, cherish or respect God’s commandments. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
“Remember your promise.” See how you translated this in [Psalms 20:3](../020/003.md)

Quote: This is my comfort in my affliction: that your promise has kept me alive
Note: This clause can be restructured. Alternate translation: “The reason for my comfort is that your promise has kept me alive in my affliction” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-sentences]])
This nominal adjective can be stated as an adjective. Alternate translation: “The proud people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
to mock someone or something that is looked down on, doubted, or not honored
This is a reference to when the decrees, the Law, were given to Moses many years before. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: Hot anger has taken hold of me
Note: This is an idiom. Anger is expressed as if it is a person that can grab another person. Alternate translation: “I have become very angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: Your statutes have been my songs
Note: Alternate translation: “I have used your statutes as lyrics to my music” or “I have created songs from your statutes”
Here the word “name” represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “I think about you, Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
This is an idiom which means to obey the law. Alternate translation: “I obey your law” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Alternate translation: “my habit”
This is an idiom which means to follow or to obey those instructions. Alternate translation: “I have obeyed your instructions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

This means Yahweh is all he wants. Just as the Levites did not receive vast territories of land for the Lord was to be their portion so the writer claims Yahweh as the satisfier of his needs. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Here “feet” represent the whole person. To repent and choose to obey God’s laws is like turning one’s feet on a path to head in another direction. Alternate translation: “changed my direction” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I hurry and do not delay
Note: The writer expresses the same idea both positively and negatively in order to emphasize the urgency with which he obeys Yahweh’s commands. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

Quote: The cords of the wicked have ensnared me
Note: In this metaphor, wicked or evil people tried to cause the writer to sin like a hunter seeking to catch an animal with a trap. Alternate translation: “My enemies have tried to catch me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I am a companion of all who honor you
Note: Alternate translation: “I am a friend of all who honor you”

Quote: The earth, Yahweh, is full of your covenant faithfulness
Note: People everywhere in the world being able to see evidence of Yahweh’s covenant faithfulness is spoken of as if his covenant faithfulness filled the earth. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **covenant faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. See how you translated a similar phrase in [Psalms 33:5](../033/005.md). Alternate translation: “People everywhere on earth can see that you, Yahweh, are faithful to your covenant” or “Throughout the earth, there is evidence that you, Yahweh, are faithful to your covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
The writer refers to himself as “your servant.” Alternate translation: “to me, your servant” or “to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
This is an idiom. “Your word” refers to the promises Yahweh has made to the writer. Alternate translation: “as you have promised” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: Teach me proper discernment and understanding, for I have believed in your commandments
Note: Some languages may require change in logical progression. Alternate translation: “Since I have believed in your commandments, teach me proper discernment and understanding” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-sentences]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-intro]])

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Before you afflicted me” or “Before you punished me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Disobeying God is spoken of as if the person walked on the wrong path. Alternate translation: “I disobeyed you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here “word” represents commandments. Alternate translation: “I obey your commandments” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
This nominal adjective can be stated as an adjective. Alternate translation: “Arrogant people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
People telling many lies about a person is spoken of as if they made the person dirty by spreading lies over him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here “heart” represents a person’s will. Alternate translation: “with complete commitment” or “completely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Here “hearts” represents the people’s wills. A person being stubborn is spoken of as if their hearts or wills were hard like a rock. Alternate translation: “They are stubborn” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here “mouth” represents what God says. Alternate translation: “The instructions you have spoken are” or “Your instructions are” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: than thousands of pieces of gold and silver
Note: This can be stated more generally. Alternate translation: “than a large amount of money” or “than great wealth”

Quote: Your hands have made and fashioned me
Note: God creating a person is spoken of as if God used his hands to shape the person the way someone may shape clay into an object. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here “hands” represents God’s power or action. Alternate translation: “You” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: because I find hope in your word
Note: Alternate translation: “because I trust what you say” or “I confidently believe what you say”

God promises to reward the righteous and punish wrongdoers, so he is faithful to do what he says he will. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “you punished me because you are faithful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: Let your covenant faithfulness comfort me
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “Comfort me by showing me that you are faithful to your covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
The writer refers to himself as “your servant.” Alternate translation: “me, your servant” or “me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

Quote: Let the proud be put to shame
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Put the proud to shame” or “Cause those who are proud to be ashamed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
This nominal adjective can be stated as an adjective. Alternate translation: “proud people” or “those who are proud” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

People returning in friendship to the writer is spoken of as if they physically turn towards him. Alternate translation: “come to me” or “unite with me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: those who know your covenant decrees
Note: This could mean: (1) this further describes those who honor God or (2) this indicates the purpose for those who honor God to return to the writer. Alternate translation: “so that they may learn your covenant decrees” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/grammar-connect-words-phrases]])
Here “heart” represents a person’s thoughts and motives. Alternate translation: “May I be blameless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: I may not be put to shame
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I may not be ashamed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Alternate translation: “I confidently trust in what you say”

Quote: My eyes long to see your promise
Note: Here “eyes” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “I wait and wait for you to do what you promised to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: I have become like a wineskin in the smoke
Note: A wineskin is ruined when it hangs for a long time in a smoke-filled place. The writer compares himself to a wineskin that has been ruined by smoke to emphasize that he feels useless. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: How long must your servant endure this; when will you judge those who persecute me?
Note: The writer uses a question to request God to punish those who persecute him. If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “Please do not make wait any longer. Punish those who persecute me.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
The writer refers to himself as “your servant.” Alternate translation: “must I, your servant” or “must I” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

Quote: The proud have dug pits for me
Note: The proud are seeking to capture the writer or cause him to do wrong. This is spoken of as if they were hunters digging holes to trap the writer like an animal. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This nominal adjective can be stated as an adjective. Alternate translation: “Proud people” or “Those who are proud” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

Quote: They have almost made an end to me on earth
Note: This is a polite way of speaking about someone killing someone else. Alternate translation: “They have almost killed me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])

“According to your steadfast love.” The phrase “steadfast love” or “faithfulness” can be stated as an adverb. Alternate translation: “because you faithfully love me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
Alternate translation: “what you have said will be true forever”

Quote: your word is established firmly in heaven
Note: This speaks about what God has said as if it were an object that stands firmly upright. Alternate translation: “what you have said will be true in heaven forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
“for all future generations.” This is an idiom that means “forever.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

All created things are spoken of as if they were persons who can serve God. Alternate translation: “all things serve you” or “all things obey your commands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “I will always remember” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])

Quote: for through them you have kept me alive

# Psalm 120 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 120 is a psalm of deliverance from liars. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/deliverer]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Fighting
The author did not want to fight, but the people he lived with wanted to fight him.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “In my trouble” or “When I was in trouble”
Here the word “life” represents the person. Alternate translation: “Rescue me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: those who lie with their lips and deceive with their tongues
Note: Here the phrases “their lips” and “their tongues” represent the people who speak lies and deceit. Alternate translation: “those who lie to me and try to deceive me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: How will he punish you, and what more will he do to you, you who have a lying tongue?
Note: The writer asks this as a leading question to explain what God will do to liars. If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “This is how God will punish you, and this is what he will do to you, you who have a lying tongue.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: you who have a lying tongue
Note: Here “a lying tongue” represents the person who speaks lies. Alternate translation: “you who tell lies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: He will punish you with the arrows of a warrior
Note: The writer speaks of God severely punishing liars as if God were shooting them with arrows. Alternate translation: “He will punish you severely, as if he were shooting you with warrior’s arrows” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: sharpened over burning coals of the broom tree
Note: This refers to how people forged the tip of the arrow in a fire. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “that he sharpened over burning coals of the broom tree” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: I temporarily live in Meshech; I lived previously among the tents of Kedar
Note: These two places were far away from each other. The writer is likely using the names metaphorically to represent living among cruel and barbaric people. Alternate translation: “It is as if I live in Meshech or among the tents of Kedar” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This phrase represents the people of Kedar who live in those tents. Alternate translation: “the people who live in Kedar” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Alternate translation: “I want peace”
Alternate translation: “they want war”

Psalm 121 is a worship psalm.

### Yahweh’s protection
God always watches over those who believe in him and protects them from harm. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/believe]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
This expression means “look at” or “focus my attention on.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: From where will my help come?
Note: The writer uses this question to focus attention on the source of his help. If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “I will tell you from where my help comes.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
This is the answer to the previous question.

# General Information:\n\nThere is a shift here to the second person. This could mean: (1) the writer begins speaking to the people of Israel or (2) the writer is quoting another person speaking to the writer. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
The slipping of a foot is associated with falling. Alternate translation: “you to fall” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: he who protects you will not slumber
Note: Here to “slumber” means he would stop protecting. The negative form strengthens the statement. Alternate translation: “God will not fall asleep and stop protecting you” or “God will always protect you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])

Quote: Yahweh is the shade at your right hand
Note: Here “shade” refers to protection. Alternate translation: “God is beside you to protect you from things that would hurt you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here this expression means to be beside or near to the writer.

# Psalm 122 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 122 is a psalm about Jerusalem.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Jerusalem
Jerusalem is an important city, the center of government and religious activities; so the author prays for peace for the city.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

This could mean: (1) “song people sang while going up to Jerusalem for a celebration” or (2) “song people sang while going up the steps into the temple” or (3) “song whose words are like steps.” See how you translated this in [Psalms 120:1](../120/001.md)

Quote: Jerusalem, our feet are standing within your gates!
Note: The writer briefly stops speaking to his audience and speaks directly to the city of Jerusalem. Jerusalem is spoken to as if it was a person who could hear the writer. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
Here “feet” refers to the whole person. Alternate translation: “we are standing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
Here “gates” refers to the city. Alternate translation: “inside you, Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
Here “name” refers to Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here “house” refers to the descendants of David. Alternate translation: “the descendants of David” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: May those who love you have peace
Note: This section states the content of the prayer that the writer wants his audience to pray. He asks them to speak directly to the city of Jerusalem, as if the city was a person who could hear them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

This verse finishes the prayer that the writer wants his audience to pray. He asks them to speak directly to the city of Jerusalem, as if the city was a person who could hear them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Note: These two phrases have the same meanings and are used together to strengthen each other. Alternate translation: “May the people in Jerusalem live in peace” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Note: Here Jerusalem is referred to by the fortress walls that protects it. The terms “walls” and “fortress” refer to the same thing. Alternate translation: “within Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

# General Information:\n\nIn this section, the writer speaks directly to the city of Jerusalem, as if the city was a person who could hear them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
Alternate translation: “For the well-being”

Quote: May there be peace within you
Note: Alternate translation: “May the people in you live in peace”

# Psalm 123 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 123 is a psalm asking for deliverance from the contempt of proud people. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/deliverer]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Trust
Just as a servant trusts his master to protect him, so the author is trusting God to stop proud people from insulting him. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/trust]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Here the author refers to his eyes because that is the part of the body used for seeing. Alternate translation: “I look to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
sitting on a throne and ruling as king

Quote: as the eyes of servants & as the eyes of a maid & so our eyes look
Note: These three phrases have similar meanings. The third phrase, about the Israelites, is being compared to how the servants and maids look to their masters and mistresses for help. In each case “eyes” refers to the whole person. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
Here “hand” refers to the provision for needs. Alternate translation: “master’s provision … mistress’s provision” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
servant girl
woman who has authority over servant girls

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **mercy**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “act mercifully toward us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **mercy**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. See how you translated a similar phrase in [Psalms 123:2](../123/002.md). Alternate translation: “act mercifully toward us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
Here humiliation is spoken of as if it were something that could be fill up a person. “we are very disgraced” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This idiom means that the amount is excessive, in a negative sense. Alternate translation: “We have had too much” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: of the scoffing & and with the contempt
Note: There two phrases have very similar meanings and are used together to emphasize how much they have been mocked by the people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “mocking” or “insults”
This refers to the insolent people. Alternate translation: “rude and arrogant people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
This refers to the proud people. Alternate translation: “the people who are proud” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

# Psalm 124 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 124 is a psalm of praise for God’s delivering the Israelites from their enemy’s attack. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/deliverer]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh saves
God saved the Israelites from their enemy who wanted to completely destroy them. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/save]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

This could mean: (1) “song people sang while going up to Jerusalem for a celebration” or (2) “song people sang while going up the steps into the temple” or (3) “song whose words are like steps.” See how you translated this in [Psalms 120:1](../120/001.md)

Quote: “If Yahweh had not been on our side
Note: This is the beginning of a hypothetical statement about something that did not actually happen. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])

Quote: if it had not been Yahweh who was on our side
Note: This is the continuation of a hypothetical statement about something that did not actually happen. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])

Quote: then they would have swallowed us up alive
Note: This is the end of a hypothetical statement that begins with the words “If Yahweh had not been on our side” in [Psalms 124:1](../124/001.md) and continues with the words “if it had not been Yahweh who was on our side when men rose up against us” in [Psalms 124:2](./002.md). It describes a result that did not happen because Yahweh was actually on their side. “They were not able to swallow us up alive because Yahweh was on our side.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])

This metaphor describes how the Israelites could have died to how a fierce animal would attack a smaller animal to eat. Alternate translation: “killed us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here “their anger” refers to the enemies who were angry. Alternate translation: “they were very angry with us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
# General Information:\n\nIn these two verses the author compares the enemies of Israel to a flood of water.

Quote: The water would have swept us away; the torrent would have overwhelmed us
Note: This is the end of a hypothetical statement that begins with the words “If Yahweh had not been on our side” in [Psalms 124:1](../124/001.md) and continues with the words “if it had not been Yahweh who was on our side when men rose up against us” in [Psalms 124:2](./002.md). It describes a result that did not happen because Yahweh was actually on their side. “The water did not sweep us away, and the torrent did not overwhelm us because Yahweh was on our side” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])

Quote: The water would have swept us away
Note: Here the enemies of the writer are spoken of as if they were a flood of water. Alternate translation: “Our enemies would have easily defeated us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the torrent would have overwhelmed us
Note: Here the enemies of the writer are spoken of as if they were a flood of water that would have drowned the Israelites. Alternate translation: “our enemies would have overwhelmed us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Then the raging waters would have drowned us
Note: This is the end of a hypothetical statement that begins with the words “If Yahweh had not been on our side” in [Psalms 124:1](../124/001.md) and continues with the words “if it had not been Yahweh who was on our side when men rose up against us” in [Psalms 124:2](./002.md). It describes a result that did not happen because Yahweh was actually on their side. “The raging waters did not drown us because Yahweh was on our side” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])

Quote: the raging waters would have drowned us
Note: Here the enemies of the writer are spoken of as if they were a raging river that would have drowned the Israelites. Alternate translation: “our enemies would have destroyed us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

The enemies are spoken of as if they were wild animals that would destroy the Israelites by eating them. Alternate translation: “destroyed as if we were eaten by wild animals” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: escaped like a bird out of the snare of the fowlers
Note: The writer describes his escape from the enemies as if he was a bird that had escaped from the snare of the hunters. Alternate translation: “escaped from our enemies as a bird escapes from the trap that hunters have set” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
a small trap of string or wire made for catching small animals or birds
The plot of the enemies to catch the writer failed as if it was a snare that had broken. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# Psalm 125 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 125 is a psalm of praise.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s protection
God protects good people. He will not allow the evil people to rule over the good people because they might make them do evil. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/good]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/evil]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Those who trust in Yahweh are like Mount Zion, unshakable, forever enduring
Note: People who trust in Yahweh are spoken of as if they were Mount Zion. Mountains are unable to be moved. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: As the mountains surround Jerusalem, so Yahweh surrounds his people
Note: Yahweh’s protection is spoken of as if he was the mountains surrounding Jerusalem. Jerusalem was surrounded by several mountains, which protected it from attack. Alternate translation: “As the hills that surround Jerusalem protect it, so Yahweh protects his people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
Here, this phrase means “always.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
Here the scepter of wickedness represents the rule of wicked people. Alternate translation: “Wicked people” or “Wicked rulers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
This is a request. Alternate translation: “Yahweh, please do good things” or “Yahweh, I beg you to do good things”
Here, “hearts” refers to their desires. Alternate translation: “desire to do the right” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Refusing to obey Yahweh is spoken of as turning away from a good path. Alternate translation: “leave good and go” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here wicked ways are spoken of as if they were a path that is not straight. Alternate translation: “their wicked ways” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

People are lead away in order to punish them. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “lead them away to punish them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

# Psalm 126 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 126 is a psalm of praise for Yahweh bringing captives home.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Sorrow and joy
People may have sorrow now; but later it will turn into joy. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/joy]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “made Zion prosperous again”

Quote: our mouths were filled with laughter
Note: Laughing is spoken of as if their mouths were a container and their laughter was in it. It can be made clear that this laughter was a response to their joy. Alternate translation: “we laughed for joy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

The verbs “were filled” can be stated clearly. Singing is spoken of as if their tongues were containers and singing was in them. Alternate translation: “our tongues were filled with singing” or “we sang songs of joy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
“the people of the nations said among themselves.” The pronoun is used before introducing what it references. This is very unusual.

Quote: Yahweh did great things for us; how glad we were!
Note: Alternate translation: “How glad we were, because Yahweh did these great things for us!”
Alternate translation: “Those who weep as they sow”

# Psalm 127 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 127 is a wisdom psalm. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/wise]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Blessings
God wants his people to have rest. It is a blessing to have many children. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/rest]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/bless]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

This could mean: (1) “song people sang while going up to Jerusalem for a celebration” or (2) “song people sang while going up the steps into the temple” or (3) “song whose words are like steps.” See how you translated this in [Psalms 120:1](../120/001.md)

Quote: to rise up early, to come home late
Note: A person who works hard often has to wake up earlier in the morning and return home late at night.

Quote: eat the bread of hard work
Note: This is an idiom. Bread often represents the food a person needs every day in order to live. Alternate translation: “work hard for your daily needs” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

property that a person can inherit from his ancestors. Children normally receive an inheritance from their parents. Inheritance goes from parents to children. This passage uses parents inheriting children from Yahweh as a metaphor for Yahweh being the only one who can give children. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Like arrows in the hand of a warrior, so are the children of one’s youth
Note: Arrows are very important to a warrior because they protect him in battle. Children are spoken of as if they are a warrior’s arrow. Alternate translation: “Having many children will help to protect you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

A quiver is a container for arrows. Having many children is spoken of as if the children were arrows in a quiver. Alternate translation: “a home full of children” or “many children” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# Psalm 128 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 128 is a wisdom psalm. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/wise]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Respect
Those people who respect God will live well and have many children. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/life]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Blessed is everyone who honors Yahweh
Note: This phrase occurs in the passive voice to avoid implying that Yahweh is obligated to bless those who honor him. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will bless everyone who honors him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

A man can be referred to by his hands because that is the part of the body he works with. Alternate translation: “What you provide” or “What you work for” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: you will be blessed and prosper
Note: The words “be blessed” and “prosper” share similar meanings and emphasize God’s favor. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will bless you and prosper you” or “Yahweh will make you blessed and prosperous” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

Quote: like a fruitful vine in your house
Note: The wife is spoke of as a vine producing a lot of fruit. This implies that children are like fruit and the wife will have many children. Alternate translation: “very productive and give you many children” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: your children will be like olive plants
Note: Children are compared to olive plants because of the way they grow to surround something. Children will surround the table and make it full. Alternate translation: “you will have many children who will grow and prosper” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
This refers to the place where a family gathers to eat. Often, all those who eat a man’s table are under his authority or control.

Quote: the man will be blessed who honors Yahweh
Note: This can be stated as an active verb. “Yahweh will bless the man who honors him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: all the days of your life
Note: Alternate translation: “throughout your lifetime”
Alternate translation: “May Israel have peace”

# Psalm 129 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 129 is a psalm of deliverance from Israel’s many enemies. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/deliverer]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh saves
Israel’s enemies have always persecuted them but God has saved them from their enemies. He prays that this enemy will be destroyed with no one to wish them well. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/save]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: The plowers plowed on my back
Note: The cuts from a whipping are spoken of as the plow of a plowman. A farmer plowed deep lines into a field. Alternate translation: “My enemies have cut me deeply on my back” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This is a continuation of the plowing metaphor. The “furrow” is the line the farmer plowed. Alternate translation: “they made their cuts long” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: he has cut the ropes of the wicked
Note: Israel is spoken of as being bound by evil people. Alternate translation: “he has freed us from our enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: May they all be put to shame and turned back
Note: Yahweh is not explicitly mentioned as the one who does these things. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “May Yahweh shame them and defeat them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: May they be like the grass on the housetops that withers before it grows up
Note: The psalmist speaks of his enemies dying and being few in number. He compares them to the little bit of grass that grows on the roof of a house and withers and is not enough to cut or bundle. Alternate translation: “May they die and may there be few of them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

These words finish the simile that begins in ([Psalms 129:6](../129/006.md)). The psalmist speaks of his enemies dying and being few in number. He compares them to the little bit of grass that grows on the roof of a house and withers and is not enough to cut or bundle. “May they be like the grass, which cannot fill … together” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: the blessing of Yahweh be on you
Note: Alternate translation: “Yahweh bless you”

# Psalm 130 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 130 is a psalm of praise that God forgives sins. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/forgive]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]])

## Special concepts in this chapter
### Forgive
God forgives sin and helps the sinner. So Israel should trust in God for his forgiveness. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/trust]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

The author’s sadness is spoken of as if it were a container. His sadness comes from the bottom of the container. Sadness is often spoken of as being a container that fills from the top to the bottom. Alternate translation: “Because I am very sad, I” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

The ears represent Yahweh, but because the author knows that Yahweh hears everything, he is really asking for Yahweh to respond. Alternate translation: “please listen” or “please respond” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **mercy**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “merciful.” Alternate translation: “to my pleas and be merciful to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

The speaker uses this question to express the futility of thinking that anyone could stand in this situation. If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “no one could stand.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

“Stand” often represents escaping or surviving when someone attacks. In this case, it would be to escape from being punished. Alternate translation: “no one could escape from your punishment” or “no one could survive your punishment” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
“My soul” represents the psalmist. Alternate translation: “I” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

The psalmist is spoken of as if he were waiting on something with expectation. Alternate translation: “I hope” or “I trust” or “I desire for something” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: My soul waits & more than watchmen wait for the morning
Note: The psalmist speaks of his desire for the Lord to help him as being greater than the desire that those who work all night have for the morning to come. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
These are men who guard towns or fields against enemies or robbers. Here it refers to men who have to stay awake at night doing this.
The people of Israel are spoken of as if they were a man. Alternate translation: “You people of Israel, hope in Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: who will redeem Israel from all his sins
Note: The people of Israel are spoken of as if they were a man. Alternate translation: “who will redeem the people of Israel from all their sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# Psalm 131 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 131 is a wisdom psalm teaching trust in Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/wise]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/trust]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Trust
This psalm focuses on the concept of trust. A quiet trust in Yahweh is best.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

This could mean: (1) “song people sang while going up to Jerusalem for a celebration” or (2) “song people sang while going up the steps into the temple” or (3) “song whose words are like steps.” See how you translated this in [Psalms 120:1](../120/001.md)

Quote: my heart is not proud or my eyes haughty
Note: The heart and the eyes represent the person. Alternate translation: “I am not proud or haughty” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: I do not have great hopes for myself
Note: Possible meanings are “I do not expect to do great things” or “I do not think I am great.”

Things that are too hard for a person to understand are spoken of as if they are beyond the person or too far away from the person to be able to reach them. Alternate translation: “things that are too hard to understand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I have stilled and quieted my soul
Note: The soul represents the person or his emotions. Being calm and peaceful is spoken of has having making one’s soul still and quiet. Alternate translation: “I am calm and peaceful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The soul represents the person or his emotions. Alternate translation: “I” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: a weaned child with his mother
Note: The psalmist speaks of himself being content and resting as if he were a young child that no longer demands breast milk from his mother. Alternate translation: “content like a young child that no longer cries for breast milk but rests in his mother’s arms” or “content and resting” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# Psalm 132 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 132 is a royal psalm praising David. It might have been sung when David brought the ark to Jerusalem.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Ark
The Ark had been moved from one place to another several times. David wanted to make a permanent home for it. God had promised David that his son would be king after him. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/promise]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “because of what happened to David”
Alternate translation: “remember” or “think about”
This refers to God.
Alternate translation: “King David said”

Quote: I will not give sleep to my eyes or rest to my eyelids
Note: Sleep and rest are spoken of as if they are things that can be given. Here eyes and eyelids represent the whole person. Alternate translation: “I will not allow my eyes to sleep or my eyelids to rest” or “I will not sleep or close my eyes and rest” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: until I find a place for Yahweh
Note: Building a place for Yahweh is spoken of as finding a place for him. Alternate translation: “until I build a place for Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
This refers to God.

Quote: we heard about it in Ephrathah
Note: The word “it” probably refers to where God’s sacred chest was. The phrase “in Ephrathah” probably refers to where they were when they heard about it. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “we who were in Ephrathah heard about where the sacred chest was” or “we in Ephrathah heard that the holy box was in Jaar” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Jaar is probably another name for the city of Kiriath Jearim. This probably refers to the fields surrounding the city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: we will worship at his footstool
Note: Worshiping God at the covenant box is spoken of as bowing at the feet of the king who is sitting on his throne. This communicates humility and submission to God. Alternate translation: “we will go to God’s covenant box and worship him as king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Arise, Yahweh, to your resting place
Note: The verb “come” can be stated clearly. “Arise, Yahweh, and come to your resting place” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

The place God chose for people to worship him is spoken of as if it were a place where he rests or lives eternally. Alternate translation: “the place where you stay” or “your tabernacle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: you and the ark of your strength!
