# Psalm 140 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 140 is a deliverance psalm. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/deliverer]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s protection
He prayed that God would save him from his enemies who are lying about him. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/save]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
This is for the director of music to use in worship.”
Here “battles” probably refers to conflict of any kind, including quarrels.

People who cause conflict by what they say are spoken of as if they had tongues of serpents. Of course, snakes do not do damage with their tongues, but with their bites and especially with poison. Neither can a person make his tongue sharp. Instead, here the idea of a sharp tongue stands for speaking in a way to cause trouble. And the idea the snakes have sharp tongues stands for the fact that many of them have poison. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
That is, the power of the wicked (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: have set a trap & have spread a net & have set a snare
Note: The exact kinds of traps are less important than the idea that wicked and proud people are planning to make trouble for the psalmist. If your readers do not know much about different ways of trapping, you may need to reduce this to one line. Alternate translation: “have set a trap to catch me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
This is a call for help. Alternate translation: “listen to me as I call to you now for help” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: you shield my head in the day of battle
Note: A person’s head is in great danger during battle. Protecting the person’s head represents protecting the whole person. Alternate translation: “you protect me when I go to war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here “battle” probably stands for any kind of severe trouble (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: do not grant the desires of the wicked
Note: Alternate translation: “please do not allow the wicked to have what they desire”
The adjective “wicked” can be translated as a noun phrase. Alternate translation: “wicked people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
This is a sign of being arrogant. Alternate translation: “are arrogant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

Quote: let the mischief of their own lips cover them
Note: This is a prayer that God would make the evildoers suffer from the trouble that they caused by the things they said.

Quote: the mischief of their own lips
Note: The trouble that they themselves caused by what they said. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
That is, stop them from causing any more trouble. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Let burning coals fall on them; throw them into the fire
Note: Images of fire stand for severe punishment for the wicked. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This is probably a reference to Sheol, the world of the dead.
those who speak evil of others without cause (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Alternate translation: “safe in this life”

Quote: may evil hunt down the violent man
Note: Here evil is spoken of as if it were someone taking revenge on another person. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: he will give justice to the needy
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **justice**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “just.” Alternate translation: “He will act in a just manner to help the needy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
This represents Yahweh. Alternate translation: “to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

# Psalm 141 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 141 is a psalm of deliverance from his enemies and from sin. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/deliverer]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s correction
The author prayed that God would keep him from sinning. He is glad to be corrected by good people. He asked God to show that he is right by destroying the evil leaders of the people. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]], [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/good]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/righteous]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/evil]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “asking you for help”

The psalmist speaks as if Yahweh were a person who needed to come from another place to help him. What the psalmist wanted Yahweh to do can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “come quickly to help me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: Listen to me when I call
Note: Alternate translation: “Please hear me when I call” or “I beg you to hear me when I call”

Quote: May my prayer be like incense
Note: The psalmist asks Yahweh to accept and be pleased with his prayer the way he would accept and be pleased with incense. Alternate translation: “May the my prayer please you the way the sweet smell of incense pleases people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
The psalmist wants Yahweh to be pleased with him because he is praying and because of the words of his prayer. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

“the hands that I have lifted up.” Lifted hands are a metonym for prayer. People lifted their hands when they prayed or praised Yahweh. See how you translated “lift up your hands” in [Psalms 134:2](../134/002.md).

The means to be like the animal that was burned on the altar in the evening. The psalmist speaks as if he wants Yahweh to be as pleased with him as he is with those who bring animals to sacrifice. He wants Yahweh to be pleased because the psalmist is praying or because of the words of his prayer. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: place a guard over my mouth
Note: The psalmist speaks as if evil words were prisoners trying to escape from his mouth. Alternate translation: “please help me not to say things that are evil” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “tell someone to guard”

Quote: guard the door of my lips
Note: The psalmist speaks as if evil words were prisoners trying to escape from his mouth. Alternate translation: “please help me not to say things when I should not” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “do sinful deeds”
Alternate translation: “their special foods”

The psalmist speaks as if giving a rebuke were physically hitting someone. Alternate translation: “rebuke me” or “hit me so I will listen when he corrects me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: it will be a kindness to me
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **kindness**, you could express the same idea with an adverb. Alternate translation: “he will be acting kindly to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: it will be like oil on my head
Note: Possible meanings are that the psalmist speaks as if a person correcting him were putting oil on his head: (1) to honor him. Alternate translation: “when he corrects me, I will know that the one who corrects me is doing a good deed to me” or (2) to make his head feel better. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: may my head not refuse to accept it
Note: The head is a synecdoche for the person. The litotes can be translated as a positive statement. Alternate translation: “may I accept it gladly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])

Quote: my prayer is always against their wicked deeds
Note: The words “wicked deeds” are a metonym for the people who do the wicked deeds. Alternate translation: “I always pray that Yahweh will stop wicked people from doing evil deeds” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Their leaders will be thrown down
Note: This could mean: (1) “Someone will throw their leaders down” or (2) “Their leaders will throw them down.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
ground that goes straight down a long way
This could mean: (1) “people have thrown our bones around in different directions” or (2) as a result of the fall from the cliffs (141:6) “our bodies are broken and our bones lie in disorder.”
The eyes are a synecdoche for the whole person. Alternate translation: “I am looking to see what you will do” or “I expect you to help me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
“I am asking you to protect me” See how “take refuge” is translated in [Psalms 118:9](../118/009.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The soul is a metonym for the whole person. Alternate translation: “me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: the snares that they have laid for me
Note: The psalmist speaks of deceiving a good man so the good man will sin or so that the evil people can defeat him as if it were laying a trap for an animal. The word “snares” is a metonym for the people themselves. Alternate translation: “people who are looking for ways to harm me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Bible experts disagree on the exact meanings of these words. It would be best either to translate one of them with the word for a net or cage that contains the prey and the other as a rope or vine that catches the prey by the leg or neck or to translate both with the general word for “traps.” See how these words are translated in [Psalms 140:5](../140/005.md).
The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “and protect me from the traps that those who do evil have set” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: Let the wicked fall into their own nets
Note: The psalmist speaks of evil people deceiving good people as if hunters were trapping animals. Alternate translation: “Let the wicked fall into the net traps they have made to trap other people” or “Let the bad things the wicked planned for the righteous happen to the wicked instead”

# Psalm 142 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 142 is a psalm of deliverance from his enemies. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/deliverer]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s help
The psalmist is alone, and has many enemies surrounding him. Despite this, Yahweh will help him. Then, good people will join the author. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/good]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
This may refer to a style of music. See how you translated this in [Psalms 32:1](../032/001.md).
open place under the earth large enough for people to walk around in

Note: If these two lines are so much the same that the reader will get the wrong meaning, you can translate them as one line. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
“using my voice” -

Quote: pour out my lament before him & I tell him my troubles
Note: If these two lines are so much the same that the reader will get the wrong meaning, you can translate them as one line. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

Quote: pour out my lament before him
Note: The psalmist speaks of telling Yahweh why he is sad as if he were pouring all of a liquid out of a container. Alternate translation: “I tell him all about why I am sad” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “tell him about everything that makes me worry”

Quote: my spirit is weak within me
Note: Alternate translation: “I am weak” or “I am extremely discouraged”

“you know the path I should take.” The psalmist speaks as if what a person does were a path that that person walked along. Alternate translation: “you know the way I should live” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: In the way that I walk they have hidden a trap for me
Note: The psalmist speaks of people wanting to harm him as if they were trying to trap an animal. Alternate translation: “They are making plans so that whatever I do they can harm me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This is a metonym for “me.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
This is a call for help. Alternate translation: “called to you now for help” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
This could mean: (1) “all I want” or (2) “all I need” or (3) “all I have.”

Quote: in the land of the living
Note: This idiom refers to a person being alive, as opposed to a person who is dead and in the place of the dead. Alternate translation: “while I am living” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

This is a call for help. See how you translated this in [Psalms 5:1](../005/001.md). Alternate translation: “Listen to me as I call to you now for help” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Note: This could mean: (1) “I am very needy” and (2) “I am very weak.” See how “we are very low” is translated in [Psalms 78:8](../078/008.md).

Note: This is a request. The “soul” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “bring me out of prison” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

# Psalm 143 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 143 is a deliverance psalm. The author prays for deliverance from his enemies. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/deliverer]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s help
The author prayed for help from Yahweh against his enemies because he is God’s servant.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

The words “my prayer” are a metonym for the person who is praying. See how these words are translated in [Psalms 39:12](../039/012.md). Alternate translation: “Listen to me as I pray to you” or “Be willing to do what I ask you to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
To “enter into judgment” is an idiom that means to pronounce judgment. Alternate translation: “Please do not judge” or “I beg you not to judge” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
The psalmist speaks of himself as if he were speaking of another person. Alternate translation: “me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

Quote: in your sight no one is righteous
Note: Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: “in your judgment no one is righteous” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here the word “soul” represents the person. Alternate translation: “pursued me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: has crushed me to the ground
Note: Defeating an enemy is spoken of as a heavy object crushing a lighter object on the ground. Alternate translation: “has completely defeated me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: My spirit is overwhelmed within me
Note: Alternate translation: “I am weak” or “I am extremely discouraged”
Alternate translation: “I no longer have any hope”
Alternate translation: “think about”
Alternate translation: “all that you have accomplished” or “all the great things you have done”

Quote: spread my hands out to you
Note: What one does with one’s body here is a metonym for the purpose of doing so. The Israelites would commonly pray while standing with their hands raised and spread out at their sides. Alternate translation: “pray to you with my hands lifted up at my sides” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: my soul thirsts for you in a parched land
Note: The psalmist speaks of wanting to be with God as if he were in a parched land and he also was about to die of thirst. Alternate translation: “I want to be with you the way a person in a parched land who is very thirsty wants water” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

The psalmist desires to know Yahweh. The intensity of his desire to know Yahweh is like one who is very thirsty. Alternate translation: “I long for you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The soul is a metonym for the person. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
A land where everything has died because there is no water.

Here the “spirit” refers to the whole person. Alternate translation: “I am weak” or “I am very discouraged” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: Do not hide your face from me
Note: This is a request. “I beg you not to hide from me” or “Please, do not hide from me”

Quote: Do not hide your face from me
Note: The psalmist speaks of Yahweh refusing to do what the psalmist asks as if Yahweh were refusing to even look at the psalmist. This litotes can be stated as a positive. Alternate translation: “Do not refuse to listen to me” or “Please listen to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])

Quote: I will become like those who go down into the pit
Note: Here the word “pit” refers to the place of the dead. This phrase is a euphemism for death. Alternate translation: “I will become just another dead person” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])

Quote: Let me hear your covenant faithfulness
Note: “Cause me to hear of your covenant faithfulness” or “Tell me of your covenant faithfulness.” If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “Let me hear of how you are faithful to your covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
This could mean: (1) “in the morning,” at the time many people thought was the best time to pray, or (2) “morning by morning,” every day.

Note: The psalmist speaks of the way people live as if it were a path on which they walk. Alternate translation: “how you want me to live” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: for I lift up my soul to you
Note: This could mean: (1) “I pray to you” or (2) “I believe that you will guide and protect me.”

Note: This could mean: (1) “I flee to you so I can hide” and (2) “I flee to you so you will hide and protect me.”

Quote: lead me in the land of uprightness
Note: This could mean: (1) “help me to live righteously” or (2) “may my life be free of trouble” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This could mean: (1) this is a metaphor for righteous living or (2) “a level land,” a metaphor for life free of trouble. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Yahweh’s name represents his reputation and character. Alternate translation: “because of who you are” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Alternate translation: “the enemies who want to take my life”

Note: “Show your covenant faithfulness by cutting off my enemies.” If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. “the enemies of my soul.” My “life” may be understood as representing the speaker. Alternate translation: “my enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

# Psalm 144 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 144 is a worship psalm. It is the first worship psalm in a series consisting of the final seven psalms (Psalms 144-150).

## Special concepts in this chapter
### Safety
Psalm 144 is a prayer for safety and prosperity for the nation of Israel.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
This could mean: (1) “the one who keeps me safe” or (2) “the one who gives me strength” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: who trains my hands for war and my fingers for battle
Note: The words “hands” and “fingers” are synecdoches for “me.” If “war” and “battle” are the same word in your language, you can translate this as one line. Alternate translation: “who trains me for war and trains me for battle” or “who trains me for war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with anadverb. This could mean: (1) “the one who faithfully loves me” or (2) “the one who faithfully protects me.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
The psalmist uses many metaphors to emphasize that Yahweh will protect him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
David speaks of Yahweh as if he were a fortress that protects him from attack. Yahweh is the one who protects David from harm. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

David speaks of Yahweh as if he were a shield that protects a soldier. Yahweh is the one who protects David from harm. See how this is translated in [Psalms 18:2](../018/002.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the one in whom I take refuge
Note: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. Alternate translation: “the one to whom I go so he will protect me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the one who subdues nations under me
Note: Alternate translation: “the one who enables me to defeat other nations”

Quote: Yahweh, what is man that you take notice of him or the son of man that you think about him?

two words for human beings. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

These words should probably be translated as requests, not commands, since the psalmist knows that God is greater than he is.
This could mean: (1) tear the sky open or (2) bend the heavens like a tree branch bends when someone walks on it or as one bends a bow before shooting arrows.
These should probably be translated as requests, not commands, since the psalmist knows that God is greater than he is.

# Psalm 145 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 145 is a worship psalm. This is the second in a series of worship psalms consisting of the final seven psalms (Psalms 144-150).

## Special concepts in this chapter
### Praise
God is worthy of all praise. This is in part because he does such wonderful things for all who worship him.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
Alternate translation: “tell people how wonderful you are”

The word “name” is a metonym for Yahweh himself. See how “may his glorious name be blessed” is translated in [Psalms 72:19](../072/019.md). Alternate translation: “bless you” or “do what makes you happy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
The word “name” is a metonym for Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “praise you” or “tell people how great you are” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Alternate translation: “the things you can do because you are strong”
Alternate translation: “tell others how very good you are”

The psalmist speaks of covenant faithfulness as if it were a physical object of which one could possess a large amount. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “completely faithful to his covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: his tender mercies are over all his works
Note: Alternate translation: “people can see him showing mercy in everything he does”

Quote: All you have made will give thanks
Note: Alternate translation: “All the people you have made will give thanks” or “It will be as if everything you have made will give you thanks”
Alternate translation: “remains forever”

Quote: supports all who are falling & raises up all those who are bent over
Note: The psalmist speaks of Yahweh encouraging people as if he were helping people who were physically weak. You may need to translate both lines using only one line. AT “encourages those who are discouraged” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here the word “eyes” represents those who watch and wait for Yahweh to act. Alternate translation: “Everyone watches and waits” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
Alternate translation: “You generously provide”

Quote: satisfy the desire of every living thing
Note: Alternate translation: “you give everyone more than they need and as much as they want”

Quote: Yahweh is righteous in all his ways
Note: Alternate translation: “People can see from everything that Yahweh does that he is righteous”
Alternate translation: “and he is gracious in all he does” or “people can see from everything that Yahweh does that he is gracious”

Quote: is near to all those who call to him
Note: Here “is near” means “ready to help.” Alternate translation: “is always ready to help all those who call to him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: to all who call to him in trustworthiness
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **trustworthiness**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “to all who tell only the truth when they pray” or “to all whom he trusts when they pray” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
Here the words “My mouth” represent the one speaking. Alternate translation: “I will speak” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: will speak out the praise of Yahweh
Note: Alternate translation: “tell everyone how good Yahweh is”

Quote: let all mankind bless his holy name
Note: The word “name” is a metonym for Yahweh himself. See how “may his glorious name be blessed” is translated in [Psalms 72:19](../072/019.md). Alternate translation: “let all people bless him” or “let all people do what makes him happy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

# Psalm 146 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 146 is a worship psalm. It is the third in series of seven worship psalms. (Psalms 144-150)

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Trust
Trusting people for protection is useless because they die. But God blesses everyone who trusts in him. He provides everything people need. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/trust]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/save]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/bless]])
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Here “soul” represents the writer’s inner being. The writer is commanding his inner being to praise Yahweh. If your readers would misunderstand this question, you can express it as a statement. Alternate translation: “I will praise Yahweh with all my soul” or “I give praise to Yahweh with all my life” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Alternate translation: “until I die” or “while I live”
Here “princes” represents all human leaders. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: in mankind, in whom there is no salvation
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **salvation**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “save.” Alternate translation: “in any person because they cannot save you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
Alternate translation: “in humankind” or “in people”

Quote: When a person’s life’s breath stops
Note: This is a polite way to refer to someone dying. Alternate translation: When a person dies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
This means that just as God made the first human, Adam, from the soil, so will a person’s body decay and become soil again when he dies. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
The words “heaven” and “earth” represent everything that exists in the physical universe. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **trustworthiness**, you could express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “remains trustworthy” or “remains faithful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
Alternate translation: “He decides matters fairly”
This nominal adjective can be stated as adjectives. Alternate translation: “for oppressed people” or “for those whom other people oppress” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
This nominal adjective can be stated as adjectives. Alternate translation: “to hungry people” or “to those who are hungry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

Quote: opens the eyes of the blind
Note: Causing a blind person to see is spoken of as if Yahweh were opening the person’s eyes. Alternate translation: “causes the blind to see” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This nominal adjective can be stated as adjectives. Alternate translation: “blind people” or “those who are blind” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

Quote: Yahweh raises up those who are bowed down
Note: Yahweh helping someone is spoken of as if he were physically helping someone to stand up. Alternate translation: “Yahweh helps those who are discouraged” or “Yahweh helps those who are weak” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This action is a sign of distress or mourning. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
God helping someone is spoken of as if he were physically lifting them up. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Here “Zion” represents all the people of Israel. The writer is speaking to the people of Israel as if they were there listening to him. Alternate translation: “your God, people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
The words “will reign” are understood. Alternate translation: “will reign for all generations” or “will reign forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

# Psalm 147 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 147 is a worship psalm. It is the fourth in a series of seven worship psalms. (Psalms 144-150)

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s control
Yahweh has created everything and controls all of nature. He provides for the animals and people.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
The object may be supplied from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “it is pleasant to sing praises” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
Alternate translation: “praise is fitting” or “praise is appropriate”

Quote: He heals the brokenhearted and binds up their wounds
Note: The writer speaks of the people’s sorrow and discouragement as if they were physical wounds, and of Yahweh encouraging them as if he were healing those wounds. Alternate translation: “He encourages those who are sad and helps them to heal from their emotional wounds” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “no one can measure his understanding” or “his understanding has no limit” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

The writer speaks of Yahweh honoring those who are oppressed as if Yahweh were lifting them up from the ground. Alternate translation: “Yahweh honors the oppressed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: he brings the wicked down to the ground
Note: The writer speaks of Yahweh humiliating the wicked as if Yahweh were forcing them to lie on the ground. Alternate translation: “he humiliates the wicked” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Alternate translation: “while playing a harp”

Quote: to the young ravens when they cry
Note: The verbal phrase can be supplied from the previous line. Alternate translation: “he gives food to the young ravens when they cry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
Alternate translation: “whey they chirp” or “when they call”

Quote: He finds no delight in the strength of a horse
Note: Alternate translation: “Strong horses do not delight him”

Quote: the strong legs of a man
Note: This could mean: (1) “strong legs” is a metonym that represents how swiftly a man can run. Alternate translation: “men who can run swiftly” or (2) “strong legs” represents the strength of the whole man. Alternate translation: “how strong a man is” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: who hope in his covenant faithfulness
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea with and adjective. Alternate translation: “who trust him because he is faithful to his covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

The writer speaks to Jerusalem, which he also calls Zion, as if it were a person. The names of the city are metonyms for the people who live in it. Alternate translation: “people of Jerusalem … people of Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: For he strengthens the bars of your gates
Note: The phrase “the bars of your gates” represent the city as a whole. Yahweh will make Jerusalem secure from enemy invasion. Alternate translation: “For he protects Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
The writer speaks of those who live in Jerusalem as if they were Jerusalem’s children. Alternate translation: “he blesses those who live in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

“He brings peace.” This could mean: (1) Yahweh causes the people who live in Jerusalem to prosper materially and financially or (2) the word translated as “prosperity” means “peace” and Yahweh keeps Jerusalem safe from enemy attack.
The writer describes God’s command as if it were a messenger that moves quickly to deliver God’s message. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: He makes the snow like wool, he scatters the frost like ashes
Note: These emphasize how easy it is for him to do these things. He covers the ground with snow as easily as a person covers something with a wool blanket. And, he removes the frost as easily as the wind blows ashes. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: He dispenses the hail like crumbs
Note: Yahweh scatters hail as easily as a person would scatter bread crumbs. Alternate translation: “He dispenses the hail easily, as if it were crumbs” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
Alternate translation: “He sends”
small pieces of ice that fall from the sky like rain

Quote: who can withstand the cold he sends?
Note: The writer uses this question to emphasize that it is difficult to endure the cold weather that Yahweh causes. Alternate translation: “no one can live in the cold he sends.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: He sends out his command and melts them
Note: The writer speaks of Yahweh’s command as if it were his messenger. The word “command” can be translated with a verb. Alternate translation: “He commands the ice to melt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: He proclaimed his word to Jacob, his statutes and his righteous decrees to Israel
Note: These two lines mean the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh gave his law only to Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: his statutes and his righteous decrees to Israel
Note: The verbal phrase can be supplied from the previous line. Alternate translation: “He proclaimed his statutes and his righteous decrees to Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: his statutes and his righteous decrees
Note: The words “statutes” and “righteous decrees,” along with “word” in the previous line, all refer to the law of Moses. If your language does not have different words for these terms, you may combine the two lines into one, using either “Jacob” or “Israel” for the people who received them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
The other nations do not know Yahweh’s decrees.

# Psalm 148 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 148 is a worship psalm. It is the fifth in a series of seven worship psalms. (Psalms 144-150)

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Praise
All creation, including humans, should praise God for his greatness.
# General Information:\n\nParallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Praise Yahweh, you in the heavens & you in the heights
Note: “Praise Yahweh, you in the heavens … you in the sky.” These two lines are parallel, with phrase “the heights” meaning the same thing as “the heavens” in the previous line. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

The writer speaks to the sun and moon as if they were people and commands them to praise Yahweh. Alternate translation: “Praise Yahweh, sun and moon, as people do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: praise him, all you shining stars
Note: The writer speaks to the shining stars as if they were people and commands them to praise Yahweh. Alternate translation: “Praise Yahweh, shining stars, as people do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

The phrase “highest heaven” is an idiom that refers to heaven itself. The writer speaks to heaven as if it were a person and commands it to praise Yahweh. Alternate translation: “Praise Yahweh, highest heaven, as people do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: you waters that are above the sky
Note: The writer speaks to “the waters that are above the sky” as if they are people and commands them to praise Yahweh. The verbal phrase can be supplied from the previous line. Alternate translation: “praise him, you waters that are above the sky, as people do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: waters that are above the sky
Note: The writer speaks of a place above the sky where water is stored and from which the rain comes.

Quote: Let them praise the name of Yahweh
Note: Here the word “name” represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “Let them praise Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “he created them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: he issued a decree that will never change
Note: This could mean: (1) “he gave a command that is permanent” or (2) “he gave a command that they will not disobey.”
Alternate translation: “he gave”
This phrase represents every creature that lives in the depths of the oceans. Alternate translation: “all creatures in the ocean depths” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: fire and hail, snow and clouds, stormy wind
Note: The writer speaks to these natural phenomena as if they are people and commands them to praise Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
Alternate translation: “stormy wind that does what Yahweh commands”
The writer continues to speak to things that are not human as if they were people and commands them to praise Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
The words “wild” and “tame” are opposites. Together they encompass all animals. Alternate translation: “all animals” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
# Connecting Statement:\n\nThe writer commands all people to praise Yahweh.
The word “nations” represents the people who live in those nations. Alternate translation: “people of every nation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: young men and young women, elderly and children
Note: The writer uses two merisms, one related to gender and one related to age, to represent every person. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

Quote: the name of Yahweh, for his name alone
Note: Here the word “name” represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “Yahweh, for he alone” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: his glory extends over the earth and the heavens
Note: The writer speaks of Yahweh’s greatness as his glory being high above earth and heaven. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: He has lifted up the horn of his people
Note: The writer speaks of strength as if it were the horn of an animal. Lifting up an animal horn was a symbolic action that represented military victory. Alternate translation: “He has made his people strong” or “He has given his people victory” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

Quote: for praise from all his faithful ones
Note: Alternate translation: “so that all his faithful ones praise him”
The writer speaks of Yahweh loving his people as if his people were physically close to him. Alternate translation: “the people he loves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# Psalm 149 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 149 is a worship psalm. It is the sixth in a series of seven worship psalms. (Psalms 144-150)

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Praise
The people of Israel should praise God and conquer the other nations.

# General Information:\n\nThe psalmist is speaking to all of God’s people, so you should use the plural command form if your language has one. Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pronouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
This could mean: (1) “a song you have never sung before” or (2) a song no one has ever sung before.
Alternate translation: “praise him with songs”

Quote: rejoice in the one who made them
Note: This could mean: (1) “rejoice because he made them” or (2) “rejoice because the one who made them is good.”
The words “their king” is likely a reference to God. This could mean: (1) “rejoice because he is their king” or (2) “rejoice because their king is good.”
The word “name” is a metonym for Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “praise him” or “tell people how great he is” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
a musical instrument with a head like a drum that can be hit and with pieces of metal around the side that sound when the instrument is shaken (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **salvation**, you could express the same idea with a verbal phrase. Alternate translation: “glorifies the humble by saving them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
This can be restated to remove the nominal adjective. Alternate translation: “those who are humble” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

The translation can make explicit that this refers to when a person lies down at night to sleep in a bed. Alternate translation: “as they lie down to sleep at night” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: May the praises of God be in their mouths
Note: The mouth represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “May they always be ready to praise God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: a two-edged sword in their hand
Note: If swords are not known, use the name of a local weapon. The word “sword” is a metonym for being ready to fight in war. Alternate translation: “may they always be ready to go to war for him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
The phrase “the nations” is a metonym for the people who live in the nations. Alternate translation: “the people of the nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
These are made of heavy metal and restrict the movement of prisoners.
a pair of chains or bands with a chain between that limits the movement of both a person’s hands or feet.

Quote: They will execute the judgment that is written
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **judgment**, you could express the same idea with a verbal form such as “judge.” Alternate translation: “They will judge and punish the people of those nations as God wrote should be done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

# Psalm 150 General Notes

## Type of psalm

Psalm 150 is a worship psalm. It is last in a series of worship psalms. (Psalms 144-150)

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Instruments
People should praise Yahweh with every type of musical instrument.

# General Information:\n\nThis focuses on praise or worship that is most commonly held in the temple. Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Praise God in his holy place
Note: God’s temple was often referred to as his holy place. This was the most common place to go to worship God.
“the great things he has done.” God’s **mighty acts** could mean: (1) natural such as thunderstorms and earthquakes or (2) miraculous such as healings and great victories in battle.
# General Information:\n\nThis chunk focuses on praising or worshiping God with musical instruments and dance.

A tambourine is a musical instrument with a head like a drum that can be hit and with pieces of metal around the side that sound when the instrument is shaken. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
two thin, round metal plates that are hit together to make a loud sound (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
# General Information:\n\nThis verse is more than the end of this psalm. It is the closing statement for all of Book 5 of the Psalms, which starts at Psalm 107 and ends with Psalm 150.
This is an exaggeration that calls on all people who are alive to praise God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
